reviews.review_text: There is something to be said for a game that I just don't get sick of. I have owned this on console and played through TVHM at least 4 times with 4 different characters there. Played all the DLC except Tiny Tina on console, but when the GOTY edition became so cheap on PC I jumped at it and bought all the Headhunter DLCs, and the Ultimate Vault Hunter Pack as well. So I can now play through the game THREE times on a character. Dar  I'm so addicted to this game still, but the funny thing is that I don't even finish it, or even come close to it now. I'm in a mass addiction to boosting my Badass Ranks so I just keep trying to 'prestige' it instead of moving on and going towards UVHM. xD  I feel like I can pick this game up and play it at any time. Do a few things, and then quit playing. Unfortunately, for me anyways, I don't do that. I keep playing for hours, and I let all the other hundreds of games in my library continue to pile up.   I play this game EXCLUSIVELY in SINGLE PLAYER. People will tell you that it is much more fun playing with friends, and truly it can be, but don't disregard this game as a single player game. It is insanely addictive, and it actually poses some slight challenges to you to play it solo. Beating Raid Bosses solo is actually a genuine accomplishment, if you can actually do it. They are meant to be beaten witha 4 player team, but you CAN beat many of them solo. The new Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode (UVHM) makes it an even more insane challenge to play solo just for the regular game enemies. Needing to pump them full of slag just so you can actually get ready to start damaging them with any real power. Of course all this is basically a math problem of damage output vs. damage defense.   Borderlands 2, simply put, is one of the best games ever made in my opinion. The sheer addictiveness and fun in playing it are jsut off the charts. I recommend this to anyone, even if you think you won't like it. I thought Borderlands 1 looked stupid for years until I bought it for $5 with everything and realized how amzing the concept is and how it was made for OCD gamers. Now they are both 2 of my most played games ever, and I don't see myself stopping BL2 anytime soon. After all I ahven't even used The Psycho yet!  Buy the GOTY Edition. It is the best deal by far and has most of the relevant content you will want. Forget about the Season Pass and regular game. GOTY has all that stuff and more. Then buy the Ultimate Vault Hunter Pack to get extra level sand a 3rd round. The headhunter DLCs are worth it too for the cheap prices. Only thing not to buy are the stupid skin packs. Unless you like that sort of thing. Wait for it to go 75% off and you can get GOTY, UVH Pack, and allt he Headhunter DLCs for less than $20. BTW...these DLCs are legit and worth buying. This isn't some garbage map pack DLC, or jsut skins. These are high quality and large DLCs on the scale of the FAllout DLCs, and add even more than that in some of tehm. GOTY edition has almost too much content. >_>
It has a shotgun that shoots swords Nuff said
1. gather some friends 2. get some drinks and everything 3. play the game 4. get some sleep 5. wake up 6. dont shower 7. and repeat

Borderlands is an FPS+RPG game that includes tons of shooting and looting fun.  Probably one of my favorite games of all time, I've had so much fun both in singleplayer and with other friends. The game has lots and lots of dlcs for you to enjoy, not to mention all the different guns this game has. It has such a massive variation , almost every gun spawn with random parts from each manufacturer which makes it even more interesting. The art style is cartoon-ish which i think is absolutely great makes it really cool to play.   The game has alot of replay value since they give you already 4 characters with their own uniqe skills to play around with plus the two dlc characters. The game is fairly long and there is still alot of stuff to do if you actualy complete it. The world is completely open and there is alot of exploring to do in the game. I've spent up to many hours getting just one gun that i wanted, but when you finally get the gun you have been farming or hunting for you really feel that you have achieved something.   I made alot of friends in the past playing this game, either i joined random games or i found someone through the community, we had tons of fun together and we always kept on playing it every day. The coop has space for up to 4 players which i think is just fine considering the balancing of enemies (The more players you harder the game becomes, the better loot you will get.) That's really all i have to say about this wonderful game, I give it 10/10 probably the best game I've ever played, recommended to the highest.

This review has been updated for the Nominee   First let me explain why I wrote this title 'Stairs? Noooooooooooooooo!' This is a funny dialog in the last chapter in Borderlands 2 where you team up with Claptrap to defeat Jack. After eliminating tons of robots and Claptrap manages to access the door, stairs are just right before Claptrap. He's not able to climb stairs as he has no feet but wheels. If you're careful enough, you will understand this right away which has been mentioned in the beginning of the game. Hence I personally prefer this as the most noticeable symbol for Borderlands and especially, for the Claptrap, who is designed to be your reliable and adorable company during the entire game-play.   As for the game itself. Borderlands 2 would stand for the the peak of the series, since the pre-sequel is widely considered as a DLC instead of a new game. Borderlands 2 brings more playable and discoverable elements compared to the origin Borderlands. More variable weapons, characters, games within the game and remarkable scripts. In Borderlands 2, you will find the deep insights of the background, where the Vault Hunters from, their own stories, how the Pandora it works. And most importantly, you're gonna save the people.    Yes the review is personal and quite personal, but It deserves the awards I personally nominated to and I share it with the community. It's my 'Borderlands' and there must your Borderlands somewhere. Thanks for your time on this.

Bout time I reviewed this game. This review is coming from over 2000 hours of game time (Steam and xbox combined) so i know the ins and outs of nearly every part of the game.  To start with, its a great solid game in which will provide plenty of entertainment for you and friends, solo or in a full team of 4. Yes the game is a blast solo, though alot is said about its co-op experience however that doesn't mean it isn't fun for single players, but obviously you can get more (or less in terms of loot) from playing with friends. This game is addicting, you just want more and better loot and to level up, kill the raid to get loot to kill the raid again, run arenas, play slots, chest farm, boss farm, toilet farm... well those aren't that lucrative. The fast paced gameplay and tense combat is great fun and when you get through without dying or going down you get a real sense of achievment, or relief if you did happen to do down or die. A first playthrough is always a blast and that alone is worth its cost, then if you REALLY enjoyed yourself you get to do it at a higher level, with more challenge, but more reward.   This game for me is about gameplay, not the story telling, yeah there is a stronger story than BL1 and more narrated side missions it still isn't up there with the likes of halo, GoW or other top, story focused games. So don't go in expecting to have a brilliant campaign story, go in expecting to have fun, and to have a good laugh.  There are plenty styles of play that Borderlands supports. Like being the center of attention, taking fire, tank it all and kicking out lots of dps at close range? Gunzerker. Like sitting back and sniping? Zer0, who isn't affraid to go ninja and stab enemies in the back. There is the siren, a support character for that team player. Then there's Axton, well, axton is a tricky one, tough to play at the top levels however early game, he shines with his huge tank, area of effect (the nuclear kind) and crowd control. then there are two bonus to provide lots more hours of fun after you get bored of the other four.  Yeah the game has its downs, its buggy, the scaling of certain skills, mechanics such as damage over time and certain types weapons just lose out to level. At top end level the game almost becomes unfair to the player forcing them to use only the best gear in the game, specific builds and so on, but then again, it is the top level. Its easy to break certain parts of missions forcing you to reload your game which can be very fustrating, also the AI has some weird quirks but overall isn't too game breaking.  Overall this is a game I would recommend even now just before the pre sequel as this is a game that will never grow old, will allways be fun to pick up and play, yes it has some flaws but to a flawless game is nearly impossible and well this is a game that triggered the looter shooter genre and so it must be good!

A young woman said 'hello' to me today. I stared back at her, my mind screeching as I looked for a way to escape this unwanted interaction. As my face grew red with nauseous stress, a blood vessel popped in my nose, and a jet of crimson shot out of my nostrils, splattering us both with blood. She screamed and ran away.

I'd say you'll spend 1,000+ hours before accomplishing everything in the game.   The comic-ish artstyle is excellent, it is unique in its' own way. The story is nothing amazing however.   The PC port is the best I've seen.

9! 24! 58! 100! 500! 1000! Critical! Is there a better visual barometer for satisfaction in videogames than damage numbers popping out of an enemy’s bullet-riddled head? The original Borderlands revelled in this instant gratification, complementing this core conceit with a ‘bazillion’ guns, tight shooting, addictive loot and a droll sense of humour. There’s little wonder why it was such a surprise hit back in 2009, and just as unsurprising that we’re back on the bombastic world of Pandora for Borderlands 2; a sequel that once again basks in the glow of numbers and bullets, hidden treasures and boner jokes.  Set five years after the events of the first game, Borderlands 2 features an entirely new cast of playable vault hunters. After the original group opened the fabled vault and dealt with what was hidden therein, an arrogant prick by the name of Handsome Jack took credit for their actions, declared himself the dictator of Pandora, and is now attempting to plunder the planet of its most valuable resources, hoping to awaken some sort of ancient alien power. You’ll team up with a resistance movement led by the original cast of vault hunters, intent on stopping him and looting the entire planet along the way.  Those same original vault hunters also now have dialogue, fleshing them out as actual characters after their previous stint as mostly silent protagonists. Borderlands 2 presumes you have some sort of reverence for the original cast despite their previous silence, but their inclusion and subsequent portrayals pay off in some interesting ways, both in regards to the narrative and the game’s humour. Most of the dialogue is fairly sharp across the board and its multitude of zany characters, new and old. The first game’s wacky sense of humour remains, with continuous pop culture references and a ludicrous amount of hidden Easter eggs, and this carries into some of the quest design and its inherent physical comedy.  The humour’s in-your-face nature can be a little much at times, especially when jokes miss or drag on for far too long, but the near constant stream of dialogue keeps Pandora feeling alive, especially in the once-lonely single player. It can be immature at times, relying on cheap gags to generate a chuckle, but there’s also a lot of humorous dialogue that will consistently muster more than a laugh or two, and the majority of its voice acting sells each character with aplomb, delivering some fantastic performances.  The most substantial improvements come in the gameplay and how you’re able to spec your character. In the first game you could pick the Soldier class, for instance, and by the end of the game you were essentially invincible if you spec’d in the right directions. Your deployable turret could not only lay waste to everything in sight but could also regenerate health and ammunition, leaving you free to stand still and eradicate an entire group of enemies with relative ease. Borderlands 2 has been reworked and is much more balanced, giving each character class a specific playstyle that comes with their action skill and making sure to never overpower them to tedium.   There are three skill paths to choose from, each one focusing on specific areas, whether it’s improving your action skill, allowing you to do higher damage with certain weapon types, increasing your maximum health and so on. The Assassin, for example, is very similar to the Hunter class from the first game, focusing on sniper rifles and improving their effectiveness. But each class plays much differently in Borderlands 2, so the Assassin’s action skill is comparable to the Siren’s previous phasewalk ability, allowing him to turn invisible for a brief amount of time where he can utilise his melee attacks; something the Berserker class focused on in the first game.   The gun manufacturers now produce particular kinds of weapons with their own distinct visual characteristics. One such manufacturer is Jakobs, who build Wild West style guns so you’ll find lots of revolvers and rifles that can fire as fast as you can pull the trigger but reload very slowly. Maliwan, on the other hand, builds weapons that deal out elemental damage, so they’re your go to guys if you want to set someone on fire.  Whichever concoction of assorted weaponry you choose, Borderlands 2’s gunplay is tight and intuitive. Whether it’s popping the heads off bandits, melting a robot down with corrosive ammunition or hitting a Skag with the butt of your rifle, the combat remains entertaining long past your first playthrough and into new game+. This is thanks in no small part to improvements made to enemy AI.   In Borderlands 2, enemies now move with more purpose and dexterity, keeping you on your toes and forcing you to adjust your aim as they dodge and roll, duck and weave. It’s not a massive enhancement in artificial intelligence, but it’s an improvement that gives the combat a more frenetic pace. Suicidal psychos will often charge you, explosives at the ready, while various projectiles are thrown in your direction. You’re constantly dashing from place to place and there’s a fantastic freedom of movement.   There’s a phenomenal agglomeration of enemies, each befitting of some sublime character design and enjoyable AI. You’ll face off against cloaked monsters, robots that can transform into makeshift tanks and a gargantuan bandit that bursts into a fit of rage, killing friend and foe alike. Each enemy requires a different tactic to beat, whether it’s utilising your action skill, equipping a weapon with a particular type of elemental damage or inciting enemy v enemy combat.  The game looks sublime on PC as well, particularly if you can run it on close to the highest settings. The cel-shaded art style never fails to shine and there’s some outstanding lighting effects that complement the level design. This is still the same Pandora as the first game but it’s been injected with a burst of colour and environmental variety. The desert wasteland still remains but now there are plains of green grass, snow swept icy caverns and a deep underground mine coated in luminous green acid. The colour pops with the art style like a comic book; Pandora’s exalted sense of place and character still remains.  Borderlands 2 successfully maintains every aspect that made the first game such a surprise hit and improves upon them in all the ways that matter. The majority of these improvements may only be incremental which gives the impression Gearbox took the safe route, avoiding major iteration, but the formula still works. Whether that formula still appeals to you is the real question. If you’ve already spent countless hours with the first game is more Borderlands something you want? If it is then Borderlands 2 is a better game than its predecessor in every way. Just only by a smidgen.

If you are here to read a review for Borderlands 2, you came to the wrong place.  However, here is a fantastic Deep Dark Chocolate Cake Recipe; Ingredients: 2 cups granulated sugar (500 mL) 1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour (425 mL) 3/4 cup HERSHEY'S Cocoa (175 mL) 1 1/2 tsp baking powder (7 mL) 1 1/2 tsp baking soda (7 mL) 1 tsp salt (5 mL) 2 eggs (2) 1 cup milk (250 mL) 1/2 cup vegetable oil (125 mL) 2 tsp vanilla extract (10 mL) 1 cup boiling water (250 mL) BUTTERCREAM FROSTING 6 tbsp butter or margarine, softened (90 mL) 2 2/3 cups icing sugar (650 mL) 1/2 cup HERSHEY'S Cocoa (125 mL) 1/3 cup milk (75 mL) 1 tsp vanilla extract (5 mL)  Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Grease and flour two 9-inch (1.5 L) round baking pans or one 9 x 13-inch (3.5 L) baking pan. 2. Stir sugar with flour, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda and salt in a large bowl. Add eggs, milk, oil and vanilla. Beat with an electric mixer, on medium speed, for 2 minutes. Stir in boiling water (batter will be thin). Divide batter evenly between prepared pans. 3. Bake for 30 to 35 minutes for the round pans (35 to 40 minutes for the large pan) or until a wooden pick inserted in the centre comes out clean. Cool for 10 minutes on a rack. Turn cakes out from pans; cool completely. (Sheet cake may be left in pan if desired.) Makes 8 to 10 servings. 4. Buttercream Frosting: Beat butter in medium bowl. Combine the icing sugar with the cocoa. Alternately add the icing sugar mixture and the milk to the butter, until a spreadable consistency is reached (additional milk may be required to reach preferred consistency). Stir in vanilla. Frost cooled cake. Makes about 2 cups (500 mL) of frosting.

-Quick Review-   Borderlands2 is a First Person action adventure shooter game developed by Gearbox and released 2012. Borderlands2's story takes place on the planet Pandora... Pandora is a very violent war-torn planet where no one in their right mind would visit, except for the insane... being bandits, local inhabitants who can't get off world, and vault hunters.    -Detailed breakdown review-   Story: You're a vault hunter, you've been lured onto Pandora in attempts to find the mystical place known as “the vault”, in the vault you gain unimaginable treasure... should you succeed in finding the vault; there's no telling what wonders you will encounter. But wait, before you run off and try to open the vault yourself, there are many enemies who wish to claim the vault as their own prize! Not to mention monstrous beasts that protect the vault. You don't even know where to go! To find the vault you will need friends, cue “Handsome Jack”...  ...okay, okay, by now most people actually know how this story goes, the Story telling in Borderlands2 is excellent, a nice blend of cinematic, voiced dialogue.   Game Play:  Borderlands2 is played in the first person view, initially there are only four playable characters/classes (with mods you gain 2 more), you have different types of weapons, elements, many different types of NPC's to fight, 3 skill tree's for each class.  The playable characters/classes are: Axton (Commando), Maya (Siren), Salvador (Gunzerker), Zero (Assassin), and with purchasing the appropriate DLC you gain access to Gaige (Mechromancer), and Krieg (Psycho). If you want to know more about a specific character/class I would recommend checking out online guides.  It's important to note that there are about 6 different classifications of weapons (Assault rifles, sniper rifles, pistols, shot guns, 'ya know – the normal gun you expect) it's even more important to note that each character/class can use any weapon... however some characters are better at certain weapons because of skill builds. (meaning, Zer0 (the sniper/assassin) is better with sniper rifles, but you can pick one up with Salvador (gunzerker) and use it, but you probably won't be as accurate as Zer0 is.  In addition to various weapons, are there many different special perks a gun can randomly roll, including different elements (Incendiary, Corrosive, Shock, and Explosive) which are more effective against different types of enemies. The point is, that the same gun can drop twice and have completely different stats.    Achievements:  Borderlands2 has 69 achievements in total, 50 achievements are available on the core game, the 19 other achievements are spread out across 4 DLC items you'll need to purchase to get 100%. All of the achievements are very obtainable, however, some require some grinding and luck (like, Challenge Accepted, Tribute to a vault hunter, and a number of other circumstantial achievements) Lastly, there is at least one achievement per class, the rest can be obtained with one character.    Price:  Borderlands2 is priced at $19.99 The game of the Year edition is priced at $39.99. I personally suggest purchasing the game of the year edition so you can get the DLC for the whole game. With the release of Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel the chances of picking up a copy of Borderlands2 on sale is dramatically increased, so it's worth noting that you could wait for a 75% off sale.   Conclusion:  Borderlands2 is hilarious, fun, has morbid-humor, insane people, guns, guns and more guns! I have little to nothing negative that I can say about the game. The graphics for the game itself are more cartoon-styled in nature, increasing the life of the game (It won't take back seat to high end graphic games as fast, because they're trying to replicate realism, they're implementing their own style and art). All in all, I loved playing Borderlands2, I played the heck out of the game, it's more fun to play it with a friend, but it's one of those games you can spend a lot of time playing just to blow up bandits. I recommend this game for FPS gamers, and people who enjoy Adventure/Action games.  ------Edits and updates------ Edit/Update June 09, 2015: Here's the URL to see my review for  Borderlands  Here's the URL to see my review for  Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep is DLC   Edit/Update June 09, 2015: Here's the URL to see my review for   Sir Hammerlock's Big Game Hunt  Here's the URL to see my review for   Mr. Torgue's Campaign of Carnage

Absolutely fantastic and thoroughly enjoyable!  ++ Wonderful character designs ++ Great dialogue supported by excellent voice acting ++ Unique skill trees even for what is essentially a shooter ++ Numerous weapon and accessory varieties ++ DLCs add a huge amount of content and replayability ++ Extremely enjoyable single and co-op play ++ Pop culture references galore (add nothing to a story but are always a nice touch)  -- Repetitive mob and boss types -- Difficulty scales up in sheer brute force rather than combat intelligence or tactics -- Redundant kill, find, fetch, and delivery quests -- Claptrap  Not a lot of cons for me in this game. I'm just kidding about Claptrap. He is as funny as he is annoying (most of the time).  I had the retail release of BL2 (and none of the mission packs and Vault Hunter upgrades at that time) way before I even became a Steam member. It's still as much fun now as it was back then. The DLCs add fresh content plus a good dose of hilarity, especially the Mechromancer and Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep!  In terms of play and narrative, this is a very simple game at its core, but it's incredibly fun because it does it what it does with great polish, and the presentation is top-notch.

Excellent weapons with huge variety, awesome boss fights, character levelling, side quests, you name it this game has it and more. A friend recommended it to me and now I'm recommending it to everyone, don't be deterred buy the age of the game, honestly it's timeless and replay ability is endless. One of the best games in the last decade.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding lemon bars recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1) 2 cups Flour 2) 1/2 cup Sugar 3) 1/4 teaspoon Salt 4) 2 sticks (1 Cup) Salted Butter, Cut Into Small Cubes 5) Filling 6) 1-1/2 cup Sugar 7) 1/4 cup Flour 8) 4 whole Large Eggs 9) Zest And Juice Of 4 Medium-sized Lemons 10) Powdered Sugar, For Sifting  Directions:  1. For the crust: Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. Grease a 9-by-13-inch pan with butter.  2. Stir together the flour, sugar, and salt. Add the butter to the bowl and use a pastry cutter to cut it all together until the mixture resembles fine crumbs. Press into the prepared pan and bake until golden around the edges, about 20 minutes.  3. For the filling: Stir together the sugar and flour. Crack in the eggs and whisk to combine. Add the lemon zest and juice and mix until combined. Pour over the crust and bake about 20 minutes.  4. Allow to cool in the fridge for a minimum of 2 hours, then sift powdered sugar over the top before cutting into squares.  (Use an 8 x 10 pan if you'd like the layers to be a little thicker.)

(Just humour me for a moment and pretend like you've somehow never heard of this game before) Hey, JacquesLeSauve, what's this Borderlands 2 game I keep hearing about?! Well, mister and/or miss random person gamer, since you ask!...   Borderlands 2 is a first-person, co-op, loot-hunting shooter with RPG elements, and, it might surprise you to know, the sequel to Borderlands 1! (and technically the Pre-squeal, but that's kind of a grey area) Play through a lengthy campaign as one of four characters, each with their own unique abilities and upgradable skill trees to compliment those abilities. Complete quests, fight badasses, earn money, level up and explore the strange and wonderful world of Pandora, all the while searching for that hot new gun that's gonna seriously f*ck sh*t up and ruin everyone else's day. Sweet.   The perfect antidote to an endless array of grey and brown shooters, this vibrant, cel-shaded style game refuses to take any part of itself seriously, save for the gameplay. Brimming with personality, it never misses a chance to hit the player with an off-colour joke or make fun of either itself or gaming in general, with a large portion of that magic being owed to the brilliant writing. The vast majority of characters fit into their roles perfectly and are expertly voiced as well, which is a huge breath of fresh air given how lacklustre the writing and acting can be in so many other games that have yet to learn how to feel natural or not completely chew up the scenery. OK, maybe the main villain is guilty of that heavy-handedness as he's so manifestly evil he goes beyond caricature or archetype and smacks of the creators trying way too hard to rile the player up and make them hate him. But even then he rarely outstays his welcome for too long.   Gunplay is pretty much rock solid as everything feels like it behaves exactly the way it's supposed to, whether it's firing something big and heavy and primitive that makes a big boom, or something more elegant and finely balanced for those scalpel-like precision kills. Even reloading a weapon can feel immensely satisfying, between the reload animation itself or the nice, big clunking sounds of a clip being jammed into place... a sentence I never thought I'd hear myself say. Now I feel weird, like a freaky gun fetishist. Eurgh. But yeah, for a game all about shooting, this nails it for sure... even though I'm the type of player that likes to bring a knife to a gun fight. But either way, whatever you're into, this game has you covered.   Speaking of having you covered, I really have to mention the online community. I'm not much one for online play typically, be it co-operatively or competitively, so not being massively familiar with it, I was a little apprehensive going into this, especially hearing horror stories about a few other communities, so I was expecting the worst. But I was really pleasantly surprised at just how nice and friendly and (mostly) competent the majority of other players seem to be. Sure, you'll occasionally get the odd palindromic loot tool come along and grab all the best gear for themselves, ignore other players in need, then talk cr*p about everyone else when no-one comes to their rescue. But in my experience most players here are incredibly nice and considerate and generous (I especially love the 'loot fairies', players that randomly dropped into my game, threw a load of gear at my feet, then disappeared, never to be seen again) and many will happily chat with you if that's what you're into. I've even added some good people to my friends list off the back of this game. So if anybody's worried about that aspect of the game, they really needn't.   If I had to make one major complaint about this it would be the opening. The bleak tundra setting of the first few hours really isn't very inviting or stimulating to the player and feels more like it should have been a mid to late game location rather than your introduction to the world, even for seasoned veterans of the first game. And, unfortunately, this is probably pretty unavoidable, given the nature of games where you have to level up, but you won't get any interesting gear for a while, either, and everything might initially feel really mundane for some players. But if you can push through it, then once you acquire newer, more interesting abilities and perks and expand your arsenal to include more exotic and outrageous gear, than that's when the game really starts to shine.   So, with tons of replay value, between the multiple characters, two new game + modes and tons of additional DLC to purchase, whether you play this alone or with others, this is a game that should keep you busy and happy for a long, long time. So good is it, in fact, that after over 300 hours of play I'm still not tired of it and can't wait to see what they'll do for the third outing. Come get you one!

So, a few years after the FIRST Borderlands came out, I developed a deep hatred for it. I though it looked stupid. I still haven't played the first one to this day (I missed the sale), but I grabbed this mainly because a friend said we could play together (we have not since).  But hey, part of what makes me LOVE this game so much is because SO many people still actively play it. I swear, every time I've started playing, and sometime during the session, one of my friends asks if they can join my game and/or I can join theirs. Some people don't intend on making me feel like a noob—though they do and I'm okay with it/don't say anything—but it's so fun! The game has the most unique online systems I've ever seen IN a video game, and everyone just has a ton of fun~  The game itself is very similar to Bioshock (thanks 2K) in the means of shooting, crazy-♥♥♥ weapons (MUCH more so here) and looting. A LOT of looting. You could spend hours in the game literally making little progress, but looting EVERY container you can find, and there are plenty of secrets to find, too! I'm sure those secrets go with a few achievments, but again, if you don't want to spend hours...they're just achievemnts, dude; I know it's hard to resist, but it really can get tiring looting everything.  The game's got a LOT of humor, and a LOT of unique storyteling/characters that help with that. It's an experience EVERYONE deserves to enjoy. And I feel bad I looked at this franchise the wrong way at first.

You get a quest from a redneck (who is in love with his severely obese sister) to collect porn mags so he use the influence to write a poem to a girl who upon reading the poem commits suicide  You get a quest that if left unfinished at a certain stage could have you going through the rest of the game with one of the most common enemy types labled as 'Bonerfarts'  You get a quest from a chronically depressed robot that involves attending his birthday party located near a dumpster in the corner of a decrepid village and waiting literally 4 minutes in one spot occasionally eating pizza whilst he dances around to static coming from a broken radio and nobody else shows up  This is the best open world game ever made and that is an objective fact, anyone who dissagrees is factually incorrect.

BORDERLANDS 2 DOESN'T DISAPPOINT The base game is packed with plenty of content, but for the die-hard fans, the GOTY Edition is definitely worth it. I, however, have never played the original Borderlands, and was impressed that the developers could create a game with the perfect balance of cartoon comedy and overall game intensity. This game is undoubtedly the pinnacle of action comedy games to date. The game is extremely easy to run (even on a single core processor in my case), and although it maintains a cartoon appearance, it is still quite beautiful at times. However, it wouldn't be fair to leave out the limited number of downfalls that hold this game back from perfection. It's limited customization is disappointing, although this can be made slightly better with DLC. I also experience a crash about every 5 hours of gameplay, which can be annoying when progress is lost and areas must be cleared again. I have also experienced getting stuck a couple times, and once again, I was forced to sacrifice my progress. Apart from these minor issues, I can't complain because of this powerful end result that is fast becoming one of my favorite games. Windows 10 Intel Core i7 FINAL REVIEW RATING: 9.4/10

Beautiful graphics and animation, excellent cinematography, voice acting, dark sense of humor and overall theme. Lots of quests that are made even more seamless than the first. This game has a very well constructed storyline and that will keep you playing it for hours.  It's also interesting to notice how good the voice acting/dialogues are. Every character has a pretty stereotyped personality, and thanks to the awesome voice acting, you will be amazed with the way it's dialogues will always surprise you in some or other way.  The mechanics are very interesting, this game combines FPS with RPG in a way that I haven't seen so far. The game is very difficult though, mainly when you are on 'ultimate vault hunter mode', but it compensates it with rare loot.  The variety of guns and skills is also noticeable.  But don't forget that this game is on it's deadline, there won't be any more DLCs for it has it's already been annouced by the devs, and also the online rooms feels very lonely once you reach a higher level, but you will usually have options when you are low/mid level.

Borderlands 2 is a hectic and thoroughly enjoyable First person RPG shooter. While replaying the main storyline campaign can get repetitive after a few times, the amount and variety of DLC content keeps the game feeling fresh. The game comes stock with 4 distinct classes and has two additional ones available through paid DLC. Each class plays differently and with the talent tree choices even playing the same class over can feel slightly different. The length of the main story campaign feels decently long but can be rushed through relatively quickly. That's why I highly suggest playing through all of the available side quests and EXPLORE. That is one of the bigger selling points of this game for me. While the story itself can feel linear and pushing you from zone to zone. The amount of extra quests and areas to discover is great. I highly recommend this game to fans of the borderlands franchise and newcomers alike.

I will start by saying; I have been playing Borderlands2 for maybe about a week now. I currently have a level 18 Commando. Very fun game! Imagine what would happen if Unreal Tournament had a night of passion with Firefly and Invader Zim. Co-op FPS+RPG featuring hilarious jokes, rocket launchers, sniper rifles, hilarious jokes, robots, lasers, hilarious jokes, spaceships, mutants, hilarious jokes, dragons, pirates, hilarious jokes... You get the picture.   The base game alone offers a lot. It took 40 hours to get through the story campaign, after which I was only level 33. The original side missions go up to level 50. Each of the DLC campaigns adds a full new story, new maps, new side missions, new items, and new skins. One DLC increases the level cap to 61 and another to 72, allowing you to unlock more skills for your characters. The 'Badass Rank' system is unlimited, so in theory you can get infinite stat boosts to make your characters infinitely powerful.   The two DLC characters are very fun to play. They feel very different from the original four characters by bringing unique playstyles. Gaige has a giant pet robot of doom, and a stackable Anarchy mechanic which encourages you to sacrifice accuracy and clip size in favor of chaos and explosions. She also has the most adorable catchphrases. Krieg is a psycho (one of the enemies you commonly face) and is actually more effective without shields and when he's lit on fire. He regains his health by decapitating foes with a buzzsaw axe and bathing in their blood. His catchphrases are very disturbing, and you will either hate him or love him. There is no middle ground with Krieg.  I played the first 40 hours solo, and after experiencing the story I started playing through the DLC campaigns co-op with my friends. I'm a completionist and there are a ton of achievements, so I'll be playing the side missions and exploring the world to unlock everything. Co-op is definitely a fun experience, but the game offers a lot for solo players as well. I've played so much and still have not experienced most of the content. This game is definitely worth the money.

I have unregretfully poured just a little over 400hrs into this game. It's been nothing short of amazing and definitely ranks amongst the Top 5 this generation. The gameplay, story, drop system and dialogue are MASSIVE (and I'm not exaggerating) improvements over the first game. The main quest doesn't feel as tedious, bland and empty as BL1, in which some will give you the chance to earn slight bonuses, consisting of stronger weapons, shields or even character skins.   One of the major overhauls I love the most is the Badass Rank. Completing levels of challenges will increase your BA Rank and give you a token whi you can apply to stat increase for better accuracy, longer duration of DoT effects (shock, fire, corrosive) or overall damage. And your BA Rank is applied to all characters that you create (my BA Rank is around 31,000 or so) so you can start off a new character and be extremely overpowered but in the long run it will pay off as True Vault Hunter Mode will greatly amp up the difficulty. More so with Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode (not recommended until Lv61 because of level scaling). You can also earn skins from these challenges as well.   Of the core classes available you have Axton the commando, whose Sabre Turret shreds up everything when deployed. Going down specific trees allows the turret to fire rockets, set of a radial nuke or even grant the ability to deploy 2 at once. Maya is a Siren, much like Lilith but instead of Phase Shifting for an advantage, she can use Phase Lock. Phase Lock surrounds the target in a orb when invested into skills like Elated, Sweet Release, Helios and Chain Reaction, you'll set the enemy on fire, drain health (and restore it to your friends) and transfer that orb to the next target. Gaige the Mechomancer (who was available as a preorder bonus before the game launched) has Deathtrap. Deathtrap is basically your scout who'll rip apart anything in sight and his abilities are further amplified when going down the Best Friends Forever tree. I've invested a few points into BFF myself but I'm more partial to Little Big Trouble. LBT primarily focuses on Shock damage, in which some weapons (and shields) can make Gaige literally invincible.   There's much more I can say here but I'll wrap this up with: If you see it on sale, better yet the GOTY Edition which includes all of the DLC (not the paid skins) you are definitely getting a huge bang for your buck. 10/10.

Saying I love this game is an understatement. I could play this game and never tire of it, and it's that kind of endless re-playability that makes Borderlands 2 one of the best buying decisions you'll ever make. A word of warning though: make sure you have at least one friend to play it with. Multiplayer is what truly makes this game worth playing every single day. Sure, playing the campaigns solo is fun and satisfying on its own, but with a friend (or friends) the game takes on a whole new dimension of enjoyment.   I love every bit of dialogue in this game, the writing is spot-on hilarious, and even emotionally touching at times. And the weapons....oh, the weapons~ Searching for rare, legendary or otherwise badass weaponry is a reason to play in and of itself. It seems the possibilites in this world are truly endless. It's an action FPS on the outside, sure, but I love just how much of an adventure RPG-element there is at the heart of the game in terms of style and character skill development. You care about the characters plights, as well as the story itself. Borderlands 2 really has its own personality, and you can immerse yourself completely in this crazy world.   Another thing to mention is the DLC. There are plenty of extra missions to choose from, and it only adds to the replay value. In fact, you're much better off just buying the Game of the Year edition since it includes a lot of them. Since I mentioned RPG's earlier, I will specifically suggest Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep as my favorite of all the DLC missions. If you enjoy Magic the Gathering, Final Fantasy, Dungeons and Dragons or anything like it---you will experience a nerdgasm with this one.
One of my favourite games of all time. If the GOTY version is on sale grab it . The DLC add atleast 15 hrs of extra gameplay and it's so worth it !

This game is brilliant. There's no other way of putting it. This game is fun in single player, and super-fun in co-op. Gameplay: - There is nothing more satisfying in perhaps any other game than seeing a stream of CRITICAL damage indicators streaming off a psycopath/midget/fat person/robot's head. - The variety in guns, grenade mods and shields is unprecedented. In co-op, you'll constantly be comparing your gear to that of your friends, trying out their weapons, trading weapons. All of the gun types are fun to use - especially revolvers. I swear they're magical or something... - The game is a well-made hybrid of FPS and RPG. You can give your character (one of 4 classes in the base game, with 2 more in the GOTY edition) abilities and level them up, enabling you to use better weapons, grenade mods and shield.   Story: - Ridiculous humour that works - that about sums it up. You'll encounter crazy situations and missions, but you'll just accept it. - There's an awful lot of it. The main story missions don't often feel recycled, presenting you with different challenges every time. There's plenty of voice acting in both the main campaign and side quests, whcih is impressive considering the volume of these. - There are a fair few unexpected plot twists, but it usually doesn't feel dragged out. - Handsome Jack is both formidable and funny. He's a truly worthy nemesis. - Claptrap makes you want to kill him within 20 seconds of meeting him. I've yet to hear a voice on par with how annoying Claptrap's is.  Graphics and Sound: - If you crank the settings up, this game looks pretty nice. The cartoony style means it also runs well on lower-end PCs without looking muddy. - If you have an NVIDIA card, you're in for a treat. There are cloth and liquid PhysX, and you can cut the cloth with bullets. Debris flies off the environment and bounces off things. It makes hectic situations look awesome. - Gun sounds and voice acting are great, everything else is generally OK, not too special. - I've had a couple of unexpected slowdowns and 2-second freezes. This shouldn't happen on my PC really, but I suspect it's PhysX related. I keep PhysX on Medium or High, though, because it's great.  Multiplayer: - The game has 2-4 player co-op multiplayer. All missions work in both single-player and co-op, with enemy volume and health scaling to keep difficulty constant. - You can start duels for loot with your fellow players, in the event of disagreement. - Pretty seamless. Invite players to your game from the main menu, and they drop into your world with all your mission progression. - I'd advise that everyone has a different class, otherwise you'll all die at the same time and respawn back at a checkpoint, which gets annoying. - For best experience, everyone in your co-op session should be within about a 10-level range of each other, or the underlevelled character will need reviving constantly.  Summary: This game should be compulsory. My life is complete, now that I can shoot midgets with shotguns and find cool loot in portaloos. My advice: buy GOTY - you'll want all the Borderlands you can get.

There’s nothing quite as subjective as comedy and the characters of Borderlands 2 will either irritate or please, sometimes even both in equal measure. From the weird rap nonsense of Tiny Tina to the cackling, evil tones of Handsome Jack, Borderlands 2 is built on a bizarre world that relies on how much you enjoy its colourful cast of characters. And for us, we definitely loved our time with these crazy people. While a continuation of the story seen in Borderlands, it’s not imperative that you have played it in order to understand the story. The sequel being most welcoming for newcomers giving the player four new characters to control, the commando Axton, the siren Maya, the gunzerker Salvador and the assassin Zer0. All four of these being Vault Hunters, new to the planet of Pandora who have found themselves in a trap set by the games villain Handsome Jack. Once escaping said trap they team up with Claptrap in order to help bring down Jack and stop him from using the vault for his own nefarious means. There are also the returning characters, including the original Vault Hunters from the first game, and the more secondary characters like Dr Zed and cosplay favourite Moxxxi. Each coming with their own selection of missions and comedic moments. A smile was definitely raised when invitations to Claptrap’s party had to be handed out, none of who chose to attend, cue awkward dancing and hanging around for a couple of minutes while bad music plays. The framework of Borderlands 2 is close to the original, with loot being grabbed, missions being collected and a whole host of creatures and soldiers standing between you and Handsome Jack. It’s neither an update nor a revolution of the mechanics, more an evolution. The FPS gameplay still remains largely unchanged. Shooting feels great with the amount of guns at your disposal staggering. From sniper rifles to shotguns, each weapon has a specific manufacture that comes with their own strengths. With some giving specific damage types, such as corrosive and fire, with some guns even exploding when they’ve ran dry. This also carrying into the grenade types and shields. The way you approach each combat situation largely depending on what weapons you have equipped, making each battle somewhat tactical, especially when certain enemy types are weaker to certain elements. Coming up against a robot? Then give corrosive weaponry a try. It’s one of the most satisfying shooters in some time. Then there’s the added ability each character comes equipped with. The commando Axton for instance is able to drop a turret once the skill is fully charged. This then can be levelled up once you gain experience points, as well as the usual shields, health and weapon damage. With plenty of side missions available there’s plenty of opportunity to raise your characters level, with each mission handily letting you know whether this is a too tough for you at your current ability or merely a walk in the park. Of course, much like the original the game really comes alive in multiplayer. Joining your friends for missions is a delight and works really well. But that’s not to say it lives and dies on its online multiplayer. Even in single player the game is a blast with an absolute ton of content, the world of Pandora being a massive place with variety far outweighing that of its predecessor. From large desert lands that can be traversed by vehicle, ice covered mountains, all the way to luscious green fields and towering structures, there’s plenty to see and do. Made even more impressive with the vibrant Borderlands art style. A cartoony world, with a visceral edge, as limbs fly and heads explode. The only issue with the graphics being the texture pop-in. An issue that plagues far too many games, as it takes a number of seconds before all the textures finally appear. What the original Borderlands did so well has been grabbed and near perfected with this sequel. The comedy may be hit and miss, but it thrives on its shooting and loot grabbing. Many hours of fun will await you in Pandora. 10/10

One of the best games I have ever played.  The artstyle of the game is wonderful, As I like to walk around for hours just looking at how beautiful the game is.  There are six characters. (Two of them are DLC) All with their own playstyles and personalities. The six Include: Axton The Commando (He's like Roland in the first game with his turrets and stuff), Maya The Siren, Salvador The Gunzerker, Zer0 The Assassin, Gaige The Mechromancer (DLC), and Krieg the Psycho (DLC).  With 3 skilltrees with each character, your playstyles for the characters can be limitless (Probably not).  There is a looting system where you have to fight a boss for a unique weapon/item or legendary weapon/item. They will have a 1/30 chance of dropping the items. (They did make drops more frequent so I don't really know what the chance of an item dropping is now)   The weapons and items all do different things, with different stats, so you would like to get the best one to become a true Badass.  The leveling system: In The third playthrough (Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode) will have all items and enemies scale to your level, There are two DLCs that increase the level cap: Those 2 Vault Hunter upgrade packs (I don't remember what they're called, so sorry), The first one will increas your level cap from 50 to 61, and the second one (You need the first one for this) Increases it to 61 to 72.   There is also something called Overpowered Levels: After you reach level 72, you can go into a place called 'Digistruct Peak' in which you can increase your level even further, as the enemies are tougher, and you can level up to Overpowered Level 8 (Level 80).  I really do reccomend this game.

Addiction to the max...  Let me get the easy and mandatory stuff of the way:  The Graphics:  Okay so this is the same engine as 3 years ago. However, there are improvements, at least on the PC version. The physx is now able to display some cool visual effects. The improvements include    +hundreds of sparkles from explosion guns; + fire looks like fire now; +the corrosion goo now oozes out on the ground and cascades down the slopes; + the battlegrounds are now littered with pieces of rocks and gravel (that do not disappear by the way); the electric guns now display more sparkling effects; +there is now some sun glare +there is now aurora borealis +there are some nice snow and desert effects +the anti-aliasing has been greatly improved +the day to night shift has also been improved  The Cons: -the water looks pretty much the same though -we still get Directx9 -Visually, everything about the game has been improved except that you still cast no shadow and you still can't see your legs -The Resolution problem. okay so I thought I was playing with my native 1920x1080 resolution until I figured out (at level 10) that you needed to change the resolution one more time IN-GAME. Apparently, changing resolution in the game menu does squat. So I've been playing the crappy console 1080x720 whitewash resolution for about two hours before I figured out what was wrong. DON'T MAKE THE SAME MISTAKE. -SLOW texture loading, just like in the first game. Whenever you enter a new are or go into a shop it will take a couple of seconds for textures to load. Thanks consoles!  Okay as for the gameplay:  It remains largely unchanged however there are improvements. The sprint effects are now more realistic. One of the things I liked is that it is MUCH MUCH harder to earn money now. I reached level 18 and rarely had more than $ 1500 bucks in my pocket. This is a breath of fresh air considering that you could easily rack up $ 200,000 by the time you hit level 15. ( I am not even mentioning the exploit of cloning artifacts and rejoining friend's game to essentially have infinite money). Also, I should mention that they now got rid of all those unnecessary zeroes, as in, there really is no reason to sell a gun for $ 254,620 when they could downplay the entire currency by a factor of 1000. Ergo, you would have to buy the gun for $ 254 instead.  The skill tree is somewhat the same from the first games with some similar perks.  They now added Eridium as currency, which is rare. Except you can only use it to upgrade your ammo/grenade/backpack capacity.  They haven't changed the driving. It is still a keyboard+mouse driving which still sucks.  They also now added caravans which can get attacked and then get looted for rare weapons.  The elemental effects largely remain the same. Fire is good against flesh and corrosion is now really effective against armor (robots don't have shield or health anymore, only armor). Also, robots are easily taken out when their limbs are blown off.  It seems like the auto-assist weaker than in the first game but it can still be felt.  The enemies are even more hilarious now. The voice acting is great (same goes for THE friendly NPCs), especially when you hear the midget armored goliaths talk. It's obvious they try to overcompensate for their vertical challenge by being extra badass. The enemies still do the barrel rolls, they still take cover and can spend up to 5 seconds and they can also jump from platform to platform. There are also the buzzers (make-shift propelled helicopters much like in the mad max movies) which are pretty fun to shoot down. It's even more fun when they sing the Ride of the Valkyries composition (from Apocalypse now), it's pretty amusing. Some midgets ride on each others' heads too.  I'm not too sure about the insects though. They are gross and disgusting to fight.  In general, it is still way more fun to fight humans or rather, the humanoids, rather than the robots and the beasties.  The weapons: I'm not sure if it's me but it looks like they put more effort into adding more flare to almost every other gun. The seemingly random-generated stats are still there but at least gun skins look more flamboyant and peculiar. They also varied the standard appearance types somewhat. So, not every rifle gun is necessarily elongated for instance.  The story: It's a continuation of the first story (perhaps a couple of years after opening of the vault) wherein The Handsome Jack, who is in charge of the Hyperion Corporation is attempting to open an even bigger vault and obtain control of the prehistoric monster to rule Pandora. The story has some twists, surprisingly and it's always welcome to see the good old friendly NPC's again.  In the end, perhaps this could quality as Borderlands 2 since it's a continuation of story and all, I just didn't really feel like it was a new installment all that much, a lot of things feel same, although it's a definite improvement over the old one. There is more narrative, more quests, new enemies, new artifacts, mods, etc. etc. But there is not necessarily more depth, perhaps it is so because of the type of game itself. However, there are plenty of comical and satirical moments that catch you off-guard. The game is also littered with easter eggs.

First time I've heard of Borderlands 2 I was like 'Meh, another blurry movie, Borderlands 1 FTW'. But then I've got a 'pirated' edition of the game. It was SO AWESOME and without any doubts I did remove it and got BL2 + Season Pass + Preorder DLC + Mechromancer pack. What's so awesome about it? Let me explain. First: 'traditional Borderlands' humor. Violence, black humor etc. It's not annoying or way too brutal. Just fit the game setting. Second: awesome characters, story line, dialogues. Even though Handsome Jack is a villain of the game - he's awesome as well. I were waiting for all the ECHO transmissions, never skept any cutscenes and did all the side quests. A lot of entertainment here. Third: of course, it's graphics. You can say 'booo, battlefield 4 has better graph' - you're kinda right, yeah. But nobody cares about 'realistic' graphics here. It's like you're playing comics. Fourth: nice characters. I can't say they have an awesome storyline (but i did like Maya's story at least) but gameplay aspect is just headsmashing. A lot of variants how to play each character, way better than Borderlands 1. Fifth: DLCs. Yeah, eve though you can say 'RIPOFF!!! TOO MUCH DLCS!!! THEY'RE NOT WORTH ANY CENT!!!'. Actually they ARE worthy. Not kidding. 4 DLC's included in a Season Pass providing SO MUCH CONTENT. And all the content is not like 'Meh, they'll buy it anyway'. No. They're detailed. They're providing experience that can be compared to the base game(and imo Tiny Tina's DLC is even GREATER than the base game). Sixth and the last: co-op play. 'Adventure time. c'mon grab your friends, this time we'll play the Borderlands'. Nothing to say. It's SO GREAT for co-oping. It's awesome when you can count on friends standing behind you, ready to help, revive or even heal you. In total I'll say this game is definetily worth EVERY cent you pay for it. If you like GOOD action games - you should get it. My overall score is TEN out of TEN.

I would not recommend the headhunter DLC's though, they are too short and don't add very much to the game. I would recommend this to anyone.

LOVE IT. OMG. TOTAL BADASSERY. I love running around and raising hell, and in this game, you do just that. So many different weapons types and grenade types, class mods and shields, skills and relics. I must say though, the experience gets twice as good playing with friends. The multiplayer has a great balancing system. The characters are insanely cool. Love everything about this game. 10/10

Borderlands 2 is a very fun game to play, by yourself and with three other friends due to the co-op. It has a nice feel to the game with the cel shaders and the fact that nearly every weapon you pick up is pretty much unique. The campaign is enjoyable and always keeps you interested, with the changes of scenery and the variety of new enemies. The four player co-op works very well, up to three other people are able to join your place in the campaign and help you with areas you are stuck on.   The only downsides to the game are the fact that once you win the game the first time, to get to the level cap you have to play the game again with gets rather repetitive (especially if you have the DLC which makes the level cap up to 70). Another downside is the fact that the legendary weapons are very rare and you have to spend hours farming the bosses to find one.  Overall, this is a great game to play with your friends for the price (especially when it's on sale). You can have some very fun and enjoyable moments with them through the campaign and I highly recommend this game.

I love this game! First things first: BL2 makes a whole lot more fun 1) with friends and 2) if you played the first one.  This is one of the few games, I can actually call a sequal. It takes all the good stuff from its predecessor, makes it more awesome and then adds tons of more awesome stuff. Amazing.  This game has a certain kind of humour and I suppose you have to like it, but when you like it, it can be amazingly funny lots of times. The story, most characters and even quests usually have this funny touch from time to time. The thing is, it does not try to be cool and copy some jokes - it actually is boss good.  But still: This is a FPS. And also kind of an RPG. Hence the term RPS. And it actually does combine both elements really great. You always feel like you're doing progress by blowing stuff up. The weapons are great and there are about 1.21 Gazillion of them (I made a reference there, did you notice?).  Apropos: Gearbox likes references. So they put so many flippin awesome references in the game, me and my friends had seemingly infinite amounts of fun with this game.  If you are going to get this, get at least 2 friends to play with you and also get all the 4 story DLCs, they have extended awesomeness in them!  Things I love: Combat system, level design, story, characters, leveling system, guns, dialogs, enemies, bosses, soundtrack, variety, humour, graphics, coop.  Welcome to Pandora!

A game for the masses. The casuals, the hardcore and the lurkers.  Are you walking around endlessly, wondering what to do? Did you decide to check out this game, but yet aren't sure? Do you want a game experience, that'll include hours upon hours, of hilarity and a good co-op and solo experience?  Borderlands 2 is just for you.    The game introduces you, and within the first minute you greet Claptrap. A robot you'll grow either fond of, or find to be like 'Pinky' in Pinky and the Brain. The voice acting in this game is beyond imagination, and the hilarity and focus upon entertainment and comedy is higher than I've ever experienced before.   Characters such as Tiny Tina, Marcus, Lillith and many more, greets you with a little cutscene, explaining their personality spot on. You'll get a specific, individual feeling about all of them, and you'll get to experience why.   The game introduces you to a story quest-line, but as you venture into the game, you'll quickly come to realize the numerous amount of side-missions available. The majority of those aren't of no reason, and feel dull and boring. No, in fact, many of them still focus on the great dialogue, and the exceptional story this game is so very known for.   The gameplay runs smooth, is very polished and introduces you to great characters, an RPG-type feeling, great opportunity to play with friends or just people you spoke with in the past. Even as far as new people! There's great community groups, and easy ways of meeting other Borderlands 2 players. If you find yourself getting lonely in Pandora, you can find new friends any moment you wish!   When you fight your way through the normal difficulty, you are quickly introduced to the second, more difficult experience that is 'True Vault Hunter Mode' (and later the third difficulty; Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode), which will drastically increase in difficulty. You'll find some bosses seemingly impossible in a surprising manner, and normal Psychos, Varkids, Bullymongs and many more to swarm up on you, quickly making you a dead-man walking. An easy target. But that's not it. When you think it gets close to unbearably difficult, you are introduced to the REAL game. The challenge that will or won't prove you worthy. But not to worry, you have lots of side-missions to prepare you for the challenges ahead, and tons of knowledge to learn about your class individually. The endgame is filled with world-bosses, designed to be slain with friends, but could potentially be slain alone. Seraph vendors selling some of the greatest loot, Tcoins giving you opportunity to buy legendary weapons in bucket-fulls, if you decide to invest your time in the game. Rare loot, that you can farm for many hours, but still feel totally hyped about, jumping around once you finally see that pistol dropping.   The game also introduces you to several classes; Axton, Salvador, Maya and Zer0. (Plus Krieg and Gaige from DLC) All with seperate skill-trees, ultimate-ability and playstyle. Out of these classes, you are sure to find one that suits your individual taste in gameplay, and you'll soon find yourself growing incredibly fond of your character.   If you played the first Borderlands, you will find it funny that the old classes; Lillith, Brick, Mordecai and Roland are mission-givers, and support you as you venture into Pandora. Not only the old classes make a comeback, you'll also greet characters such as Scooter and Angel. With genius dialogue, touching moments, awesome explosions, epic guns, polished gameplay, incredible voice acting and some of the best comedy in any game I've ever tried, I decide to rate this game with a well deserved 9/10, and certainly my zeal of approval. Any fan of a game that supports individual playstyle, decisions and expectations will surely enjoy this game!   There aren't many flaws in this game, but I have to mention the few there is. You can find yourself jumping around, trying to skip over a mountain to get to your objective in a quicker manner, but unfortunately see yourself getting stuck in a hole, having to save and quit, and start the past perhaps 10-15minutes over. (You will not lose your experience-progress, and I see this as a rather small flaw.)  The chances of a boss dying just as it jumps away, leading to it flying in the air is very slim, well, barely a possibility... But unfortunately it can happen that your loot will then fly off in the distance, impossible to find again. Either that, or it literally flew out of the map. Again, a very small flaw, that you possible won't ever see happening to you, but sure if a possibility.  When you progress in this game, there is a usualy flawless save-system, but it can be problematic. If your game bugs out just before another 'checkpoint', you could end up having to spend those 10-15minutes again. I haven't found myself getting a roll-back, losing the XP I gained in the meantime, but I've heard of such.  The dialogue can be interrupted by talking to another characters at times, and you have no way of listening to it again, untill you get to next difficulty, or replay.  No seperate loot table (both a good and a bad thing, but when playing online, you can easily find people looting EVERYTHING there is, so you're left boned!) - There is a way to dupe items though, so if you co-op, you can essentially both get the item, if that's how you prefer it.   Unfortunately, this is a written review, so I will finish off here. And if you've read this far, I'm sure you're already filled in enough, so you feel ready to enjoy the unlimited amounts of fun and one of the most superior game experiences out there! If you haven't yet gotten this game, I cannot do anything, but tell you: GET THE GAME. NOW. It's amazing and unbelieveable- An experience you NEED to have!  Rating: 9/10, and my zeal of approval!  Pros: - The dialogue in this game is beyond awesome. - Gameplay is smooth, both for the casual and the hardcore. - For both the social and the loner. - Has one of the best villains ever! - Ingenious eastereggs. - Oceans of both story and optional missions. - 100+ hours of incredible content. - Lots of DLC to enjoy. - A lot of endgame material.  Cons: - Little to few bugs, glitches and exploits. - Save-system can be problematic. - No character-customization. - Loot-system seems clunky to some.   I hope you enjoyed reading my review, and I hope I've inspired you to try out this amazing game!  Thanks, Mr. Reegen
Great game. Even better when playing with friends.

Borderlands 2 takes everything that was good about the first game and makes it better, it takes the stuff that could be fixed and improves it, and then it adds it's own flavour of awesome. It is deffinitely a game that you should play. It's absolutely hilarious, and I can't help but love almost every single character in the game (and there are a lot of them). It is highly recommended though that you play this game with a couple of friends, as it really is designed around the co-op experience.

Borderlands 2 is a FPS full of RPG elements. Loot is very important in this game. The action is fast-paced, extraordinary, a little out-of-the-line but incredibly fun. The story is decent and funny, ranging from all sort of whacky quests (i.e. getting a mohawk for your robot master) to very intense action (i.e. a bandit arena). The art-style and cell-shaded graphics make this game look very much like a graphical novel in its appereance.  If you believe this game is not to be taken serious, you are wrong, as you'll find yourself immersed in this crazy, stat-ruled, bullets-everywhere (even vending machines) world very quickly.
This game is awesome and badass ;)

This game is bloody amazing! I've sunk almost 300 hours into it and I still enjoy it massively! The DLC for this game is astronomical as well, but it does make up the better part of the content. If you are looking for a sci-fi - dark humour - loot fest - RPG hybrid, this game is perfect for you!  Pros: - 87 Bajillion guns - Controls feel tight and precise - Skill trees are well panned out - 4 classes that all play differently to each other, with an extra 2 if you buy the repsective dlc packs. - Brilliant story line, it's both emotional at points and funny at others - Mr. Torgue (he is worthy of having his own pro - Trust me) - Great with friends! - Well built wiki, this game has been out for a while, so its wiki is good. You won't be needing it too much though. - Quite a large amount of background lore, for all those book worms out there.  Cons: - Can feel a little repetitive at times, but it's not usually too bad and these sections are generally over quite quickly. - While there is a lot of guns, not all these guns have different models, so you sometimes feel like you're picking up the same weapons - Can feel a bit drained without a friend, this is generally only a problem for people that have either played lots with friends or not at all with such. Other than that, the average player won't feel that problem  This game is definitely worth your time and money, it's a perfect sequel to the original game! If you've got a friend, get this for them and get it yourself too, they'll be thanking you soon after. The good definitely outweighs the bad and it's a very polished formula.  9/10

Borderlands remains to this day my favorite game due to its uniqueness of combining rpg and fps elements with a great story and voice acting that were fun and entertained me for basically months of gameplay time, some of which isn't on Steam before I decided to buy the GOTY just so I could get all the achievements for this game. So don't get me wrong for the review below, but:  I never hated jumping mechanics and invisible walls more than in this game, ever! Or map designs that make you cover a distance by going on an arch or a zig-zag to reach your objective just to add more gameplay time, and this happens especially in the dlcs. The first two aspects persist from the first game, but the third.. oh man. Also on that note I hated the most all the quests in Tundra Express given by Tiny Tina, because the entrance to her cave is located in exactly the opposite direction of all the objectives except one. I can't even remember how many times I've cursed the developers for making me run around a god damn rock to turn in something, just to get another in almost the same spot.   Also the story is kinda forced and lacks character which made me quit the game two or three times before level 25 because I didn't connect with what was going on in it, and this is the first game I've pre-ordered! I still prefer the first Borderlands for that where you actually care about your hero and what's going on, you wanna get involved in changing the situation.  Other than that it's still a great game built in the same manner with a lot of content that can keep you playing many hours alone or with friends and they did improve on the later part, connectivity becoming easily accesible which is great because that's why we're all using this Steam platform after all. So I can see why it lacks in some content, just to make up in other related to the multiplayer category, like the badass ranks and bonuses and all the playthroughs (hell in the first game max health and shields were in the two to four thousand limit), so the players have something to return to that doesn't feel absolete after just a few hours.   I hope to see a Borderlands MMO one day, which seems they're getting closer and closer to and might be the perfect game yet as the developers usually listen to what the community asks for and they constantly improve the new releases on that matter.

Greetings Badass or potential Badass.  Borderlands 2 is one of my favorite shooter. It is an awesome mix of a shooter and a complex story full of mad humor. As a warning: This game is really full of splatter scenes and mad side-kicks so if you look for a simple not that wicked story-based shooter, Borderlands should not be your choice. You start in a snowy landscape were you meet the very annoying little robot, Claptrap. He helps you for the first missions, were you ahve to fight your way to Sanctuary, the last rebell country, were the Crimson Raiders, stand to fight the Hyperion-Corporation and his leader Jack. The whole shooter is on the planet Pandora, were everything is very modern, for example Laserpistols, but always mixed with a nice shot of magic, which you can control, if you play the Siren, which is one of the 4 character types you can play in Borderlands. Each one has his own skilltrees and an action skill, like a placeable turret, which you can improve in the skill tree each level.  The world is very big and very varied. So like i said there is a snowy area, a desert area and mining caves or lavaseas. The missions have always a nice background story and are very nice to play. The most missions are to go to some points, pick something up or kill somebody and fight your way back to the employer. Some other types like defending places or deliver packages in a short time are also included. This does not sound like very variable missions, but because of the nice world, without repeating areas every single mission has his own touch, which is improved as well because of the background story. Just the deliver missions were sometimes annoying, but with just 3 or 4 missions of them it is not bad.  Another good point for the game is, that if you play alone, the enemies are less stronger than with a friend, so you can go alone to save Pandora or go with your friend. Another good thing for the multiplayer is that if you collect money or get a reward your friend will get the same amount, so you never have to fight for loot.  In the beginning of my review i already mention the sick humor of the game. Full of Eestereggs and references to games or TV Shows the game does not look that mad, but for example in one mission you have to capture a bandit for a 13-years-old female, which torture him than and drink some tea with him on an electric chair and all her teddys. They are some more of these scene which explains the 18+ sign.  For people who likes that humorstyle and look for a very very very long story (played 40 hours just for campaign and all side missions), the game is definetly a good choice.

Do you like first person shooters? Do you like RPG's? Do you like action packed adventure with friends? WELL GUESS WHAT, If you answered yes to any of those questions, stop pondering whether to buy it or not! This game is a hek of a lot of FUN! I garentee you, that you will get a great time out of it!
