Borderlands 2 is a really good game if you love shooting people and collecting loot, especially the awesome guns. What you probably won't like though is that it's really REALLY repetitive for some people. That's one reason that people may not like this game. The other reason is that, in this game, you kind of need to grind a bit because in the later places of this game, you might find yourself getting owned. And finally, my third reason that you may not like this game is: the level difference. I'm talking about when you join a friend's game and find out you're a bit behind.  Okay so it starts normally, you're shooting enemies right? And then you notice, your shots are doing so little damage. Your reaction would be: What the ****, why is my gun useless? Yeah, that will happen. It really reeks of donkey ♥♥♥♥ how that works. Anyway moving on, if you can ignore all of that, this game is great.   (Like me, I like this game even though it's shooting people and collecting loot. I bought the goty edition of this game even though I already had the original just for all the dlc :D)   Characters: The characters of this game are really well acted. I like how Handsome Jack is a kind of villain that's likeable though you still hate him. Cl4ptr4p is annoying though. I heard the C14PTR4P from the original Borderlands was much better. I honestly don't know since I haven't played much of the first game. And to be honest, I didn't really know the story of the first game since it was really vague. Tiny Tina is also an interesting character so to speak. Her backstory was really interesting too, for me.   The playable characters you can choose from are: Axton, Maya, Salvador, Zer0, Gaige, and the latest and last playable character, Krieg. I will summarize all of these characters' main abilities.   Axton is a (bisexual, lol) guy who can summon his turrets to fight alongside him (or with his friends too). You can further upgrade his ability so that when he summons his turrets they can have a shield sphere, or when you summon it, it can cause an explosion which damages the enemies near your turret. And also you can upgrade your turret's gun which makes it stronger.   Maya is a siren, who basically has an ability called phaselock which allows her to trap her opponent in an orb that makes them unable to move. You can further upgrade this so that it can cause effects like slag, or you can make it a supportive ability which you use phaselock on your friends to heal them.  Salvador is a kind of um short and plump guy who has the ability to dual wield any two weapons of your choice. Sniper and rocket launcher, check. Pistol and assault rifle, check. Smg and smg, check. Basically any weapon combo you want, it's possible.  Zer0, this guy is too awesome. He's an alien guy, who can turn invisible and slash enemies with his katana. I can't describe him much. The info about him is really vague. And yes, you heard me right, he is an alien. (Or possibly, it's heavily hinted he's an alien though.)  Gaige is girl with a mechanical arm who summons Deathtrap, a robot that she can summon to fight for her. To be honest I haven't played Gaige's char yet. So idk what she really does well in.  Krieg, now this is where it gets fun. Have you always wondered if you could play as the psycho in Borderlands? Ohhhh boy, well if yes then, this is for you. No? Well then, this is still for you. Imo he is my favorite character next to all of these char. I can't really pick my fave character because I like all of them, but Krieg is my favorite if I'm forced to pick. This guy is so awesome to play with. I recommend you get the Psych0 pack dlc if you haven't. His special ability is that you use your axe and ♥♥♥♥ people up. Yes, I mean that literally, okay maybe not but still. He is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome.  You either throw the axe at those mofos or chop the ♥♥♥♥ out of them yourself. Not only that, you can also upgrade his skill tree which makes him more awesome. Basically, you got downed? No problem man, get the ♥♥♥♥ back up and strap a bomb to yourself. Then when you explode, bam, you get revived. There's also something SUPER MEGA FOOKIN AWESOME. When you upgrade his skill tree high enough, when a time comes your health is low at a certain level, you transform into a badass psycho and..... holy ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥, get ♥♥♥♥♥ rekt. You can rek them like there's no tomorrow.  Sound: Hmmm, this section is going to be short. The sound is what can I say, okay I guess for this game. There's not much music going on that makes me really want to fight. If you count the opening song though, that song is awesome. The gun sounds are pretty good. They sound great if you ask me. I'm not really a gun sound expert but it sounds fine to me. Great sound.  Visuals: Unlike some people, I actually like the cell-shaded style of this game. It's what makes this game Borderlands. It probably wouldn't be the same if they tried to make the graphics different. The visuals for this game are really good. I like the landscape, the ice areas, lava, eridium blight. All the places in this game are well done. Props to Gearbox for making this game spectacular. Awesome visuals.  Plot: I'm not going to say much but the plot of this game is great for me. It's a game about where you're a vault hunter who is searching for the vault in this game. And throughout the game you encounter Handsome Jack, the main villain, I already described him but basically he's a likeable ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. In the beginning of the game, you are discovered by C14PTR4P who is shocked to see a vault hunter like you alive. After that you go through fights and then you reach Sanctuary. Here is where the main cast of Borderlands 1 are in this game. (Lilith, Mordecai, Brick and Roland) At this point you're going to meet the Firehawk and then rescue Roland. You basically meet all of the original cast of the first game and you work together to defeat Handsome Jack. It's a good story imo.  I would say this game is well worth your money at the 10 dollars I spent during the Steam Summer Sale. As I said, I already owned the game, but I decided to buy goty for 10 dollars which is the same price for the season pass. (Goty is the same price as the season pass, the season pass contains all the main story dlc which is in the goty. The goty edition has additional dlc like the Gaige and Krieg char pack.) So if you own the game, I would recommend you buy the goty edition if you want the dlc of the season pass. Back to the main topic, this game is well worth over 10 dollars to be honest. It's the best RPG FPS I've ever played. (Not counting Deus Ex because I consider that sci-fi) If you didn't already have this game, I would suggest you buy it. Good job Gearbox, you did a good job. I'm a bit sad about Aliens: Colonial Marines. But in this game, you've put an outstanding amount of work into it.

Prepare to dive into the loot-filled world of Borderlands 2! This game is one of my personal favorites, and with only 70 hours (so far) on the PC, I have many more on the Xbox 360. Breeze through the game on normal mode, collecting loot and punching faces in. Not satisfies with all of the side quests? Ready for a harder difficulty? Jump into True Vault Hunter Mode and grind your teeth and enemies until you get to level 50. Still not completely satisfied? Yearning for just a bit more fun and loot? Try out Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode and prepare for the harder-than-dark-souls enemies and bosses (but they drop more loot!). Picked up any DLC? Great! Head into one of those and bash some more baddies. Ultimate Vault Hunter Pack DLC's? Make your way up to level 72, getting the best guns in the game along the way. Doesn't sound fun? Doesn't sound like there is any variety? Personally, I can't think of anything to prove you wrong, but you'll just have to check out other stuff.   So, whether you're farming for that legendary or fighting your way to that last raid boss, Borderlands 2 is sure to satisfy even the most treasure-hungry person.  Get the GOTY (Game of the Year) edition when it's on sale for an experience that doesn't disappoint.

Borderlands 2 is a very well done loot finding Fps, however if that isn't your thing I don't recommend it.  The visuals are very top notch and the animations are solid. The voice acting is top notch and the music adds a good amount of atmosphere. The gameplay feels more refined than the first by that I mean they added a mini map, more customization, etc. The shooting works well for what it is, but I think they could make it more satisfying. Honestly what makes borderlands a rewarding game is finding a new weapon or leveling up more. The feeling you get when come across a new gun and using is such a great feeling in a game.  Now in terms of what I dislike with the game, well the biggest one is the humor. It's really forced and it's just a bunch of internet memes, since that's what the writer considers 'humor'. Now I do appreciate that the game attempted to put in a narrative, and while the humor falls flat the actual writing is good mostly and the characters are well done. In terms of other issues well sometimes borderlands can feel a bit samey in places.  That being said the positives out weigh the bad, though it's not everyone it's a solid title.  8/10

Borderlands 2 features a new array of procedurally generated guns, shields, grenades, artifacts and enemies aswell as 4 new playable classes. Play as one of four new mercenary classes, Assassin (Zer0) who used to perform both political assassinations and common hits, Commando (Axton) who was a member of the military force ranked as Sergeant, Gunzerker (Salvador) who was born and raised in the planet of Pandora and is known for using excessive violence and Siren (Maya) who used to live in her homeworld, Athenas and has a variety of superb powers, while exploring a new set of surprising environments across the living planet of Pandora. Aswell as Borderlands, Borderlands 2 also features an amazing 4 players cooperative experience and the content released provides an near-endless variety of missions, weapons and character customization. Borderlands 2 is a game I highly recommend along with the released content for an even more epic and fun experience.

Borderlands 2 isn't much different from the first game, but if you're looking for a fun coop shooter, look no further than this game. Story and diverse gameplay isn't the game's strong suit and the humor is rather childish, but all this is forgotten as soon as you start shooting midgets in the face with shotguns or rocketlaunchers. The main game without DLCs takes about 40 hours if you do every last one of the Side quests, upon completing the game you unlock a New Game+, NG++ is unlocked by DLC. DLC wise, the game does boast alot of them, though not all of them are worthwhile. If you want to spend money on only one of them, you should probably go with 'Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep', because it is not only the longest one of the four add on stories, but also features completely new enemies and dragons. I felt like mentioning dragons. Bottom line, if you like shooters or action-oriented RPGs, this game probably is for you and you can easily spend hundreds of hours playing it. I certainly did.

Borderlands 2. After playing through one hour of the first game, I turned it off. I found it to be repetitive, buggy, bland. I saw this in the Summer Sale for £5. My friend said it was amazing, so I thought what the hell. I am so glad I brought it.  The Humour is ALOT better than the first game. (Tiny Tina!). The graphics are alot more colourful and varied than the first game. There is hardly any glitches in the game, which really annoyed me in the first game. The story actually has a good few plot twists that fit in well with the RPG elements of the game. Actually, the RPG elements are very good. I like loot based games such as Diablo 3, Torchlight, and I'd say that Borderlands 2 is on par with them games. Also, the in game UI is also alot better, and they added a mini map. A MINI MAP!  The world surprised me as well. The characters in the game are some of the best video game characters ever produced. All of them are memorable.  Overall, I loved Borderlands 2 and was one of my favourite games of the 2012 releases. It is a vast improvement over the first game and is a very replayable game as well.  I give Borderlands 2 a 5/5.

Borderlands 2 is incredibly fun, it combines the fun of shooting things with the extended campaign of an RPG. There are new, awesome environments as well as playable characters that are interesting and fun to play as.  There is also a lot of replay value considering there are between 4 and 6 classes depending on whether you buy the GOTY edition/DLC packs, also the main campaign plus DLC can get you 25-40 hours in playthrough 1 alone, then there is True vault hunter mode and Ultimate vault hunter mode which can lead you to play even longer. There is also up to 4 player co-op which makes the game even more fun, however single player is also extremely enjoyable  The only issue I have is the loot system, which will probably cause you to have to farm for a decent amount of time to get that legendary you want.  Overall Borderlands 2 is a great game and I would strongly recommend buying it (buy the GOTY edition). 9.5/10.  Edit: I forgot to mention, the DLC campaigns do not scale to your level so you will probably wind up being level 40 fighting level 30 enemies, it isn't necessarily a negative but it's not a positive either

I'm not a big shooter player. Most everything I don't like about your average AAA shooter, Borderlands does well for me. It uses just enough RPG elements to average out skill levels in multiplayer. So I can play with friends, loved ones, whomever without having to worry about dragging them down, or my dragging them down. The humor's great. The writing swings from hilarious to powerful with no notice. The characters are interesting and diverse.   If you have a chance, the Tiny Tina's Dragon Keep DLC is amazing, and wraps up the main story with a charming, cathartic twist.   I'd recommend buying this if you're a person that likes things which are good. If you're not, avoid this title.

Simply put, this is probably one of, if not the most rewarding loot based games on Steam. Not to mention that it includes a compelling storyline, great downloadable content, and a very unique art style that draws away from many games, yet remains visually appealing.   This is a game with great replay value too, and can/will keep you occupied for hours on end. For its price, and everything you can get with it, Borderlands 2 makes for a truly enjoyable shoot n' loot game. There always seems to be something more to do in this game, whether it be side quests, loot farming, or just exploring the huge and diverse world that is Pandora. A rewarding skill tree and additional bonuses granted from completing challenges will keep you coming back to keep playing.  Borderlands 2 is a game that I got much pleasure from, and one I still will continue to play for a long time, which is an opinion that most people who have played this game can easily share.

This game is great, from the art design to the writing and all of the combat. Being able to equip any variety of weapons from a basic pistol all the way up to a rocket launcher that shoots small nuclear blasts of acid is unbeliveably addicting. Even the grenades are customizable, so if tossing a standard frag grenade is getting old you can try homing grenades that leech health from enemies, or a teleporting grenade that deploys a tesla coil when it lands, or even bouncing grenades that spawn smaller, random grenades. The beauty of this game is the chaos you can create. Oh, and shooting insane midgets in the face (that's fun too).
This is a really great game that everyone should buy.

Honestly, without the DLCs, the game can get quite repititive and a max cap of level 50. Borderlands 2 is one of the games where the DLCs (mainly campaigns and ultimate vault hunter packs) are COMPLETELY worth buying, adding so much more into the game.  We're talking about: -2 more playable characters -4 more campaigns which includes more loot and UNIQUE weapons to be found. -Max level cap at 72, meaning more skill points to wreck your enemies -Level 72 not enough? Get overpower levels (up to 8) to make your enemies scale up to level 80+ and find level 80 weapons in the process. (Also a DLC) -5 Head hunterpacks, optional if you're willing to spend some cash to spice up a little more missions. If you love open world games with a mixture of RPG values AND coop features to play with your friends, would definately recommend this game. -Ranks to increase stats that apply to ALL characters by completing tasks As for storyline, has many aspects in it, of course, definitely humour The only cons i see in the game is tedious farm for EXP towards end-game ONLY if you are playing multiple characters. Its a pain to level each one of them to level 72 (Only if you have both vault hunter packs) if you really felt like doing that in the first place, unless of ocurse you have the patience to do so. Overall, in my opinion, i enjoyed the game and i do still have plans to continue here and there.

There is nothing new I can contribute to the pile of 'Overwhelmingly Positive' reviews.   + I love the cel-shaded graphics;  + The different classes provide a little something for everyone. The 3 skill trees per class, along with the ability to respec your character whenever you'd like provides a lot of replayability and customization;  + The pop culture references were great additions, whether they were side-quest related or spawnable bosses (Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Donkey Kong, and Batman to name a few)  + The game never takes itself too seriously (I looted a gun named, 'Bulets Go Fasterified Plasma Caster', and no that is not a typo...)  + After beating the game, you can restart at the beginning and do a 'Legend of Zelda: Second Quest' version of the game, where you bring over your equipment, money, and experience and fight scaled-up enemies for better loot;  - The only minus that comes to mind for me is a very preventable minus. It's easy to get overpowered for the DLC if you don't play them at the right point of your playthrough. After I beat the game, I played the Pirate's Booty DLC and nothing really scratched me.   ** One thing I would like to add is that Borderlands 2 GOTY edition is the type of game here on Steam that goes on sale quite frequently. I purchased the GOTY edition for $7.99 (as opposed to the normal $39.99). After about 180 hours of play time, I daresay that was probably the best $7.99 I ever spent :) So if you haven't pulled the trigger on playing this yet, and your wallet is not overflowing, bide your time and pick it up on sale at some point this year. You will definitely get the most bang for your money this way.  (Those gun puns were unintentional...maybe.)

So, typically, when people who make games like the games that I like, they end up making games that I don't like.  I'm not sure what that's all about--probably something about being fundamentally antisocial and hostile to anything that smells even faintly of solidarity--but it's been a constant for as long as I can remember with one or two very rare exceptions.  At any rate, it's clear that some dudebros at Gearbox like the games that I like: I've got maybe 15 hours in on Borderlands 2 right now, and I've already identified references to Altered Beast and Dark Souls.   Which makes me instinctively dislike this game.  Which makes me dislike this game in spite of the fact that I am definitely having lots of fun playing this game.   I was talking it over with a pal of mine, and we agreed that Borderlands 2 is like the potato chips of games: you're in the bag, up to your elbow, telling everyone around how you much you hate these chips and you're not going to stop eating, even though you're full, until you hate yourself.  Everyone should definitely play this game.

Borderlands 2 is fun, challenging, and funny as hell. From the big selection of guns and upgrades, to the challenging bosses and replayability, to the hilarious character that are very memorable, as well as the fantastic art style, lead writer Anthony Burch and Gearbox/2K know how to make a fun and comically enriching game that defiantly lived up to its expectations. Though, I do have a minor problem with the save system, as my level, upgrades, and items would be there, but I would have to beat a slew of enemies again or beat a boss again unless I fully complete a mission, which sometimes can become frustrating. But overall, this is a must-buy in the FPS genre. 9.5/10

So very playable! Borderlands 2 follows up on Borderlands and improves on everything. Once again you explore the  cray-cray wild west meets sci-fi world of Pandora. You do missions, you shoot stuff, you use badass powers ,you kill stuff, you loot stuff. Fun all around You do this for tens of hours and it never gets boring ( a sign of good game design)  The main missions are fun. The side mission are better, as they range from crazy to funny and usually a combination of the two. You do often really weird stuff for both old characters from B1 as well as brand new and just as crazy new characters (meet the teenage girl explosives expert who does tea parties and talks like someone from GTA)  The gameplay is as crazy as the rest of the game. As one (or up to four) man (or woman) you take on bandits, beasts and the evil Handsome (meh) Jack. You choose from a variety of gun types and a variety of crazy powers to kick ♥♥♥. And did i mention those guns have crazy powers too? Well they do - like the explosion Torque weapons which blow stuff up or the tediore guns which you can turn into grenades. There's also in-game achievements. You get these for pretty much every thing you can do in the game. As you complete more of these you can boost your stats to be even more badass.  The playthrough should give you tens of hours. But wait, it's not over yet. You can get dlcs and kick new ♥♥♥ in new areas. Or you can start the game over in true vaulter mode, where you keep your level and your gear but every enemy is stronger. And then once more with ultimate vault hunter mode, where amazingly enemies are even stronger and kicking ♥♥♥ is even more of a challenge. Or you can start the game again with a new class which plays in a very different way.  So to sum up. Borderlands 2 is a funny game which plays well and plays for a very long time indeed. I'd recommend getting it because the gameplay is such a lot of fun, but also because this is a game where you really get your money's worth.

SO, I'm actually doing a review. OK then...    So first, why, did I get this game? Because I'm a veteran Vault Hunter, who played Borderlands 1. Now, what I expected from this was simply... bigger. Larger world, larger story, larger number of guns (In which Gearbox decided to break their own record for most guns in a game, which was previously held by Borderlands.), and a bigger amount of fun. And you know what? I got all of that, but you don't need to have played Borderlands to be able to fully enjoy this (But I do recommend.), all you need to do to really enjoy this, is to want to shoot something in the face. Moving on, this game, storywise, was, y'know, sort of loose at first, just regular, wanting to be the hero kind of biz, but then, things get freaking serious. And, by that part, some of the fights aren't as much putting bullets in every soon-to-be corpse, as just having everything against you, you not having the upper hand, just a matter of survival, not gaining or losing ground. But those 2 kinds of fights in the game, are what I enjoyed most. At one point, 'Should I play with others?', well, that's a pretty retorical. One of the joys of playing this is to bond with other gamers, have someone to share a laugh with as you hear this game's hilarious dialogue. Have someone, to have seen how awesome it was, when you made a dude burst into flames. Other benefits: Well, more players= more enemies, more enemies=better loot! You also have someone to keep you from dieing throughout a firefight... And you're only one person, so the benefits of playing with the other characters won't be able to help you out. You can play solo... if you want, but I recommend playing with others more than 50% of the time. And so, we talk about graphics and how it feels running this. I... am not at all very knowledgable about this topic. All I know is from hearing my friend obssessing over 'how it looks playing Crysis 3 on MAX GRAPHICS SETTINGS!' So how the graphics are. In this, they have a bit of emphasis, I guess. on the lines and outlines of things. The lines are thicker or thinner depending on how well you have your graphics set up. Also, texture quality gets really nice as you go up in the settings. But now I shall tell you the wonders of the PhysX option. I forgot most of what I know about it, but it gives added realism, like the water looking more realistic, ton of other liquid-enhancing crap... Also the ability to shoot cloth and leave, not a little dent, as if it were concrete, well with this, nope, you get to strip a tent of it's cloth by shooting it! Other things like that, too.   So the altogether Borderlands 2 experience? Amazing. Fun. Memorable. And every synonym for those words. Just... what I expected out of this experience.   Rating- 9.6/10.  Recommended Type of Gamer: One that feels like having multiple ways to kill a guy and laugh about it... and feels like doing that with friends.

Borderlands is one of the best game-series ever made in my opinion. You can play it for 200 hours and there will still be something you didn't find yet.    Gameplay:  First things first - You get further in the game by doing quests BUT every quest is kinda unique and I don't feel like doing the same thing all over again. (Except you are playing the game again and again. In this case you really do the same thing over and over again... but it's still fun!) The best thing about this game is it's great sense of humor. It doesn't take it self very seriously even though you will recognize that there is a deeper story going on under all the jokes. At some point it feels like an MMO mixed with a FPS and the detail and humorous story of an indi game. I don't see any way how this could go wrong! :D   Combat: I've never had such a variety of weapons in a game before and with those different kinds of guns there comes a whole new feeling to all of the fights. You can start of by picking the obvious enemys with a sniper rifle and take the rest out with a shotgun that makes everything explode around you. And I'm not even talking about the legendary weapons yet. When it comes to combat everything is up to you. There is no 'whaaat you want to use this weapon? sorry but you took that class so you can't use this!'. Just take something that looks nice to you and tare the world apart!   Characters: You will meet a lot of different characters through out the game and everyone is insane in a different way. You will even get background information about some people by doing quests or finding random stuff. The Characters are one of the biggest reasons why this game is so great!   Leveldesign: The world could look a little boring when you look at it but it really isn't. There is so much going on and things are changing as you move forward in the story. You can find secrets and eastereggs all over the place but they are sometimes really hard to find. In general the world is split in different areas which you can explore so it's not fully openworld but it doesn't feel like you are forced to go a specific way. For me it solves the problem of wanting to explore the world and every little detail in it and fully losing track while doing that. You are free to look around but you still get to where you have to go.   Looting: I think that's one of the biggest parts of this game. You will lose count of how many cases and lockers you've looted really soon but you will find new weapons and ammo in it so you should try to loot everything you see. The ammo runs out really quick on some weapons so keep an eye out for the green light which marks a lootable object.   Lategame: You will finish the main story kinda quick (depending on how many sidequests you are doing and how much you are into exploring) and that will be around level 25-30. But it's not even close to being over at this point. You will just unlock the next stage of the game at this point which means that you start a 'new' game but you keep all your levels and stuff, just the story resets and the enemies will now be on your level again. There are some quests which you can only do if you are level 50 or even higher so it's worth the extra time you are spending. And as i said earlier, you won't be bored since the combat is so much fun and you will develop even further, getting stronger weapons and all that nice stuff. And if you are level 50 in the end and everything is done, don't you worry mate, there is still a ton of DLCs and other playable characters to try out! Borderlands 2 may be released some years ago but it's not even close to beeing dead! There is still stuff released for it and it get's better the longer you play it.   Bad Stuff: Of course there is something bad on every game, so these are my greatest problems in BL2.  - Sometimes when you kill an enemie and it drops loot or throw out something of your inventory the items will fall through the ground and be gone for ever. I lost quite a high amount of my legendary weapons this way. So always search a save spot for something like that or use the trade option.  - There are some quests which lead you right back into an area which you've already cleared and it's a bit painful to walk that way all over again especially since you have to do that twice for every character since you will have to replay everything to get a highlevel char.  - The pizza at Claptraps party is cold. (Insider xD)    I really hope i could help you with this one and thanks for reading :)  For me Borderlands 2 is a must have and I promisse you - you won't regret it!

I absolutely recommend this game to anyone who just wants to have fun. You can hang out with your friends and kill raid bosses or play the campaign, or you can join random people and just have fun doing whatever they are doing. All in all the shoot and looting in this game is really good, however, some legendaries don't drop often enough to make it worth farming for. However, when you finally do kill that boss you have been struggling to kill or finally get the legendary you've been wanting, it feels really good. It makes you feel like you actually earned what you got.  Secondly, the story is absolutely amazing even though at some times it feels a bit repetive, for instance 'Kill this thing and pick up what it drops.' This happens a couple times in the story and in the side missions. All in all, I really recommend this to anyone who likes fun first person shooters with a lot of humor at some times. Each character feels unique and different from the others, whether its a playable character or just an Npc. Honestly I think you will have a good time playing and my final rating for this game is a 9.5/10.

'Sup'  Borderlands. The series that defines the masculine art of looting people that you've killed and hoarding it until you look like a man who's smoked for 20 years and has an extreme case of Vitamin D deficiency. The original Borderlands was built around a mechanic made by Gearbox Software. Randomized weapons and components. It was a great engine component and many people credit Gearbox for inventing the 'shoot 'n loot' genre. The first game didn't have much of a story, it was just built around the game mechanic.  Borderlands 2 made an extreme improvements. To list a few: enhanced mini-map, enhanced HUD, a entertaining story, better vehicles, character customization and better loot. OH GOD THE LOOT. The writers at Gearbox clearly put a lot of time into writing the story, making it funny, charismatic and witty. It is one of the highlights of the game. The graphics of the game has improved greatly as well. It has integrated Nvidia PhysX into the game and engine and recently been compatible with 4K, at the sacrifice of 60 fps.  In all, this game is a must have. 9/10

An amazing idea executed amazingly. Buy it now. Enough has been said.  Now to write an actual review (kind of):  Like it's predecessor (which is aptly named 'Borderlands', for those of you not astute enough to realise), Borderlands 2 is a fusion of genres, namely murdering and looting. You slay large crowds of enemies with weapons such as the 'Murdurin Slagga' and the 'Bandity Pistal' and then loot chests for stuff that's probably not as good as what you're already using.  In all seriousness, it's an RPG/FPS fusion, full of dark humour and pop culture references. Well, not necessarily pop culture, but references that many internet/gaming veterans will get. From suicide side missions to crude sexual innuendo, this game is full of fun for....not quite the entire family.  The main storyline is decently long and there's plenty of side missions and replay value, so you'll definitely get your money's worth of playtime out of this game.  Whether you're a bandit or not, give Borderlands 2 a try. It might just become a favourite.

There's so much I can say about this game, it's enjoyable to play by yourself, just plug your headphones in and listen to music whilst you enjoy your time. You can play with your friends doing quests, trading, duelling each other. I myself online, offline and on my PS3 have put a few thousand hours in this game altogether and i've loved every last minute of it! the gameplay is enjoyable with there always being something that catches your eye and then being your main focus.   There's a range of easter eggs throughout the game some more subtle than others but all placed in the game the correct way which makes us search for them and work together as a community to find them all. The mass amount of guns allows for you to play however you'd like to and also creating your own fun little challenges which affect the way you play the game massively.   (small spoilers ahead)  The story itself is quite enjoyable when you get deeply involved and attached to characters, personally from playing the first game there were characters that I was happy to see back and locations which were from the first game too but changed and developed to follow along with the plot. The villain in this game has got to be one of the best i've seen in awhile, how he talks, finding out about what he's done to other people in the past, his own daughter (which I know some people have mixed views on). The story is designed to introduce you to new areas, enemy's and also teach you that you objective may not be given to you straight up in a way which lets you explore the area and makes you use your brain when searching for items. The level progression in the main story missions makes it so you the player need to do side missions to get more experience and become a higher level whilst also making you explore new areas the you wouldn't have come by otherwise.   There is a total of 4 characters in the base game and an additional 2 making there 6 if you purchase them, i'm gonna start by talking about the base 4.  The commando: His ability is that he sends out a deployable turret that can become a killing machine if upgraded in one of the 3 skill trees that he has. Without spoiling too much this includes adding a shield surrounding the turret, adding rockets that fire from it and making it explode like a nuke when it's deployed. His skills make him very deadly when using assult rifles by increasing their damage, fire rate and reload speed. I started off playing as the commando because of how many different play styles there was with him, for someones first ever time playing through the game and learning about what guns are best, what element is best against certain enemy's I recommend the commando.   The siren: The siren is one of 6 that can exist in the universe at any given time, she is able to 'phase lock' her enemy that is small enough in to a orb in the air allowing you to damage them whilst they're vulnerable for around 5 seconds. The siren is based around elemental damage in all forms; increasing the elemental damage all together, increasing the elemental effect chance and allowing you to inflict elemental damage with a non-elemental gun. Using SMG's with the siren is where she shines the most with there being a wide range of SMG's with elements that you can access early in the game. Playing as the siren I recommend to be done once you understand how the element system works and what works best.  The gunzerker: This is my favourite character to play as during the late game, the gunzerker's ability is that he can duel-wield any guns for around 20-30 seconds (before skills come in to play). During his gunzerk he is regenerating ammo slowly for the gun type currently being used such as pistol and shotgun however, the one ammo type that can't be regenerated is rocket ammo. His skill trees vary how he plays massively; you could be create a gunzerker who can basically fire forever without using any ammo when at low health, a gunzerker who can flip off his enemy's and get most of his health back instantly. I recomment to play the gunzerker after researching his skill tree first so that you can plan out how you play the game.   The assassin: This is the character i've played the least out of the main 4, he is a strange and mysterious person that we don't really know much about. Zer0 the assassin is able to vanish whilst deploying a decoy for 5 seconds where the next attack you do does considerably more damage but will remove you from your invisible state. Zer0 can be played either at long range with a sniper or up close with his melee attack doing massive amounts of damage and if it kills the enemy will allow for him to deploy another decoy and let you remain invisible for a few seconds longer. I find him the least entertaining to play out of the base 4 but he can still become a very powerful character to play as if you know how to build him.  The DLC in this game includes head hunter packs which gives you unique skin customisation for your characters, the main DLC stories which include: Captin Scarlet, Sir Hammerlock, Mr Torgue and Tiny Tina's assult on dragons keep. Then there is the other 2 characters the mechromancer and the psycho.   The mechromancer: This character's ability is she summons a death trap which chases down enemies and then slices them with razor sharp claws. Similar to the siren the mechromancer is very skilled with using elemental weapons mainly shock weapons increasing its damage output and effect chance, you can chose to either develop and improve on your character's damage output and make you the badass or you can turn the death trap in to a flying death machine which can shoot electricity at ranged enemies, gain a copy of your shield and clap its hands together causing a large explosion. When you want to play for fun and have a really entertaining time playing i recommend using the mechromancer for this experience.   The psycho: This character is designed for all out brutality, his ability is to run around with a large buzz axe and slice through his enemies, being damaged allows for him to regain his ability faster which when working with certain builds can make him almost invincible. The most common and powerful build turns you in to a raging badass who can chain expload his enemies with ease which when fighting large groups of enemies in a small space makes him deadly. You can also follow the path of lighting yourself on fire and then getting increased damage whilst ignited. To use this character you will need to do some research before hand to ensure that you get the best build possible as some skills can be difficult to understand so I greatly recommend this character but only after gaining information about him.   Overall I can recomment this game to anyone who enjoys FPS, farming and insane games, when i say insane i mean it as in the world that the game is based in and you have to live in with the story line, crazy characters you meet along the way and the ones you also play as. It's easy to pick up and play but hard to put back down afterwards I hope this helped anyone wondering if they should get this game :)

Worst game   This was sarcasm, I've put over 600 hours into this and I'm still going. No, it's not the best game and yes, while Gearbox got the systems right (in my opinion) their actual coding is amateur at best. The game is pretty solid now though but it took a while to get there, I can't think of any 'oh wow' glitches, exploits or mistakes in the game. If you suffer from OCD - and I mean this seriously - you might struggle; to do everything in the game you're going to be playing it for a bloody long time. Each of the six characters can do 3 playthroughs of the game (the third being repeatable), there're four story DLCs each of which can be played three times, there are the Head Hunter packs, Digistruct Peak (designed to be beaten eight times to get you to over power level 80), the heads, skins, vehicle skins for four vehicles, Badass challenges (which are repeatable)... There's a LOT of content here.   If you pay for it all, anyway. The game without any DLC is still pretty big.

I completely recommend playing this game with friends. The game has a lot of content (in terms of DLCs) and if you enjoyed the humor from the first Borderlands you'll have plenty of it in BL2...  The game offers a lot of improvements over the first one. - weapons are more diverse - You get badass points as you play and you can allocate the badass levels into stats (like weapon damage, shield capacity, accuracy, reload speed etc). You can't pick the stat you want all the type, but you do get to pick out of 5-6 stats that are random (or change with every level).  - You can gamble all the extra money you have for Eridium (a rare currency used to increase your ammo capacity and inventory/bank size).  - You can transfer the items from your characters through claptraps hideout. So if you've found a super nice class mod and think you might play that class, you don't have to store it in your bank or inventory.  You should probably buy the game if you like a FPS that is fun, works fine on older hardware and has some dark humor in it.

The offspring of Dungeon Crawlers and First Person Shooters. If you don't know what Borderlands is you're sheltered or new to gaming. It's one of those rare games that makes you laugh just by playing the game, not because you found some glitch or hidden easter egg, but because you just looted an old, nasty out house with flies buzzing around it and the words 'No fapping' spray painted on the side. To top it off there were actually guns that came out of the toilet. It's not just funny though it also has a next to infinite ammount of randomized weapons and gear. A pistol that shoots two bullets at the same time which seek the enemy and explode on contact. A grenade mod that spits out more grenades and explodes twice. A machine gun that shoots incindiary rounds and can be thrown like a grenade when reloaded. A grenade that teleports to the target and spits out acid. Those all exist.

A great single and/or co-op experience with thousands of possibilities for gun loadouts, stats, and fun.  You do have to adjust to the gameplay as you level up and advance through the game modes (Normal, Ultimate, etc), so typically, you should not expect to easily succeed, especially if you have not played very often. It is totally okay and even sometimes necessary to die, which is definitely a feature not as common in games that I have played. Sometimes it is also difficult to find a loadout of guns and abilities that work for you, so it is key to explore and experiment with different brands and gun types and stats and ability trees. Especially try out the different characters, because you will very likely find a specific one that works best for you and is your favorite.  If you love comedy, being involved in action, honing your aim, battling giant monsters, shooting up a storm in a camp full of bandits, delivering amputated limbs to mailboxes, performing mad science, opening loot crates, getting your heart torn out, using badass powers, working together with teammates/friends/family, and having a great time, this is definitely the game for you.  10/10 would Vault Hunt again

Borderlands is one of the best game-series ever made in my opinion. You can play it for 200 hours and there will still be something you didn't find yet.    Gameplay:  First things first - You get further in the game by doing quests BUT every quest is kinda unique and I don't feel like doing the same thing all over again. (Except you are playing the game again and again. In this case you really do the same thing over and over again... but it's still fun!) The best thing about this game is it's great sense of humor. It doesn't take it self very seriously even though you will recognize that there is a deeper story going on under all the jokes. At some point it feels like an MMO mixed with a FPS and the detail and humorous story of an indi game. I don't see any way how this could go wrong! :D   Combat: I've never had such a variety of weapons in a game before and with those different kinds of guns there comes a whole new feeling to all of the fights. You can start of by picking the obvious enemys with a sniper rifle and take the rest out with a shotgun that makes everything explode around you. And I'm not even talking about the legendary weapons yet. When it comes to combat everything is up to you. There is no 'whaaat you want to use this weapon? sorry but you took that class so you can't use this!'. Just take something that looks nice to you and tare the world apart!   Characters: You will meet a lot of different characters through out the game and everyone is insane in a different way. You will even get background information about some people by doing quests or finding random stuff. The Characters are one of the biggest reasons why this game is so great!   Leveldesign: The world could look a little boring when you look at it but it really isn't. There is so much going on and things are changing as you move forward in the story. You can find secrets and eastereggs all over the place but they are sometimes really hard to find. In general the world is split in different areas which you can explore so it's not fully openworld but it doesn't feel like you are forced to go a specific way. For me it solves the problem of wanting to explore the world and every little detail in it and fully losing track while doing that. You are free to look around but you still get to where you have to go.   Looting: I think that's one of the biggest parts of this game. You will lose count of how many cases and lockers you've looted really soon but you will find new weapons and ammo in it so you should try to loot everything you see. The ammo runs out really quick on some weapons so keep an eye out for the green light which marks a lootable object.   Lategame: You will finish the main story kinda quick (depending on how many sidequests you are doing and how much you are into exploring) and that will be around level 25-30. But it's not even close to being over at this point. You will just unlock the next stage of the game at this point which means that you start a 'new' game but you keep all your levels and stuff, just the story resets and the enemies will now be on your level again. There are some quests which you can only do if you are level 50 or even higher so it's worth the extra time you are spending. And as i said earlier, you won't be bored since the combat is so much fun and you will develop even further, getting stronger weapons and all that nice stuff. And if you are level 50 in the end and everything is done, don't you worry mate, there is still a ton of DLCs and other playable characters to try out! Borderlands 2 may be released some years ago but it's not even close to beeing dead! There is still stuff released for it and it get's better the longer you play it.   Bad Stuff: Of course there is something bad on every game, so these are my greatest problems in BL2.  - Sometimes when you kill an enemie and it drops loot or throw out something of your inventory the items will fall through the ground and be gone for ever. I lost quite a high amount of my legendary weapons this way. So always search a save spot for something like that or use the trade option.  - There are some quests which lead you right back into an area which you've already cleared and it's a bit painful to walk that way all over again especially since you have to do that twice for every character since you will have to replay everything to get a highlevel char.  - The pizza at Claptraps party is cold. (Insider xD)    I really hope i could help you with this one and thanks for reading :)  For me Borderlands 2 is a must have and I promisse you - you won't regret it!

I picked up this game a long time ago at Best Buy because it was on sale for about $10. I had heard great things about it and knew it was a great PC game and I had played a good bit of the original Borderlands and liked it as well. It took me over a year to really sit down and play it a good bit (Note: Gameplay was post Destiny release) I've got to say after playing Destiny fairly heavy for a good week and half, beating the current campaign, all strikes, exploring all the maps to the fullest and finding most gold chests, alot of crucible and achieving 3 pieces of legendary gear, for me Borderlands 2 is the better game by a pretty good margin. There is wayyy more variety in the guns and gear you get on Borderlands not to mention how cool the guns and gear actually look. The more you progress in the game, the cooler the guns look obviously. This didnt seem to be the case in Destiny, you could have a level 1 gun beside a level 20 legendary gun and wouldnt really notice any difference other than the stats of the level 20 item. Also the armor ranging from the world and the other five factions had very little variety at all and didnt seem like something I really wanted to work towards. They always claimed the maps to be so massive in Destiny, and they were for the most part, but after playing Borderlands 2 I quickly found out this game was just as much or more ambitious than the new title with tons of different locations to visit and a good variety of weather and terrain it kept the entire game up to the point im currently at very entertaining. Alot of the locations are also very memorable in Borderlands 2, you can remember when you choose to side with either the irish guys from overlook or the rednecks from the dust map each time you pass through the areas and so many more other things. Another thing is the humor and voice acting in this game is some of the best out there, there are some parts that will seriously make you laugh out loud typically with the rednecks in the game they are pretty hilarious. However in Destiny ive got to say the voice acting was awful, probably the worst thing about the game I couldnt believe from a game with that kind of team and budget that the voice acting was so bad and unimmersive, not to mention there was 0 humor in the game (not saying there wernt attempts) Another thing is the story in Borderlands 2 is so fun and action packed and never gets dry because the characters and locations are changing so often, you may do 3 missions here 2 there and 3 for some other guy before you ever even go back and touch a main storyline mission. This is another thing I like is the game doesnt feel linear whatsoever. You can choose however you would like to play it whether that be knock all the story quests out back to back (which may be hard due to having to continously level your character up for certain parts of the game) or do side missions and explore for loot to make sure your character will be fully adept for the main storyline. In Destiny I really dont even know what the heck went on in that game, I ran, I shot, i took cover, fought some boss that took 45 mins to kill and moved on to the next mission on the planet in which I didnt really know why I was there in the first place other than to try and reach level 20 (Which is the current soft level cap) As much as I wanted there to be a cool story, it just wasnt there in Destiny, however you could look at it as you make your own story with your friends as you play through the campaign in co-op, but who really wants that kind of story? Last thing i'll mention is how long and how much playability there is in both games. I know in Destiny I played the game pretty heavily for 2 days before i beat all strikes and missions and reached the level 20 cap. All i really had left to do was the same missions and strikes or crucible to try and find light armor to continue leveling my character. There was no more story, no more xp, no more anything new, just hopes of finding one more piece of better gear after 4 hours of gameplay, and this is only 3 and 4 days after release?? However in Borderlands 2 i've put in 36 hours in the past week and a half and still have not beaten the game and am level 26 (Soft level cap of 50, 72 after all dlc) I like to play alot of the side quest and have done tons of those to make sure i level enough and to get all of the story. There is just so much to do in the base game alone and thats how it should be honestly, not spanned out through dlc over 10 years. There is a ton of great dlc content for Borderlands 2 which i have not purchases or played yet but viewed some gameplay and it looks like alot of fun, Id like to beat the regular game first before i buy anything extra for the game. I know it may have sounded like I bashed Destiny a little in this review, it was a pretty good game overall despite being repetitive and having almost no story but i figured it would be a good comparative for Borderlands 2 since ive seen so many people compare the two already. I was really stoked for weeks about the release of Destiny and went to the midnight release so im completely unbiased, but ive got to say im kinda done with it. I know there will be alot more dlc to come but I dont think it will change things much other than putting you in a new mass location with more grinding for levels and waves of things to shoot. If anyone is looking for a new fps shoot and loot with great replayability, Pick this up right away (Preferably GOTY edition I wish I had) you wont be disappointed.

Loads of great humor, unique style and madcap weapons. A game has rarely made me smile and laugh so much.  It’s a sci fi shooter with a cell-shaded style just the same as the first game. Although there is a greater variety in the environments this time around. The humor is great. The characters are full of personality and the hilarity keeps coming without ever getting too much, aside from Tiny Tina. She's not racist like a lot of people are claiming she’s just too full on and loud.  This game has a bigger focus on plot. Where as the whole of the first Borderlands was just leading up to a final objective, here you will play a part in an actual story. Feeling more involved along with the aforementioned area variety are a big step up in your immersion in the world. You can coop play with up to 3 others but unlike the first title you don't have to be in a team to have the most possible fun.  This is a loot based FPS with more guns than you can shake a stick at. The drop rates require some dedicated playing in order to get the guns you really want. The guns truly are the focus of the Borderlands games. There are several manufacturers that each have distinct game play and aesthetic features. For example Torgue (NOT Torque! >:( ) weapons exclusively use slower velocity, but high power explosive rounds. They have a checkered design. Vladof have very high rates of fire and have a silver or gray finish, with a hammer and sickle or star printed on them. Maliwan typically produce the best elemental guns and have a very sleek sci fi look about them.  Elemental weapons can be fire, corrosive or electric or slag. Using the correct element verses the enemy you're engaging will do a great deal of bonus damage. Likewise using the wrong elements will reduce the damage you deal. Slag guns cover enemies in the substance, which causes them to take double damage from other damage types/elements. Explosive damage and non-elemental guns tend not to be resisted and give you some safe, reliable damage choices.  In general the guns are very silly, but a good silly. Things like rocket firing assault rifles and guns that fire rounds in strange patterns. There are many bizarre and fun guns to find. The exact same gun can spawn with very different stats, which can still be the case with guns of a similar level. Or the same gun could come with a different element. This variety of factors makes for thousands of different guns. A great deal of variety also applies to the other types of loot too. That's why it's frustrating that storage in this game is so limited. You have to make mules just to keep a lot of loot.  As you level up you'll be picking skills and gradually finding better loot for your current level. You've heard it all before. It's the 'multiple classes, leveling, finding better gear' routine. It’s not any deeper than that but it is done well. Aside from guns there are loads of different shields, relics, grenade mods and class mods to find. Class mods buff certain stats and add points to skills. Grenade mods change a grenades behavior and damage type.  Each class feels unique thanks in no small part to the unique ability they can use when combat gets challenging. This is called the 'action skill'. The Gunzerker can dual wield, the Commando lays down a turret, it’s the major factor that separates the them. The characters have three different skill trees each, along with their action skill. You can have a variety of different builds even if you only have the level 61 level cap (the level cap gets raised with certain DLC's). You can get many skills in two of the trees once you hit your level cap. You can respec skills as often as you like if you have the cash.  You can also customize your character's look with different heads and skins. A lot of these are DLC but plenty are unlocked in game. Unlike the first game you can't choose a colour scheme. Your choice of skin dictates the colours you use, as well as their placement on your character. I would have liked to have had more choice in terms of the colours. It feels like a step back even though we now get head customization.  The death penalty is loosing cash. Also enemy health will be fully restored upon your death. That's not a big deal a lot of the time but it’s a game changer against bosses. If your health is reduced to nothing you enter fight for your life mode. When this happens you drop to your knees, unable to move. If you kill an enemy you gain a second wind, getting back on your feet with some restored health. The tense moments, praying you get a second wind before your time runs out make me really enjoy this mechanic.  There are vehicles to ride, which your coop partners can join you in. They're nothing special to be honest. They do help you to get around big area's that would otherwise be tedious, but the combat is average. You can also select different skins for them.  There are a huge number of DLC's. I've found the most enjoyable to be Mr. Torgue's Campaign of Carnage and Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep. There is so much optional content to choose from. This game is huge. If I didn't have many other games to play I could easily get 1000+ hours out of Borderlands 2. The DLC's don't just add quests they also add more gear.  WHAT OTHER REVIEWS ARE NOT TELLING YOU  For your average to low skilled players this is what can ruin the game despite how wonderful everything else about it is.  When you reach the 3rd play through (after completing the game you start again, keeping all your loot and current level) you are forever forced to play at the hardest setting, Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode. You are forced to stay on UVHM as you can only reset the game on this mode of difficulty. Resetting the game allows infinite play throughs while keeping your loot and level. Once you have completed the 1st play through and True Vault Hunter Mode there is no reset for either of them.  UVHM is so tough it massively increases enemy health, gives them health regen, their damage output is such a stupendously high level that you can be in Fight For Your Life after just a few shots and the use of slag is mandatory. Mandatory if you want to survive. In a game that allows for a massive CHOICE in firearms you are forced to play a mode that LIMITS CHOICE?! What utter contradictory madness is this? Even shields are made useless so there goes the great feeling of looting a nice shield.  However if you're willing to muck around a bit I have come up with a solution.  THE WORKAROUND  This review used to be thumbs down. Due to finding a work around in combination with how great the rest of the game is, it now gets a thumbs up.  So you're the average to low skilled player? UVHM has ruined your fun? Follow these steps for infinite TVHM play.  1. Make several 'mule' characters that function only as storage for loot 2. Store most of your level 50 loot with these mules. Keep one level 50 load outs worth of loot in storage on the character you wish to play TVHM with 3. Endure UVHM until you're at your level cap 4. Retrieve your level 50 loot from storage (so when you start TVHM you have access to gear that doesn't make you OP from the start) 5. Download and use a Borderlands 2 Save Editor and reset your TVHM progress 6. Use the level 50 loot you have stored away for the duration of the game 7. When you complete TVHM again reset your progress 8. Repeat steps 1-7  Your skill points may go above level 50 but that won't affect the difficulty much. All that matters is that the loot you use against level 50-54 foes is level 50. This stops you becoming overpowered and thus able to enjoy True Vault Hunter Mode again.  I can confirm there is a save editor out there. It’s easy to find. You can't get a VAC ban as this is not a VAC enabled game, so don't worry about using it. I don't condone the use of a save editor to cheat, only to give the TVHM option that should not have been excluded in the first place.

One of the most fantastic FPS games I've played! Its cartoon graphics are really amazing, which only helps to make this game unique!  While Skyrim, in my opinion, is the best RPG that incorporates FPS elements, Borderlands is the best FPS with RPG characteristics (XP, leveling, skills, items with numerical attributes). The game is really huge, specially considering the optional quests and the DLCs, that are surprisingly enormous! It is a kind of Far Cry, but much more exciting and miscellaneous!  You can experience 6 different character classes (in GOTY edition) and in 2 different game modes: single and cooperative multiplayer. The first one is more slow and technical, in which you'll need to search better ways to defeat the enemies, since having your health depleted is quite a problem; while the second one is faster and insane! As more users join the game, more 'run into the action and fire, fire, fire!' the game will be - you'll need to exit from your cover at least to help fallen friends in order to avoid their deaths! The cooperative mechanism of the game is awesome! The best part is that it is possible to use the same characters (a.k.a. vault-hunters) in either single or cooperative game. The unique annoying aspect, for me, is the excessive looting and the need of farming during all the time, searching for better items. It reminds me of Diablo a lot, that is a game completely dependent on farming, what displeases me after some game playing. The game is too cheap (with sales up to 80% off sometimes during the year) for the fun it is able to grant. One of the best aquisitions I've made. I'll buy the Borderlands Pre-Sequel in a near future, for sure! But, for while, I want to explore deeper what Borderlands 2 has to offer! After finish the game with a character, you'll have the possibility of replay it in hardest difficulties to keep your vault-hunter evolving. Almost infinite joy!

Like co-op? If you're looking for a friendly, community game to play with others, this game is exceptional and unbeatable. It's also the best way possible to introduce someone to first person shooters that perhaps has not been a gamer in the past (in this case, my wife). Usually co-op is an afterthought, or not thought of at all. Co-op is the primary focus of this game, and has been absolutely perfected. Borderlands 1 was excellent, and the best co-op to date. Borderlands 2 fixes anything and everything that you didn't even realize you missed in 1, and for an experience that is extremely fun for all, easy to join or host, productive on both fronts, and endless fun. The non-stop add-on content they keep throwing out is great, lots of contests, as well as virtually unlimited loot combinations to make it always worth your while to keep playing. This has trumped all of my old favorites that are not even the same genre (I typically hate FPS since I can't compete with those that play 24/7/365 and don't have things like a job or responsibilities). I can't recommend this game enough, you won't be sorry!

The best way to describe the Borderlands series is a epic adventure full of snarky comedy, decent plot, and many many shiny guns. As far as gameplay goes, the variety of characters and build trees lead to many types of character builds to satisfy whatever you feel like playing, and the added bonus of resetting your skills for a miniscule charge is great when you want to change skill trees rather than characters.  The only negative thing I noticed was how annoying it was to level other characters after I had finished the main quest. When you jumping around as a level 50ish Zero, a level 2 Maya isn't that fun. Fortunately, friends can help you farm bosses to speed up the process a bit.  Definitely a must have with friends, and a great buy if you're a loner.

Overall this game is a must-have for most anyone who enjoy FPS's with some RPG elements thrown in.

RAAAAIIID BOOOOSSSSS!!! Those two words still echo in my ear. The comedic factor of this game is off the charts (two words: Butt Stallion). Excellent FPS with RPG in a very wide, replayable environment. Absolutely love the different characters to play and the NPC interaction is hilarious too. I could not get enough of this game, and the fact that the end boss is taunting you throughout the entire gameplay experience and is a total jerkoff makes the desire to kill him heat up through your entire being as you proceed.

An infusion between a standard RPG and FPS. Storytelling and environments are varied and interesting, though it might try too hard to be funny at times. Normal and TVHM difficulty are trivial but UVHM will give you a run for your money, especially if you have the upgrade packs installed and the OP levels unlocked. Unfortunately, UVHM turns everyone into massive bullet sponges and makes certain skill builds completely obsolete. Rare and unique weapon drops are also incredibly satisfying, especially if you get an item with the best possible parts.

If you include the DLCs, it's a great game with potentially hundreds of hours of entertainment value. The basic mechanics of shooting stuff for loot feels good enough that I have no problems with keeping on playing long after the story is complete, just to go farm some more rare gear. It's got a good story with interesting character designs, and a very extended end-game if you're into that sort of thing. Overall, a solid game.

If youve played B1 you know what to expect in B2. Obviously the main selling point is those bazillion guns, and they dont disappoint. The different zooms, mag sizes, reload speeds, elemental damages and other features give each weapon its own tactical feel. Theres also a pleasing variety of enemies to shoot. The story is vastly improved compared to B1, and includes a strong antagonist in Handsome Jack. I really grew to hate him, which is a tribute to the quality of the writing and voice acting. I also laughed several times at the wacky sense of humour throughout the game. Theres easily above 40 hours of content including side quests and I encountered no significant bugs. There are minor negative points. Vehicle combat still sucks but fortunately it can be avoided for most of the game. The checkpoint only save system doesn't fit the huge maps. And occasionally characters will talk during the shooting. But overall, B2 is an outstanding game, and a strong contender for my top 5 GOTY.

Borderlands 2 is a worthy successor. Fans of the original will enjoy that the game retains the franchise’s bombastic play and irreverent humor. The game’s varied environments range from familiar deserts, frozen tundra, and haunted swamps. The multiplayer interface is significantly improved for PC users. Critics would be valid in pointing out that the game takes few chances and changes little from Borderlands 1. I have played this game for over 80 hours and recommend this buy.

The last time anything this good dropped WW2 started   Aw Borderlands 2, a great rpg and fps game mix. Both of my favorite genres in gaming, Borderlands 2 is a fun and great game that runs like a well oiled machine that keeps chugging with new content no matter how many hours I've pured into it. I orignally came across Borderlands 2 on the Xbox 360 and immediately became attached to this game, so much that after spending close to 110+ hours with three normal and true vault hunter modes completed, I had to purchase it again on the pc and glad I did with the addtional 160+ hours invested (,most of which were offline and not recorded) I'm still finding new content and weapons to enjoy. So much so, that I've alreasy maxed my current level 56 siren inventory and bank with level 50+ weapons for my ultimate run if I decide to do so, with over 100 golden keys to spare. In short, if looking for a great singleplayer or coop with friends or be randomly joined with other players then Borderlands 2 is that game. The gameplay is superb, the story is well written and progress in a very solid pace, the backstory of Borderlands 1 is clear and precise and you feel like you can make a difference on Pandora.   Borderlands is my favorite fps, out performing Halo. While Halo gets a 97 out of 100. Borderlands as a whole gets a 100 out of 100. I applaude Gearbox for a superb game that takes what the original did and make it five to ten times better in almost every way. Borderlands 2 gets a 10 out of 10. Prepare yourself for the commencment of funtime mayhem solo or with friends in the end, it is worth the ride and one to remember for years to come. Borderlands 2, the single most fun game I have ever played. This game doesn't have the best plot, best controls, best graphics, best characters, or best jokes. What this game has is fun. Though nothing it does is the best individually it makes up the best game ever at just being fun. The game is funny, and serious, it has moments that will make you laugh out loud, and moments that will melt your heart, often these moments are seconds apart, and then claptrap will say something to ruin everything. The multiplayer is seamless and works very well. All in all, probably my favorite game of all time. Every game mechanic is made to give the player more entertainment. The fight for your life system makes the game hard to die in yet difficult to live in. The skill tree gives each class bonuses, but allows psychos to be good snipers, snipers to wield good shotguns, and sirens to wield bazookas. Each class provides a entirely different combat experience, and each DLC is worthy of its own game. Besides, what other game is there that allows you to be the faithful minion of the single most annoying robot in history?

It's a decent shoot and loot, not as enjoyable as the first game in terms of gameplay, however, Borderlands 2 has a much better story and more interesting characters. Personally, I think the level design is much more monotonous so while the replayability is fairly high, it's not enjoyable seeing the same landscape/environment more than once. I've noticed that the loot system isn't as interesting or randomised anymore either, there's only a set amount of legendary gear you can obtain whereas in the first Borderlands, every single legendary had random stats and a randomised name.  The DLC in Borderlands 2 is quite fun, each DLC is more developed and has a more interesting quest/storyline which interesting new characters in each one. my personal favourite was Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep because it incorporated so many RPG and Dungeon Crawling stereotypes and elements which made it funny and also interesting to play.  In my opinion, if you loved the first game for what it was and have high expectations, Borderlands 2 (preferably GOTY edition) is only worth purchasing on sale.   Rating: 8/10
