At hour 117, I died by a legion of dwarf wizards.  10 | 10  Now, for WORDS.  This game is unlike any I have every played before. It's hard, fun, engaging, funny, satirical, progressive, and extraverted. First off, this game is not meant to be some serious 'masterpiece', and it doesn't act like it is. Although, I think it's pretty damn near flawless.    Pros:  + Enemy levels scale  well with character progression (on 'True Valut Hunter Mode', levels scale one to two levels above your own, which in turn, gives you tons of xp) + Character progression  is well balanced (can fully level out two of the three skill trees [if DLC has been bought] giving you the 'major ability' of two widly different trees) + Gives ample character choices  for the player (you got a Sniper who can go invisible, you got a tank who can dual weild weapons, a soldier who can plop down a turret (or two!), a 'magic' babe who can render even the hardest enemies useless (by entrapping them inside a sphere of awesome), a pyscho who loves fires (and meat!), and a 'engineer'-type girl who ams best friend with a Mech) + Fair challenge  with various levels of hardship (from downright easy to unforgiving) + Weapons  are an abundance with a variety of special effects + Humor  (I find this game funnier than a lot of other games and even TV shows. It's very unconvential and not 'politically correct', for lack of a better word) + There are enemies named  'Enraged Midget Goliaths', 'Suicide Skeletons', 'Badass Knights', 'Partially Digested Head Hunters', and 'Anchorman'. They are all as awesome as they sound.  + Sound effects  are stellar (never get tired of hearing a Goliath yell 'GET ON YOUR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ KNEES FOR ME' in a very uneducated, slurrish yell. It's hard to describe, really) + Graphics (I was running this game on my laptop [Intel 3000 Graphics] on low and was running great, then I upgraded to a 780, and wow... this game runs beyond silky smooth, at even the most intense moments) + Easibilty  (I haven't played the original Borderlands, and walked into this game pretty much blind. It was very, very easy for me to get sucked in. Controls are great and fluid; I run a PS3 controller through a program and I am able to switch between controller and keyboard/mouse at anytime!) + Comfortability and Pacing  (This game doesn't force you to do anything. Hell, from levels 43 to 51, I did nothing but finish up side quests.) + DLC  (This is a pretty controversal pro, as some agrue it's just milking of a franchise/supports dev's to not sell a finish game, however I believe this game was finished, polished, and complete before DLC was an option. I'm not going to sit here and sell you on their DLC; you can [and I have], totally enjoy the game without it. I beat the game twice before I bought my first DLC! I recommend 'Tiny Tina's Assualt on Dragon Keep' the most, if you can only buy one DLC. The headhunters are pretty linear boss type locations, but for the price, are well worth it. The extra characters are great if your want to try out a new, unique build. The cosmetic items, are pretty much worthless, in my opinion. I don't see the point in buying a single helment for $.99) + Replayability  (YOU CAN CONTINUE PLAYING THIS GAME, EVEN AFTER YOU BEAT IT. Sorry for the yelling, but damn, don't you just hate it when you're playing an RPG and at the end of the game, right when you get the most sweet of gear after killing the most henious of bosses, the game is over? Well with this game, it actually encourages you to farm the end boss [for he rewards the deligient], and you can swap through difficulty's anytime, and continue their individual stories.) + Co-op  + Group Raids  (Took me four and a half hours to kill one of them [Pyrocaustic Pete the Invincible], on my own. Wasn't worth it, for the loot I got, but with a couple of buddies, I could see it being great fun)    Cons:  - Farming  (This game does kind of get to be a bit of a drag when you're at the higher levels of the game) - Spawning  (When you get injured enough, you don't die. You go into a state called 'Second Wind', in which you are able to fight for your life. Get a kill in this state and you'll be revived a percent of life back. Don't get a kill, and you die. You'll end up at the closest checkpoint with a percentage of money gone, and you'll have to fight all those enemies, again. I actually kind of like that, because then 'hey, that's twice the xp for me', but then again, you could be going through the most vicious cycle. [Pro Tip: If you're in 'Second Wind' and want to keep all your money, simply pause the game and exit and load back in. You keep the xp, gear, and money too]) - Frustration  of getting one hit by certain bosses (be careful of Tremors, that is all I can say) - Inability to customize weapones  (This game doesn't allow you to customize your favorite weapons, not even a little. Instead, it depends on the game giving you them: customized weapons. I really wish this was a thing, because, as a Zero main, I would love to deck out a sniper of my own, putting tons of upgrades into it. Instead, I am left having to farm bosses for hours upon hours to even get a 'percentage chance' of a drop of an awesome weapon.) - Money is pretty useless  (The only things you can spend money on is weapons, ammo, shields, and the occasional cosmetic item. This is pretty pointless as nearly every thing you shoot at drops weapons, ammo, shields, and the occasional cosmetic item. When you die, the game takes a percentage of your wealth [about 10%-20% depending of difficutly, I think], and that's about it. If there were some kind of shop where a user can customize their favorite weapons, money would have some value, but as of now, I don't believe it merits much) - Favorite weapon loss  (I have no idea how to title this one but use adjectives to describe it. The jist of it is, and it ties in with my past two con claims, that once you find that really awesome sniper rifle/shotgun/grenade/etc., it will become useless in a matter of a few levels. It will get replaced with a new 'favorite', however, sometimes it's not as a good. For example: At level 33 I had this awesome level 33 sniper that triple shot caustic [acid] rounds towards the enemy. It had a decent mag size of about 15, and laid to waste most everything in my way. For this reason, this was my 'go to weapon' whenever I was in a jam. About four levels later, that level 33 sniper was utterly garbage. Now, I had to find a new favorite weapon, and it just felt forced. I would much rather keep one gun, add my own self into it [with upgrades, etc.], than to have to rely on what the enemies/shops drop) - Drop Percentages  (Just because you've been farming The Warrior for eight hours doesn't mean you're going to get that legendary weapon drop. For the reason of spotty, non-cumlative, drop chances, I think it's a hinderance. Sure, I could just as easily agrue that by having low drop chances, the integrity of those 'ultra mega rare' weapons are saved; however, I don't think people should have to farm for hours upon hours and still end up with nothing) - Workshop Support  (A game like this, would be most legendary if Steam Workshop was implemented [custom missions, locations, weapons, bosses, suits, helments, characters, abilities, vehicles, etc.], however, that is not the case)  And that pretty much wraps it up. A fun casual, hardcore, game for everyone who loves blowing stuff up with style.   This is my first review, so sorry for the length. Also, feel free to message me if you have any questions. I'm not an expert or anything, but I do genuinely love this game.

I guess that after nearly 200 hrs in this game (currently 193 hrs) I am now able to write a decent review. So here ya go  So - what is Borderlands? Is it an RPG? Is it an FPS? It's combining both in a, in my opinion, perfect matchup.  I love this game. The story is overall pretty nice and the DLC's are completely awesome. Tbh I've never seen DLC's that are worth it's price such as Borderlands' ones.  The classes:     Zer0 | The Assassin: Zer0 is an overall awesome character/class to play and it fits with the playstyles of nearly every person. You can play him with Shotgun-, Pistol-, Sniperrifle-, Aussaultrifle-, SMG- and Meleebuild or just go for a Kunai build and use what ever weapon you want to play with. And you can get invisible, I mean, who doesn't want that? With Zer0 you have someone who can be played for fun as well as for serious business. Added to that he looks awesome and is mysterious, so he would be my first choice even if I were new to the game ayy.      Maya | The Siren: The Siren WAS the class for everyone who wants to support his teammates in an online game. Since the last patch you can play her better in solo games too because she got a DMG-Buff. With Maya you can play with SMG's or Pistol's best and heal you or your teammates with you action skill 'Phaselock', which stuns the enemies and makes them more vulnerable. Your decisions how to skill her depent on the choice to play either solo or online. And she's pretty good looking. Hands down.      Salvador | The Gunzerker: The Gunzerker.. well.. you want to play a spanish/mexican/whatever little dwarf that is mostly screaming and shouting at you while you run through hordes of enemies wielding two weapons at once and destroying everything? You'll looove Salvador. No, for real, the Gunzerker is the class for everyone who wants to make DMG in the game. Want to play a Rocket Launcher and a Sniperrifle at once? No problem.       Axton | The Soldier: The Soldier is the class for Newbies. He is not hard to skill and to play and can use most of the weapons pretty decent. Your action skill is a turret you throw into enemies and it's autoaiming at them, so, as I said, I'd recommend Axton if you just started to play or do not have many FPS experiences. I don't know what to add to that, sorry.      Krieg | The Psycho (DLC Class): You love Melee-DMG? You want to breathe fire? You want to throw axes at enemies and letting them explode in a wave of fireballs while your teammates can damage you to make you even stronger? The Psycho is your class! The Psycho is basically skilled on melee- and firedmg and can be used to 'tank' the enemies, because your action skill makes you going crazy, returning to full health and splattering the enemies with axes. You should play fire-based weapons with, but be carefull, there is a chance to set yourself on fire and still getting some profit from that.  And *SPOILER*   Krieg is the father of tiny Tina, a little disturbed girl living in the Tundra Express        Gaige | The Mechromancer (DLC Class): Gaige uses here skill to make bonus DMG if not reloading. Her squishyness and overall complicated playstyle make her not easy to use for beginners. She's an awesome class, no doubt, but hard to play if you don't exactly know how. I guess that's all I gotta say to her.   Now some Pro's and Con's.  Pro's:     LONG playtime, if you really are into the game     Godlike DLC's     Nice cel shading graphics     Pretty much endless list of weapons     Pretty much endless list of using your skills     The whole skill-system     Badass lvl's that do give you more power     Awesome written characters     A nice, open ending story     Pixelwalks and glitches that can be used in your interest     Lilith ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)  Con's:     Claptrap (start the game and you'll know what I mean)     Some annoying enemies     The vehicles (I personally like them but there are a LOT of guys out there that can't drive them properely)     Sometimes just really dumb AI    The normal maxlevel in this game is lvl 50, but if you buy the Ultimate Vault Hunter Upgrade Pack 1 & 2, you will get to lvl 72. It's not neccessary, but if you want to get to the OP-levels, you'll have to buy them. The OP-levels basically are a way to make the game interesting after reaching lvl 72. There are 8 OP-levels and with each one your enemies are getting stronger and stronger, up to being lvl 90 while you still are lvl 72. You'll find a*s-destroying weapons that will help you to not just go in the fight and die all the time.  I would recommend this game to nearly every type of gamer. I hope this helped and that you will enjoy the game as much as I still do. :)

Welcome to Pandora, kiddos!  Now that we're back on Pandora, four new Vault Hunters have decided to join in on the phsycotic adventure.   Zero, The Assassin - Like Mordicai, great with sniping and pistols. But has the skill to turn invisible for 5 seconds and score a hit dealing up to 200 - 300 percent more damage!  Maya, The Siren - A Siren like Lilith. She can phaselock eneimes to render them defenceless and let the team blast away at them. Definetly the support class, with healing skills.  Salvador, The Gunzerker - Um, well, kill? Can use the skill to pull out two weapons at once....nothing more to say.  Axton, The Comando - Can deploy a Sabre Turret, like Roland, but slightly less powerful. Skills focus on accuracy, ammo, and assault rifles. For the more aggressive players.  There are two DLC characters, Kreig, and Gaige, but you'll just have to learn about then yourself. This game....is well, AWESOME. I can't explain the whole game other than this:  Kill, Explode, Loot, Kill. Crazy, Explode, Guns, Kill, Blood, Explode.  That's right. Three kills, and eplodes.  The storyline is great, I won't spoil it though.  One of my favorites.  What? You haven't bought it yet?!  Do it! Now!  Go one and buy the game of the year edition while you're at it! It's worth it!  GO!  15/10       That's right, fifteen.

First of all, I humblely want to thank two special people who got me into this game in the first place, to explore what good yet humorous of a game this has made to be!  The gameplay and graphics is extremely fluid after its prequel giving the user a better way to enjoy the hell out of this. The weapons system in the game are quite intuitive with its elemental scheme with a strategic sensibility on what enemies weak points are along with having just funny, creative names. I especially love the 8+ level OP gear that you get after a certain mission of the game if you're looking to REALLY be the true Vault Hunter.  For the humor....what can I say? Handsome Jack, Claptrap, Steven, and so many to name just few more are truly memorable for their funny antics and the way how both good and very evil it is. Jack is far by the most funniest, given that he is the main villain of the game, in the entire series. In the Pre-Sequel probably not as much and it'll be one of the reasons to come back to the second for that. Can't forget about Mister Torgue......BECAUSE REASONS! Not gonna spoil it, but it's worth listening and watching!  As for the story itself, I take it as it is and leave it at that. From beginning to end. Do want to see what will happen in the next sequel!  Overall, this game is worthy of its merits and up until now it's still enjoyable and lovable. If this was a movie I'd pay to go see it for sure! This game is absolutely fantastic. It's a pure example of how to make a game properly. This was one of the first steam games i got, and defintely the the most memorable. From the combat, to the loot system, to the environment, EVEN the DLC's, this game ticks all the right boxes. Let's talk about DLC's. DLC's in this game aren't overpriced. The amount of content you get in any DLC (maybe not the headhunters) is fantastic. After a while the base game does get boring to play and the DLC's are a breath of fresh air. They're just good. Also, easter eggs. Easter eggs are one of the coolest things in any video game, as they shine a new light on the game as a whole in the gaming industry. The enemies are awesome, the fact their difficulties vary and they can upgrade their difficulties is brilliant. I sound like such a fanboy right now. Also, WHAT A GREAT COMMUNITY. Seriously, 95% of the people you will play with be incredibly helpful and kind. It's just-t-t-t great. Honestly, this sounds all dreamy, doesn't it? Buy it and then you will fully understand.  Also, there is a mission where someone WANTS you to blow their face off. And just for that 10/10. GOTY- oh wait...

Borderlands 2 is an Open-world 4 player co-op, First Person Shooter RPG Developed by Gearbox software; Borderlands being the only reason to why they're still allowed to make games lol  Borderlands 2 has a nice comic art-style touch to it, it can run smoothly on Ultra, with only a few lagspikes here and there but they happen so rarely, that you barely even notice them.  The game has a very great story, unlike the first one. Heck, it's one of the very few games, that doesn't make you have to play the first one.  If you've seen the trailer(s), which you most likely have there's always a caption saying 'Bazillion of guns' which is right, but overexaggerated. The game has in total: 110,000+ different kinds of guns, with different variants and 8 weapon manufacturers. Which is mind-blowing. Finding the same gun twice is very rare.  Borderlands 2's amount of enemies is ridicolous, everything wants to kill you. Literally. Like, Bandits, The Hyperion Corporation, or just Pandora's wildlife. Enemies interact with each others, quite so often, that's it at the point of getting hillarious.  The soundtrack for this game is just amazing, especially with the 4 DLC campaigns. All 4 bringing amazing soundtracks.  My ONLY flaw with this game, is the Multiplayer. This is a flaw, that everybody agrees with. Whenever you play in a public game, you'll most likely end up with a greedy jackass. Picture this scenario: You snd your ally kills a boss, for instances. Chances are, your ally WILL rush to the one unique weapon that the boss dropped. See, this is the type of people that ruins the experience for everyone. Why can't there be one for each player? Trades can still happen, with these unique items, and everyone likes to use unique items.   Pros: • Cool story • Great Enemy AI • Hilarious Dialogue • Has the greatest villain ever. • Soundtrack • Weapon randomizer system.  Cons: • Greedy players.  But i recommend it. A lot, be sure to have somebody to play with you, or else the game is gonna be.. Quiet boring. 2-4 friends is what i'd recommend.  So yeah, go buy the game or something. Idk.

My husband bought this game for me several months ago, and I, not usually a fan of shooter games was immediately enthralled. The fun, the humor, the time that the creators of this game obviously put into it had me hooked, and I still find new things and immensely enjoy this game. While I usually play solo, I have met some other amazing players who have taught me loads about strategy, and because of this game I now enjoy a few other shooter games as well. I would recommend getting Borderlands first though. I started here and then went back to the original game and have discovered so much content that originated in that first game that would have helped my understanding of characters and places had I started at the beginning. If you like laughing as well as killing bad guys (I feel like a bad guy some of the time), then the Borderlands franchise is the game you cannot miss.

Now while I do reccomend this game (I have not played any DLC's though) I'm more interested in pointing out the negative things. I like the combat, I like the gameplay, I like the design, I like the story, I like the characters so there's not much to say there.   Edges & Invisible Walls Right, so to start it off there are some annoying ♥♥♥♥ing edges here and there that are quite annoying. I'm talking about a piece of ground that is about a decimeter in height which stops your character dead in his/her tracks. They aren't littering the place but they do occasionally happen and my god are they annoying when you just wanna run somewhere fast and your character gets stuck on a little thing for no good reason. And there are quite a lot of annoying invisible walls so if you want to think outside the box and jump around to get a better position think again because even if your character could realistically jump up on something an invisible wall will pop up going 'no, you aren't allowed to do that'.  Dead-stop when jumping forward agaisnt certain things. Another thing you'll come across, most often with invisible walls but sometimes during other things as well is that if you are mid-jump and hit something your character won't continue to increase in height but will instead stop dead in his/her tracks. This can be quite annoying at times.  Don't bother out of the box exploration. Because there's nothing there. You think that because you could potentially get up on a certain place that there's going to be something nifty up there? Well think again. Most of the time there is ♥♥♥♥ all and you might as well not bother. I got rewarded for exploring areas by jumping up on them seldom. And I might be looking back at BL1 with rose-tinted glasses but I'm certian that I remember that we 'were' rewarded for exploring hard to reach places.  Too many guns. There's too many loot chests and guns in regular containers and the spawn rate of rare stuff is far too rare. 999:1000 guns are useless to you and you end up tossing them away or selling them for money. But apart from the very very veeeeery few times that a store/vending machine has something worth buying there is bugger all to use the money on except for slot machines (and the slot machines have way too low of a chance for the good stuff, I never got an orange weapon and almost every single purple and blue weapon were garbage), which are good to farm Eridium for (You use Eridium to buy ammo/backpack/bank upgrades. I dunno, it feels like the developers wanted the players to be given weapons constantly but realized that it'd be too easy to farm really good stuff so we end up with waaaaay too many weapon chests and weapon drops and way too low of a drop rate for orange or half-way decent purple stuff.  The enemies are too dangerous and my weapons are too ♥♥♥♥. You might come to a point like I did when my weapons simply did not pack enough of a punch to deal with the enemies in a feasible and fun way to progress the storyline so guess what you gotta do? That's right, farm. And like I said in my previous post, most of the weapons will be garbage, no exceptions. I had to spend 9 hours grinding weapon chests, bosses for orange weapons (only to find out all but one were ♥♥♥♥) and playing slot machines before I had weapons that actually packed a decent punch. And that isn't fun. Not to me. I don't so much mind farming if there is something clear to farm for. But since most of the stuff in the game is based on random generation, well, you can't rely on farming one spot for something great. Only bosses are useful for it and it becomes real tedious to have to exit the entire game and start it up again to reset bosses to farm.  ♥♥♥♥ the enemies with physical steel shields. Just ♥♥♥♥ them, on New Game+ the badass variants will consume tons of explosives.  Moxxi stares at you. Like, she 'really' stares at you and it became unsettling for me to turn around from the slot machines to see if she still was gawking at me only to have her lean down on the counter staring right at me.   But yeah, the storyline is fun and interesting and has some nice plot twists. The characters are well-developed and interesting even if two of the previous game's cast are a bit forced into the game. The combat is fun and varied. The art-style is great. Like I said, I enjoyed the game. But it's far easier for me to fixate and go ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ over annoying and frustrating ♥♥♥♥ than it is for me to delve deeper into good aspects.  Oh and New Game+ seems kinda pointless to me. I mean, once you've played through the story and heard the humour there's nothing left to drive me forward. I already know how the plot is gonna go. I already know of most of the objectives. I already know about the jokes that are coming so they aren't as funny the 2nd time around. So why bother with NG+? To collect more weapons? Yeah, cause that doesn't sounds repetitive and boring. I guess I'll continue on my NG+ (which I left quite quickly after starting it) once I get the DLC's (when they're on sale) so I can enjoy them.

I don't feel like writing an actual review so here's a recipe for marinated pork chops:  1. Mix water, soy sauce, vegetable oil, lemon pepper seasoning, and minced garlic in a deep bowl; add pork chops and marinate in refrigerator at least 2 hours. 2. Preheat an outdoor grill for medium-high heat and lightly oil the grate. 3. Remove pork chops from the marinade and shake off excess. Discard the remaining marinade. 4. Cook the pork chops on the preheated grill until no longer pink in the center, 5 to 6 minutes per side. Diablo With Guns, that would be the best way to describe this game.  As a Single Player game it's not bad at all, the Story is Great, it's got a good Longevity to it, but the meat of the game is the Loot and the challenge that it offers. The game offers serevall classes and all of them can be modified to your liking, either be a Solo Hunter or a Party Healer and Buffer, it's your choice and the best part is that each class was it's own playstile and not just a simple change of main type of weapons.  The Game engine is well optimized (even with PhysX, it is one of the games that best uses it and with the least impact on performance), and the Online is Great, unlike the first Borderlands, the second one deals much better with your progress in a Single Player Game and your progress with a Co Op Game (let's say you finish a quest in Co Op that you did not even got near in Single Player... when you unlock said quest, or quests, in your Single Player, the game will go 'oh hey! You already done that Online, want to skip that?').  Most of the DLC are worth it but... if you need to choose, as for story driven DLC... Tiny Tinas is the best one!  As for the DLC classes, well... it's a matter of playstile, I can't help you with that, the Mechnonancer is a pet focused class and the Psycho is a Melee class.  Overall, it's a good Single Player game and a Great Co-Op Game, one of the best in that regard.

Borderlands 2 is basically a fresh new borderlands with more pleasant graphics and other miscellaneous upgrades to make the game more hands on (Like Bl1 is dota 2 and bl2 is League of Legends).  Pros - Fun as hell in co-op. -LOOT! (If diablo was the ♥♥♥♥ when you were a young teen, you will love this aspect). -Unique characters with different personalities, and many can be humorous at times. -Interesting storyline. -Side Missions for DAYS -All the DLC is worth it (Except the cosmetic items) -References to other media is prevalent and plentiful. -Endless replay value. - Fast paced -it is an FPS but also and RPG and it feels like one too. -4 Unique playable characters with different roles in co-op, and 2 more for DLC -Most bosses are an adrenaline rush and fun     Cons -Grinding can be tedious -Some quests are insultingly easy(However some are meant to be like that, ie, shoot this guy in the face) -Other quests are horrifyingly difficult -Some things you can use are totally unbalanced. -Single player is much less enjoyable; Get a friend this game too if nobody has it :) -Boss fights can be lazy at times. -You will find yourself underleveled a lot, meaning you need to grind for ages -Graphics are unpleasant if you need to turn them down.   Overall, I definetly recommend this game for fans of games like Quake and Diablo. It definetly acknowledges the incredible things you can do with the loot system. Buy this game!

Borderlands is one of those game series that you'll get a lot of different a opinions on. Some people love it, some people hate it. Some people really want to like it, but they can't force themselves to. For me, it's a near-perfect game with some extremely frustrating elements.   To break it down into simple terms, I love the art style, the characters, and the satirical direction Gearbox went with it. Claptrap is funny to me, even if he is the JarJar Binks of video games, your silent protagonist is always spoken to directly, but seems to be peripheral to the whole thing. You are, after all meant to be that character.   The special powers are fun and combat is a blast. No matter how many times you die, you can always retry failed missions and just respawn. This is normal, but it's stlil pretty cool in this game because they do give you a penalty for it. You have to pay some money. The more money you have, the more money they take. This is what motivates you to not die, but you will die a lot. Even still, it's a game that Gearbox obviously wants you to win.   My playtime isn't a joke, it's literally 50 hours of me being obsessive. If you have been accurately diagnosed with obsessive compulsive disorder by a physician, it's probably not the type of game you want to play. My only major complaints are usually the same complaints I have with games - the soundtrack is cool for a little while, but it grows really tired after just an hour or so. Maybe I'm unique in this, but a full soundtrack is maybe 2 hours of music, and I fail to see how Gearbox couldn't afford someone to compose thise considering game music creators are a dime a dozen. If they put real money into that, it's a waste.   However, the voice acting is near-flawless and some of what they say is hilarious, most of it being just chuckleworthy. There are parts that will have you running in circles that make the game feel a bit repetitive, to a degree. But that's not a totally bad thing with Borderlands 2, because you'll always be picking up some neat loot and weapons.   One thing you'll never have to actually buy is weapons, but sometimes the 'daily specials' at the vending machines are pretty good, so make sure you check them out. The mini games and joke missions are also enjoyable, and they cause you to sympathize with some of the characters even while there's a lot of humor behind their destruction or self-loathing.   The DLC thing is divisive. I did buy all the DLC's for content, and I personally think they were worth it.   In short, you'll get out of this game exactly what you put into it. It can take you 8 hours, or it can take you 800 hours. I don't think you'll find any shortage of real gameplay here.   8.5/10

Uh Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead  Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg 2 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed  Now to make it 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla. 3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. 4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed 5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed. 6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

I don't know what to say about this game, so here is a recipe for pancakes,   Ingredients:  4tbsp plain flour (about 100g) 1 large free range egg ½ pint semi-skimmed milk + water (about 300ml - ¾ milk ¼ water) Pinch of salt Butter for frying How to make pancakes: Sieve the flour and salt into a large bowl and make a well in the mixture.  Break in the egg and stir to make a breadcrumby mix.  In a jug add 1/3 of a pint of milk and top up with water to make 1/2 a pint (200ml milk, 100ml water) - this makes a lovely light batter.  Add the milk and the water mix bit by bit, beating constantly to avoid lumps.  Tip:*If you have a food processor just throw all the ingredients in and zap until smooth!  Pop a large frying pan over a medium heat.  Add a large knob of butter (roughly 50g) and melt.  Pour the excess butter into a small bowl and reserve it for later.  Using a ladle pour a spoonful of the pancake batter into the hot pan and swirl to get a full covering - cook for about 1 min each side (it's ready when it's easy to flip over).  Serve immediately with sugar and lemon or other exciting toppings. We love cheese and Marmite for an extra British twist! Delicious!!

Borderlands 2 has to be one of my all time favorite games. It is affordable (when on sale) and is a lot more fun than many other games on the market. I would highly reccomend this game to anyone who likes video games because of how long you can play it without becoming tired of it, and just because of how fun it really is.  Play with up to 4 friends at any given time as you go through the story mode which is very detailed and has many missions to complete to earn in-game currency, weapons, and exp to level up your charecter to become even stronger than you were before. The fun never ends with 3 game modes, with the loot becoming increasingly better, aswell as the difficulty increasingeach time. The graphics arn't bad for being a couple years old, and the weapons look very cool. There is no thing I really like more than the other in Borderlands 2. The story mode is very fun, earning cool weapons and raiding places for loot is also fun. There is just so much to do, which makes it easy to keep playing without getting bored, especially if you have a short attention span like me.  If you havn't got Borderlands 2 already, you are missing out. You can get it on sale for 5$, or sometimes even cheaper on other sites. If you are going to buy Borderlands 2, I would reccomend buying the GOTY Edition because of all the DLC which makes the game even more fun and interesting, although the game is still very fun without DLC.   *WARNING SPOILERS AHEAD*  The game starts out when you wake up as a vault hunter in the snow with a robot named Claptrap, who will guide you through the game. Vault hunters are very rare, and their mission is to stop Handsome Jack (the main villan in the story). Handsome Jack hates vault hunters and will kill them whenever he has the chance. You soon start to gather some weapons, ammo, a shield, and more. Across the planet of Pandora (the planet everyone is living on) there are Bandits, which will try to kill when when they have the chance. Killing enemys such as bandits will reward you with exp, to help level up your charecter, which will give you more health, and access to more weapons (weapons will require a minimum level to use).The higher level the enemy, the more exp and loot given. Enemys also drops things like weapons too, aswell as health packs to help replenish your health. All around there are chests, some containing better loot than others. These chests contain ammo, guns, health, shields, grenades, certain class mods, relics, and more. Once you start getting better you will face harder enemys, and some bosses here and there. Eventually, you get to Santuary, a town of people who all hate Handsome Jack. You will join the Crimson Raiders, a team trying to take Handsome Jack out. You are assigned to do more missions there. Roland is the leader of the Crimson Raiders. Soon you meet Lilith, Roland's ex, who helps you rescue Roland who has been captured by bandits. Roland and you will become friends, but soon some bad news comes in from Roland's spy, Mordacai. He finds out that Handome Jack has been charging a vault warrior with eridium (an ancient alien rock). This vault warrior will obey its awakener, which Jack hopes to become. If Jack gets ahold of this warrior, he could use it to take anyone who he wanted out, which would be you. In the end, you are about to kill Jack, but before you do, he manages to awaken the warrior. You will have to kill the warrior as your last mission, and let me tell you that is not the easiest thing to do. If you defeat the warrior, you will be able to kill Jack, and save everyone from his evil ways. Once you finish the story mode, you will be able to go to the next mode where you do the story all over again with harder dificulty and better loot.  Overall, Borderlands 2 is too complex of a game to fully cover in one review, but I tried to give you as much information as possible. If you havn't bought Borderlands 2 already, what are you doing? Just buy it. It is worth every penny ;)

Borderlands 2™ is a classic puzzle game developed in the long past year of 120 AD by Rareware™. It brings the return of many of their most popular and well revered characters, such as, Pac-Man, Waluigi, Pikachu, and Knuckles. Originally planned to be a sequel to the popular Super Mario RPG: Legend of the Seven Stars™ they ended up using the same concept and battle style, but with a whole new look. The game you now all know as Borderlands 3 & Knuckles™ has a long history which requires a lot of research to discover. Rareware™ is now developing their latest game Team Fortress 7™ and Sonic Colors 3D World™.

Borderlands 2 is a FPS, in which you are a vault hunter, hunting for, well, the Vault. This game adds great graphics and humor to make a great game.  Borderlands 2 is set on a planet called Pandora. You get the option between four different characters, with two extra added in the DLC for the game. Your goal is to stop Handsome Jack and the Hyperions from opening the Vault, which is an alien vault containing the Warrior, a god-like alien being. There are many side quests along the way, and the game makes you constantly level up, which is a great thing to do.  Overall, this game is fantastic. Even after you beat the game one time, you can go back and do it AGAIN in True Vault Hunter Mode, where you keep all your weapons and levels, but you start the game over, and the lowest level, is 30. This game is great, and I recommend it to anyone who doesn't mind a little dirty jokes and cursing. I am 12, and I LOVE this game, and I know you will too.

Borderlands is a multiplayer RPG/FPS game. By far, the best RPG you will ever play (FPS is just an added bonus). Buy this game with all the DLC's, especially Tiny Tina's. Make new friends, find the character that represents you, and show how OP you can be. Also, read the guides for your character to develop them further. There's still plenty of gamers in the community.   Note: I will say that my comp specs were not up to spec for playing this game, but adjust your resolution and turning off ShaderEngine will help you immensely.

Gameplay 9/10- Playing with either a keyboard and mouse or controller feel great. Gun play is very nice and the different guns do feel different from each other. The only downside is sometimes the AI can be a bit stupid and that can ruin the fun for that small fight.  Story 8/10- It's nothing super complicated but the game does have a decent story, involving the characters you play as in the first game. The best part of the writing in the game really shines through in the humor of it all. No matter what mission you're on the game will find a way to sneak in a joke or two.  Music 5/10- For a good chunk of the game there is no music playing and when it does its kinda boring and not very memorable. There are a few tracks I liked, but for them most part it was boring to listen to.  Overall- If you're looking for a fun FPS that you can play co-op with your friends, or heck random people this game will be right up your ally.

This is my review for Borderlands 2. I want to cover the game first on its value to the consumer, which I will rate the vanilla (without DLC) experience vs. the full DLC filled game. I will then explain my own thoughts on both underneath the unbiased value of each respective part.  Borderlands 2 is primarily a shooter, with RPG elements and a Diablo-esque loot system comprised of many types of loot to aquire. It can be played in co-op and has a lot of content to play. It is varied in humor and with gore, but if that doesn't turn you off then continue.  Vanilla Borderlands 2:  Consumer Value: 7/10. Alot of story content and alot of sidequests, not much replayability. Two bosses for end game content isn't that great, but both can put up a decent challenge to someone entering this kind of game for the first time.  My Thoughts: About the same, not much to do once you beat the story. Unless you wanna play through every character and min/max them.  Borderlands 2 GOTY:  Consumer Value: 9.5/10 Alot more content, most of it is worth the players time and can be enjoyable with co-op or without. Tons of End-game bosses to defeat could leave the player more satisfied with their purchase. Includes 2 interesting characters added and a higher level cap to make it a stronger game for those seeking value from their purchase.  My thoughts: Its good, get it already. It can be hard, but thats what friends are for right?  I hope I somewhat helped if you somehow haven't played this and are deciding to buy it.  What, you're still here? I hope you aren't thinking of NOT buying it, as I put SO much effort into a relatively short review. Anyway, buy it already. Diamond ponies and robot dubstep? References out the A**? Ok. Move on... I get it...

I recommend this game SO MUCH if you like FPS,RPG,exploration and open world genres.The game is cartoony,a nice break from the super realistic FPS games (looking at you medal of duty field).The characters are funny,interresting and unique with personality.The game's antagonist Handsome Jack is hands down one of the GREATEST video game villains.There are over 4 billion weapons in borderlands 2 alone,you can farm bosses for Legendary weapons (rarest) If you get tired of the game itself there are TONS of DLC to keep you entertained.  Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep:By far my favorite DLC,play through the tale of fantasy in a dungeons and dragons based medieval DLC campaign told by Tiny Tina.  Mr.Torgue's Campaign of Carnage:If you like explosions,muscles and outall manliness this DLC is for you :D.Enter the BADASS tournament to open the vault in the Badass Crater of Badassitude  Sir Hammerlock's Big Game Hunt:Ok this one is controversial but f**k it.Join Sir Hammerlock on his adventure through the savage jungles of Pandora and go head to head with Professor Nakayama trying to take the place of Handsome Jack.  Captain Scarlett and her Pirate's Bootey:Arrr maties!Set sail on an exciting journey,swashbuckling and loot!The beautiful scenary and levels,a pretty good (...controversial and overbloated) storyline to find Captain Blade's treasure.What are you waiting for landlubbers?  AND SO MANY HEADHUNTER PACKS! :D  No other game deserves the title Game of The Year more than Borderlands 2.It is my definetly and no other competitors just downright FAVORITE GAME OF THEM ALL :D.The game is so entertaining huge and just begs you to go exploring,encountering new foes and friends,guns and much much more!I recommend this game with all my heart and joy.Buy this game RIGHT NOW no questions asked :)

Are you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ me? I really have to write a review about this? God, alright.  The graphics, brilliant.  The writing, hilarious.  The story, gripping.  The DLC, jam-packed with content.  The vehicles, crisp and sharp with fluid controls.  The weapons, I can't even begin to cover them all because there's too ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ many, but all of them are brilliantly balanced.  The skills all feel like they have an actual effect on your performance.  The level cap of 72 (with both Ultimate Vault Hunter packs) is a huge allowance, allowing you to fill in two full skill trees, plus twelve points into the third.  The classes all have their uses, strengths, weaknesses, even personalities, not to mention stories tied with how they came to Pandora. Good luck finding the ECHOs related to them, though, they're scattered all over the place!  The characters are all great and deep, from the sexy Moxxi to Sir Glorious (Hammerlock to you plebians).  Seriously. You owe it to yourself to try this game. It may be a RAM hog at 1.1 to 1.4 gigabytes of memory used during runtime, but if you've got the machine, you need, and I mean NEED, to give this game a try. As well as its prequel.  What does the story entail? Well ♥♥♥♥ that, I'm not gonna tell you! Just know that it's full of plot twists, references to the last game, and still has so much new stuff to keep players both new to the series, and vets, entertained for hours.  Also, let's not forget the replayability, and raid bosses. ♥♥♥♥ing raid bosses.    Good luck getting Legendary items into all your slots; the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s are rare, but COMPLETELY worth it!  Rating: 9/10, because too many people say it's 10/10, and honestly, it is home to its own set of glitches. But what game isn't? This game, for what it is, is absolute perfection, and you should add it to your library and play the ♥♥♥♥ out of it.  Good hunting!  Recommend: VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY YES. With all the DLC excluding the costume packs (get 'em if you want, it's more money to Gearbox Studios!)

I recommend it definitely and without question. Borderlands 2 is one of the best, most enjoyable games I\'ve ever played in my life. If you\'re someone who likes FPS and loves humor (and some feels), Borderlands 2 is an excellent choice, for both begginers to experienced gamers. Heck, you may not even like FPS, or be good at it, but if you play with friends, you can still have hell of a great time!  ++ +The story is great  +The characters are huge dorks. You\'re gonna end up loving all of them whether you like it or not. +The gameplay is fluid and simple +The style is visually appealing. Gearbox has done an awesome good job with the visual design! +The DLCs are super fun too (Mr. Torgue\'s badass arena of badassitude is my favorite)  +This game is the first FPS where I tried the public matchmaking, and literally everyone I was paired with was super nice. I even made some new friends. But maybe that\'s just me...I hope not. +Totally worth the full price! But hey, get it on sale if you can. It\'s 4 years old already anyway...  -- -Since late 2014 BL2 has become pretty unstable. I noticed everything was fine until DirectX 10 settled for good. And then...Windows 10. I know I\'m not the only one in this situation. Some people with older specs (and Windows 7 or XP) can still play just fine though!  -Don\'t play it in french. Just don\'t. Trust me.  On a side note, I suggest you start with Borderlands 1, though I hear you have to use Hamachi or something similar to play with people now, because the game is...well, getting old. But it\'s still great!

In general a good shooter with plenty of loot, interesting enemies, comedic tone few other games achieve, visual style of its own, and tons of guns. However, nothing's perfect.  The gun-play is good but nothing amazing. The way enemies are turned into bullet sponges during coop is plain lazy design on the developer's part. The way loot drops is absolutely terrible in coop so if nobody loves you and for some reason you want to play with randoms, plan to race for loot.  There's plenty of extra dynamics and depth they could have added to this game but when you get down to it, this game feels like a mostly blank canvas with hints of a masterpiece scattered across it.  Simply, I lost interest after 36 hours a couple months ago. Humor alone can't justify playing a game that goes on for this long. I'll still recomend this game but only with the assumption you're either not a cynical ♥♥♥♥ like myself or actually have friends.

To be completely honest, i dont find this game to be that much fun anymore.  after it's original release on ps3 (when i got it) it was the best game ever.. and i mean EVER   Now there is more DLC content than normal. it sucks to see companies selling out like this. in my opinion they should just make the DLC free. i know this may cause trouble to the people that bought the dlc but to make it all fair they should just get some additional content. like a 'Supporter gun' or something like that.  the idea of the game being a mix between a FPS co-op RPG is so epic, and they did extend it to its fullest.  but after the many hours of playing this franchise i dont find it that fun anymore.  Now lets get into the real review here:  Pros:  Super fun first couple of days/weeks/months/years If your friends play this game it is the most fun game to play EVER nice graphics, funny gameplay and awesome characters Runs SOOO smoothly.. its insane  Cons:  Will take up all your day to play this game (You will get addicted) After you buy all of the dlc and complete everything (DLC and regular) it gets boring No friends = No fun If you play random co-op they will ninjaloot every single piece of rare items People will kick you for being nice to them, and or just trying to play with someone Alot of people back in the day modded BL2, so now they are max level and have everything if you get into a game with a modder/hacker you will have a bad time TRUST ME  There is alot of other cons but the game is worth it, IF and i cant stress this enough IF you are new to this series then what are you waiting for? try out the game and if you dont like it.. get a refund. Its a simplistic game with alot of features and overall an amazing game with stunning gameplay  my rating are the following:  Gameplay (First couple of months) 10/10 Characters 10/10 Graphics 8/10 Optimization 9/10 DLC 11/10 best DLC you will ever get  Amazing game overall 9/10 score for me.

There's nothing I can say about Borderlands 2 that hasn't already been said by better writers.  I don't know that I've ever been so completely enamored with any gaming world (and I've been a mildly obsessive gamer since Christmas of '85 when I received my NES). The eclectic cast of characters that populate Pandora, the phenomenal (and often hilarious) writing and voice acting that bring it all to life, the vibrant art style, varied enemy types, rock-solid shooting mechanics and endless pursuit of the best gear possible make Borderlands 2 my absolute favorite game of the past 10 years, and that's coming from someone who's generally not real big on shooters.  I cannot recommend Borderlands 2 highly enough.

Which by the way depending on your eyesight and what not, it gave me headaches if I played too long, so be mindful of that.   You don't really get invested in the characters all that much, they are amusing at times and some of the stuff they say, you don't really care what the bad guy did you just know he's a quest and he needs to die. I doubt I will invest in the prequel though unless I get it for less than $5 as I'm guessing it's will just be borderlands expansion number 3 for the original game, just as a prequel ;) If I want to play a borderlands game I'll just go back and play BL1/BL2.

Probably my favorite game of all. Why? To be honest, I don't know exactly why myself. Perhaps it's the well written story, full of jokes and interesting lore, and able to go from funny to serious at a moment's notice. Perhaps it's the different classes, with their own playstyles and diverse skill trees. From Axton the Commando, with his Turrets and focus on assault rifles. Or Zer0 the assassin, who wields invisibility and melee. Maybe it's the extremely diverse range of enemies and characters. Including insane bandits, wild alien creatures and murderous robots with selectively destructible limbs. Almost all of which are very satisfying to fight, sending damage numbers flying into the air. It could just be how fun it is to share the experience with friends, with the singleplayer experience still remaining just as fun on its own. Or it's quite possible it's just Handsome Jack. The best Villain I've seen in a game or movie.  Either way, Borderlands 2 is an extremely fun First Person Shooter. Numerous side quests will keep you busy long before you get near the end of the main story, and all the DLC (all included in a single purchase of the GOTY edition) extends this even further. Even Sir Hammerlock's Big Game Hunt, considered the weakest offering, presents you with a completely different environment and a few new enemies. The endgame content, with several highly difficult raid bosses to fight, Badass Challenges to complete and The Raid on Digistruct Peak as the ultimate goal. Once you've beaten all that, you can do it all again in True, then Ultimate Vault Hunter mode, with enemies scaling to and above your current level. While this may sound repetitive and boring, it somehow isn't. I've played through the game fully on both Console and PC around 4 times, yet I'm still enjoying myself just as much. The story is the same each time, but at the same time you'll be learning to play differently with new characters, finding better loot for your current character or adjusting your skill build, which manages to still keep things fresh (And the permanent bonuses from Badass ranks make the starting sequences that little bit easier each playthrough).  The game is criticised for its high amount of DLC, but the majority of it is just purely cosmetic items. Aside from those, the four story DLCs are all entertaining, with Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep being one of the best experiences in the game. The Headhunter DLCs, while not as long or as high quality as the main expansions still manage to entertain for a while, and The Raid on Digistruct Peak gives you an end goal to work to. All DLC, excluding the cosmetic packs, are included in the Game of the Year edition, which drops to nearly £4 every sale at this point. In fact, the entire borderlands collection drops to less than £10 every time too. For a price like that for so much content, there is no reason why you shouldn't give Borderlands 2 a try.

Savie out.

A solid game, well desigend and keeps the feel of the original. For the replayability alone this game is worth the price, but get the Game of the Year edition, as it contains all the DLCs you really need, with the rest being the Headhunter packs and a bunch of heads/skins for the 6 different characters which you really don't need (but get a few if you're so inclined). The only downside is that to truly max out your character, Overpower levels aside, you're going to have to play the main campaign 3 times per character as each of the 3 play modes have a level cap, which can start to feel boring.  The DLCs offer a lot of additional content, however they're not as massive as the ones from Borderlands, and some of them (Like Hammerlock's Hunt) are ones you just want to get through as quickly as possible, so don't expect them to take a long time to complete.  The game has its share of bugs and glitches, but most of them are minor and don't effect your gameplay.   Also, taking this game to open-to-all online co-op is risky, as people hacking the game (or even your character) is a major issue. So it's safer to co-op with people you know, but the game is still a lot more fun with a full squad of players, even if you can do everything solo.

I had never played the first Borderlands but after seeing gameplay footage I felt confident in purchasing Borderlands 2 and it was money well spent. The game itself is a blend of FPS and RPG elements that balance the two together without making the gameplay feel awkward. As with most RPG systems you steadily increase the level of your Vault Hunter and gain access to talent tree builds that change up the many ways you can approach combat in this game. The FPS element adds another depth of variety on how you handle encounters with its many ranged weapons. (pistols, shotguns, sniper rifles, sub machine guns, etc) The system is very good at complimenting the pace and tactics that the player enjoys using. Charge in shoot everything in the face with a shotgun or perform stealthy sniper headshots from complete safety its up to you. Harder difficulties after completetion add decent replay value and improved weapons and loot for those that want more along with extra DLC classes and content. Pros - Fluid and smooth controls, plenty of player choice, multiplayer with friends, and memorable characters (TINY TINA!!!) and probably one of the best lead villians I have seen in a game in a long time. CONS- Can feel repetitive on consecutive playthroughs, a good friend of mine completed the first Borderlands and found it to be much of the same and similar individuals will probably not enjoy it as much as I did since it was my first introduction to the series. 8.5-9/10 Gameplay this smooth is always a plus even if it closely mirrors its origins.

Otherwise it's pretty much the FPS version of Diablo 2, but in a world where the villains and half the NPCs have perpetual high school mentalities.

*Gnome Seal of Approval* A good game for sure. No doubt about that. Great gunplay, cool setting (if you're into post apocalyptic future stuff), fun characters and lots of content.  I'd recommend this to anyone who like RPG shooters (this is an RPG in the lightest of sense). Chances are, though, that you allready know what Borderlands is all about.  What made me stop playing it boils down to three points. First off, the unbalanced difficulty. I'm basically breezing through the game with little to no effort. Shields rarely gets depleted. Then suddenly a bossfight that totally steamrolls you. After a multitude of tries and lots of swearing (in my case) you finally manage to finish him/it/her off and you're back to EZ mode.  Secondly, timed delivery missions. Why put those in a shooter? Seriously.  And thirdly; it's too long. At least in my opinion. I typically prefer my games to last about 15-20 hours. Not 40. I have other games I want to play too. But hey, that's just me.  Solid game, but I didn't finish before going tired and frustrated.

This is a truly amazing game. The graphics are great, there's hours of gameplay, a lot of DLC packs (if you want more content), lots & lots & lots of guns (there's even a gun that shoots exploding swords, you can find it while you're enjoying the extra content from the DLC pack 'Tiny Tina's Assault On Dragon Keep'). In addition to that there's suicidal pyschos, even an obese cannibalistic mother! So I don't wind up writing a 15 page long review, I'll just say this: Choose Borderlands 2 if you're looking for a game with a TON of weapons, enemies and content.

Okay, so Borderlands 2 is a FPSRPG game developed by Gearbox. In this game, GUNS. Its GUNS GUNS GUNS GUNS GUNS. Seriously, its all about the guns. Guns are really important in the Borderlands series. You find guns in chests or quests or perhaps EVEN A PILE OF VOMIT (I'm serious). Also, you can LvL up until 50 (61, if you have the DLC that raises your level, LvL 72 if you also bought the other DLC) You have 4 classes here.  Gunzerker (Salvador) Action Skill: Dual-wielding guns/Gunzerking. (Resembles Brick in 1st game)  Siren (Maya) Action Skill: Phaselocking/Trappin' baddies in a ball. (Resembles Lilith in the 1st game)  Commando (Axton) Action Skill: Deploying a Turret (Resembles Roland in the 1st game)  Assassin (Zer0, he's my personal favorite) Action Skill: Activating Decepti0n (Meaning he becomes invisible and his Gun Damage and his Melee Damage increase) (Resembles Mordecai in the 1st game)  There are also DLC charcters which currently are 2 as of May 18, 2013. (There might be new classes in the future)  Mechromancer (Gaige) Action Skill: Deploying Deathtrap, a robot. (Dosen't resemble anyone cause there were no DLC charcters in Borderlands 1)  Psycho (Krieg) Action Skill: Going into a rampage where you can either swing your buzz axe or throw it, which is pretty cool. Aside from that, very humorous one-liners. (As I said, no DLC characters in the 1st game)  Overall Statistics:  Gameplay: 10/10: Nice work on the gameplay, Gearbox, here have a chocolate chip cookie.  Arsenel: 10/10: Estimate of over 87 billion possible guns  Co-op: 9/10: We need sharing of loot, please. Still pretty good though.  Characters: 10/10: Psychos recite Hamlet, Handsome Jack is a pretty cool villain, and the 6 classes have a pretty funny dialogue, especially Krieg.  Story: 9.5/10: Great story, nothing to say here  DLC's: 9/10: The Captain Scarlett DLC is for loot, The Torgue Campaign DLC has a very funny dialogue, Tiny Tina's DLC created its raid bosses with great design, Hammerlock is probably my least favorite.  Art Style: 10/10: The cartoonish feel for the Borderlands is fitting.  Classes: 10/10: 6 badass classes who save Pandora, nothing else. Also you have skill trees (which upgrade your Action Skill, entire self, etc) which you can manipulate to fit your style of playing this awesome game.  Humor: 10/10: Oh my god if you don't think Borderlands 2's humor is hilarious, I will come to your house, and have a serious talk with you, mister.  Overall: 9.5/10   To conclude, its an exemplary game, with alot of weapons, cool characters and the co-op is nice as well.  See ya next time guy-who-is-reading-this-review. - Guns

Great to play alone, even better with friends, this space Western pits the player against the hilariously evil Handsome Jack in a quest for loot, money, experience and saving the world in that order of importance. The comics-inspired world eschews the usual three-tone palette of most FPS's (grey, brown, muzzle flash) in favor of a highly colorful and violent realm to run, shoot and even drive across. This game goes on sale frequently, so there is no excuse not to experience one of gaming's most fun franchises.

So, I recently played trough this game, and I must say Gearbox just can't get thier endings right. This game even mocked it's predecessor for having a bad ending, but in my oppinion it didn't do a much better job itself. But hell what does that matter anyway with a game as awesome as this. And no it is not awesome in the meaning that it will inspire speechlessness on you, but in the modern meaning that IT'S-COMPLETELY-BONKERS-AWESOME. I love this game as much as I loved the first one. The sequel improved on gunplay, movement, car-handling, storrytelling, character customisation and all the other stuff. It did however manmage to botch up the menus even worse than the first game, and they are clearly optimised with controller in mind, and doesn't even work with mouse half the time. Don't expect anything clever with this game, as it isn't. Instead it is a fun shooter with fun mechanics, a bit bulletspongy, but I managed to get around that by using more stonky weapons such as snipers. As mentioned before I really like this game, but it is not without flaws and nowhere near a perfect game. One of my favourite things about it is the artstyle, wich pretty much keeps itself true to the first one, but I absolutely love the cartoonish style, and the nice drawn textures.  I can really reccomend this game if you like brainless fun, but beware of bullet-spongy-ness, and a f*cking annoying CL4P-TP. Seriously he's so annoying -.-

Borderlands 2 is a loot/shoot/loot-them-up. Basically, you will get many hours of fun out of this game, even more so with friends. The gun play is decent, the looting is where it is at, there is a huge variety of guns, and the dialogue in this game is fantastic. The story is way better than the original borderlands storyline(if you could call it a story). The visuals carry on the unique style and it looks great. The environments vary from snowy tundras to exotic deserts to lands filled with molten lava. I definetely recommed this game. I would also recommend picking up Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep, it is an excellent example of how DLC should be done, it adds a crap ton of content, new storyline, and brings back those culture references that Borderlands 2 is so known for.  game is 9/10 in my eyes.

Combining the FPS and RPG genre is something not all too new these days, but Borderlands 2 gives it a shot once again and succeeds - for the most part. Though the story is quirky and witty, the loot table system and combat that is akin to hack and slash games quickly becomes repetitive, as well as the quests that are given to you in which you will soon notice a monotonous pattern. This second installation overall feels more like an expansion to Borderlands, rather than a sequel, as there are no notable changes. That being said, if you can't get enough of Borderlands, this game will not disappoint you.

Fun shooting and good comedy, but the character builds are too simple and enemies have unnecessarily large amounts of health. Playing with a full team of 4 negates the oversimplistic character builds and over-healthed enemies enough to make it fun. Playing alone.... enemies should seriously have their health halved. At least, the 'powerful' enemies should. I don't consider giving an enemy WAY too much health a threat or a good form of drama to make me feel that it's important. I feel it's wasting my time. Make exceptionally powerful enemies a challenge in more ways than tons of health.  Otherwise, the game is great all around. Definitely worth playing through alone. ABSOLUTELY worth playing through with friends (full party of 4). I would suggest NOT playing new game + or new game ++ (known as 'true vault hunter mode' and 'ultimate vault hunter mode', respectively). Just play through the first run then do it again with a different character while doing all the DLC you've bothered to get (preferably both run throughs with friends). New game+ modes just make the high-health problem even more prevalent for enemies. It's annoying and adds nothing to the game imo.  Recommended fun with friends.

Short description: A game like shares the DNA and characteristics of Diablo-like games. Borderlands 2 isa loot-heavy, sci-fi, first-person shooter. And like Diablo, a surprising amount of lore to keep you busy going from location to location, and loot to loot. The settings and voice-acting is top notch, but like Diablo, mostly a non-interactive, pretty yet sterile environment to run and gun. And like Diablo, a bit slow in the beginning. And like Diablo, fun to play in solo, but a blast if you can rope a friend or two into co-op, where it really shine.

Capable of meeting all of the expectations of Borderlands veterans and welcoming newcomers without making them feel lost, Borderlands 2 is one of the best games out there. The game is very long (if you go for all of the sidequests, which is EXTREMELY recommended), but it manages to remain entertaing at every step of the way - quests don't feel repetitive, and thanks to a healthy dose of excellent humor, you'll be wanting to play it again. The game is considerably harder - enemies now scale to your level much more often than in the original game, leveling up is considerably harder and money drop has been DRASTICALLY reduced (prices were balanced, too). Newcomers will love it and veterans will have an excellent time. Worth every cent. DEFINITELY recommend.

I've been having a blast with this game. It is like a hybrid FPS and RPG. You're characters level up and unlock more abilities. The weapon types are the same throughout the game, but the loot drops level with you. You will end up with your favorite setup and keep looking for more of those guns at higher and higher levels. I also really enjoy the elemental system, and how some units are immune to certain weapons. But most importantly, the boss fights are what make it a great game. Even after you beat the main storyline, there are new quests and harder bosses to try fighting. This is even better when you have friends playing with you. I am waiting for it to go on sale, so I can have a few more peeps pick it up.

Borderlands 2 is the continuation of the adventures on Pandora, a planet inhabitated by fearsome creatures, dangerous adversaries, and the so-called mythical and valuable 'Vault'.  The game is diverse in almost every way, including the landscape and level design, selections of weapons and a wide variation of NPCs and enemies. Simply put, an amazing game. They took a great game, and just improved upon it.  Multiplayer works way better. There is now finally a shared gear stash. Falling damage is removed. Also there is now an optional(you can turn it off) Bad ♥♥♥ perk system that works across all your characters, which replaces weapon specialization. Weapons and gear are a bit more unique now, plus Slag-damage has been added. They listened to players and added a lot more variation to the environments. Several amusing new NPCs have been added to the mix, but you will run into some old favorites.The is also a lot more character customization, with varying heads and more detailed skins. Now you have to use Eridium as cash to purchase storage and ammo upgrades. Gambling can be amusing too. The main quest and side quests are clearly marked. Be warned, many of the main quests take an hour or longer to complete.   The game really a ton of fun, especially with good friends. GET YOU ONE!!1!

Fun if you like an rpg shooter. Fun in solo and co-op, but I recommend co-op because you get better loot and the action is much more intense. Enemies will react when you inflict damage to them with your weapons or melee. Has plenty of ini guides over the internet for tweaking settings [such as turning off cel shading or shadows, etc that will increase your performance] in your notepad/etc file. You can respec your skill points for a cheap amount so you can try many different playstyles when you feel like it. Short-ish campaign, a bit grindy when leveling though. Most of the guns will have different iron sights, which adds to the fun. If you like the borderlands 2 shift codes on facebook, they give you free shift codes for keys you use for the golden chest to get nice purple weapons, scales with your level.

Even from the start of the game, the player follows an obligation to be engaged with the plot as well as the various aspects of any great FPS game (e.g. weapon specs and character growth/development) that ultimately sustain variety and interest. This, along with extra elements such as character design modifications and the Shift Key Code system assist and immerse players in this unique and awesome game.

I've never felt so conflicted about a game. I love what it tries to do, but hate how it does it. Addicting and compelling loot-motivated gameplay, RPG leveling-up, creative weaponry, and wonderful worlds of creative and extremely effective dialogue with references of memes to retro gaming, the first game to do such of what I can recall. But then, once the game loses that honeymoon luster, the game derails and becomes a heartless loot quest with bullet-sponges in the way, but your friends to liven the experience. A game that can't stand alone without the help of being enjoyed with friends comes as a weakness in design. I could have fun with my friends doing things none of us enjoy solely based on the fact we're suffering together. I love this game, one I might have played too much, but it could do so much more to take away its artificial difficulty and push beyond the comfort zone it created for itself.

This is a fantastic first person shooter. when compared to your average 'Call Of Duty' or 'Battle feild' it's nice to have a new range of colour and art style. As far as the Shooting mechanics go it's fairly standard and easy to get to grips with. The weapons however are all individual '87 Bazzilion guns.' the loot drops are randomized but limited by level with gives the player a massive spectrum of playstyles to choose from. The characters are well balanced for each class but can be changed depending on playstyle e.g. if playing a zero you could go down the sniping tree for long range of Bloodshed for close combat.  Overall a fantastic and diverse game and a nice change from the norm.

At low levels the game is playable solo, but as the difficulty increases I find that content is only available in multiplayer co-op. The leveling systems means that you will only be an effective partner if you are within 3 levels of the enemies. In other words, the population is divided in such a way that I often find nobody playing online in my level bracket.   As the game ages, expect to find no players available. The good news is that all content is available in the normal mode(the easiest version) so you aren't missing out on anything. Just remember that with the level dispersion that you may never find anyone to play with.   The storyline is well written just remember to play through the content at easy level and play in coop, if possible, when it gets hard.   I recommend this game when it's at reduced price from a sale, in the single digits range.

Ohhhhhhhhhh Borderlands 2. What to say, what to say.  You are a Vault hunter, Pandora is claimed by a man named Jack. You team up with the old crew of Borderlands (the original) to stop his reign of terror. You start your journey with Claptrap, a seemingly quirky robot, and travl throughout the lands of Pandora, gunning down, and slaughtering any foe that stands in your way.  Eventually, you reconvene the four orignal Vault Hunters and go on a search for 'Angel' who seems like some sort of AI.  You end up attack Jack's base and you live happily ever after, depending on what ending you chose.  Graphics- 6, They are made a certain way, on purpose, not the best, but not the worst graphics.   Story- 8, The story isn't deep, but the acting and basic plot are good, the characters, though, are deep.   Gameplay- 10, I could spend enless hours just shooting stuff up with all the crazy guns and other wacked out stuff they have.   Mechanics- 7, The controls are sound, and they're aren't as many crazy glitches like its predecessor, it is like any other FPS on the PC.   Replay Value- 8 with exception, With all the DLC and blasting with friends, this game has plenty of replay value, but if you are alone, it does not have that much appeal.  Overall: 7.8, This game is definitely a blockbuster. Worth every penny for the hours of fun that you will get from this.

Is there even a reason to not recommend this game to people? At this point, this series needs no introduction. An expert blend of RPG/Shooter that provides unlimited hours of fun. I'm not going to go over the synopsis or description because its pointless at this time. What I will talk about is why I recommend this game. I love Borderlands is because I usually avoid multiplayer centric games. Like Call of Duty, Battlefield etc. Nothing wrong with them but they just not appeal to me. Not to mention the fact that their Single Player campaign is nothing but a training mode for MP. Borderlands actually have a personality, it stands out among the countless SciFi/Military shooters. It has a crass personality and a wicked sense of humor. Not to mention the fact that it provides hour upon worth of gameplay. With different player classes, it always makes you want to try experimenting with different characters. However, I do think that the story could use a better writer to make it more cohesive, not just a bunch of missions loosely woven together. Besides that and some rather annoynig time centric side missions, it is a terrific game. I hiughly recommend it to people who are sick and tired of the likes of CoD or Battlefields of modern shooters.

Yes I recommend it. Confused? Let me explain. I played the heck out of BL2. I played BL1 to death before I even had a Steam account or even cared for FPS games. I love the art, characters, dialogue, banter, jokes...I mean I love it all. I did....until UVHM came along and ruined the game totally. Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode...at the time I quit playing, was the top difficulty setting to play on and to do this youd play through normal all the way through again and again until you hit the difficult playthrough UHVM. Whats wrong with playing through a few hundred missions a few times? Nothing as long as the gameplay allows you to feel a sense of power. As you progress the weapons scale with you and enemy life bars scale a bit faster until the last playthrough where it takes more ammo than you have on your person to take down a simple mob and bosses are reduced to a high pressure grind fest. In BL1 you feel that sense of power. You feel strong when you attack a group of bad guys. You feel like the comic book, John Woo styled hero, just blazing away at the baddies. There was a sense of danger and a sense of heroism as you battled on through hordes of monsters and midgets. In BL2 when you get to the fabled UVHM, which is forced upon you as you purchase a DLC, you dont feel heroic. You feel like a victim. Pushed into a corner as you constantly die. Enemies resisting your attacks on an elemental AND physical level. The game forces a particular style of play. Slagging! Allow me to introduce to you the element known as Slag. Its the element pretty much ignored for lack of importance on the first few playthroughs. Slag increases damage. Thats it. Its a mechanic that you use to basically manage damage on powerful enemies. It also wears off every few seconds so you have to re Slag an enemy every few seconds. Couple this with a horde of overpowered 'bad asses' and you get a dysfunctional damage management game instead of a shooting party. This is every encounter during the last mode of play. Enemy appears. You get tagged with a shot. Shields down. Slag shots. Enemy slagged. Switch to gun of choice. Blast a few rounds. Enemy becomes resiliant. Switch back. Hit 'Special' and hope it regens health because most likely youre low on health at this point. Slag...bam bam bam...switch...Slag...bam bam dead. One baddie down. Rinse and repeat for another 12 thousand enemies of increasing difficulty to go. Couple that with a few other issues like lack of gun variety, lacluster 'cover', worthless skills as a point sink, and TONS of crap items flying out of every badguy you can hit. I still recommend this game for ONE thing. Dont get the all the DLC if you DO buy this game. Get this game and really play the heck out of the story the first time and on the second playthrough go through the DLC as released in order. Its worth every penny to one time it. After that however....I just got sick of it after a while. The fighting at higher levels is just a huge unbalanced slaughter.
