It's okay. I personally was never fond of the game's attempt of humour and the combat can get very dull with extended play. the only thing that is interesting is the game's randomly generated weaponry. that feature alone may be enough for some, but I lost interest in Borderlands 2 after a while.

The Good: Bright and colorful artwork. Great voice acting. The storyline is at the low end of good but still a positive. Moments of humor, sometimes subtle and sometimes very crude, add to the overall enjoyment. Fast-paced action is nice, and combat feels suitably frenetic. Four (six with DLC) classes add to the replay factor, as does the plethora of add-on DLCs if you like what you got.  The Bad: Reliance on the random drop system means there is no difficulty curve, just random zig-zagging based on whether you've found a gun recently that matches your spec, play style and the type of enemy you're fighting. Occasionally droughts of good weapons mean the game becomes frustratingly difficult. On top of that difficulty, having an underpowered weapon means you burn through ammo frustratingly quickly, reducing your glorious charge through an enemy stronghold into a SMG clip scavenger hunt, or a back-track race to avoid respawns. The story doesn't give you a strong reason to keep going, and amount of back-tracking and just running through areas you no longer care about can get tedious.  The Bottom Line: Combining the worst parts of MMOs (the grinding, the struggle to find relevant loot, the vast amounts of walking) with the worst parts of RPGs (arbitrarily area level gating through enemy difficulty, fetch quests) on top of a workable but badly-balanced FPS, I really can't recommend this game at full price. I got it as a gift and I felt it was a waste of my time. In short doses it's fun but the grind and erratic difficulty are too much to put up with for a story not compelling enough to get me to keep going.  You'd like this if you like: If you thought that grinding your T0 gear set was the best part of vanilla World of Warcraft. If you think modern games give you too many useful level-up perks and miss Goblins 'n Ghouls-style useless weapon 'upgrades'

Having come from Borderlands 1 and loving it, I'm severely disappointed. Drastically reduced variety of weapons, drastically reduced interesting drops, the same tendency to get stuck on terrain features that are 6 inches tall...  I really wanted to like this game, especially given how much I enjoyed the first installment.  But when every weapon I've ever found (that wasn't a sniper rifle) requires a full clip to kill enemies, even after going through every other possible sidequest beforehand to level up and try to find something other than the pantload of white guns that I always ended up with... well, I found myself angry.  With Borderlands 1, there were a lot of issues that proved annoying, but they were worth working through or ignoring in order to get to the fun part - a variety of powerful guns that allow tons of interesting options, and the excitement about uncovering them just before opening that chest, or killing that Badass. You'd think a sequel would increase the variety that was offered, but the loot system feels gutted - manufacturers now have a gimmick that they cannot stray from, rather than a tendency towards certain effects/stat combinations. This, combined with how rare it was to get anything other than trash, meant that finding the kind of gun that I wanted, which also did any noticeable level of damage, was like finding a needle in a haystack. But whereas in Borderlands 1, you'd be noticing all kinds of interesting needles along the way, in Borderlands 2, it was like the whole thing was needles, except they were all infected. And you needed to search face-first.

So I've played this. I probably will after I write this, because friends of mine enjoy it, perhaps even unironically. I'm not a huge fan of fetch quests and other than a few firearms with some interesting mechanics, I'm not to thrilled by the shooting, so there's a lot I don't like there. The game's enemies are either 'guy that runs at you and blows up,' 'guy that runs at you and hits you a lot' or 'guy that shoots you and maybe makes you explode' and all of them take about five hundred more bullets than they should, so that's out. So what's this review about?  I like one character in this game, even ironically, and that is Krieg. I like him more for his /italics/ video trailer /enditalics/ and his abilities than I do the whole of the rest of the game's characters. They're not funny or interesting and they're annoying for exactly all of the wrong reasons. Imagine Claptrap from Borderlands 1 was copy pasted onto every other character in the game, but now he has some terrible accents to break up the extremely unfunny dialogue's monotony.  You wanna know why I like Krieg? He's got /italics/ potential /enditalics/ to be interesting. I mean he is the sole guy on the planet that has a conscience (and don't tell me any of the other main characters have anything remotely resembling a consicence). He's got a tortured inner self that has to look on at atrocities he commits in abject horror and shame and can do almost nothing about it. It's a small part of him, but it could highlight just how messed up everyone else is in your party that there likely is no inner dialogue. He's literally a stark raving madman and that small part of him is probably more sane than the person playing the game.  Does this show up in the game at all?  Of course not! Can't get in the way of shooting and fetch questing! No need for this supposed RPG to focus on it's supposed characters that are supposedly advancing some kind of plot! That and more lines for Claptrap, our favorite and most beloved character! And involvement of characters from the first game, who now have voices and their own 'plots' and 'interesting' things to say!  There might be redeeming qualities about this game somewhere, but I guess I don't see them. Other than Krieg. And not even Krieg, his /italics/ potential /enditalics/.  Oh wait, there's one: I guess if you're playing this you're not going out and committing actual atrocities. So yay! 'Borderlands 2: Virtual Violence So You Can't Commit Actual Violence' should just be on the box from now on.

I hate this game more than I hate stance and ISIS. There is nothing this game does well or that something else does better. 'B-b-b-but it's fun with friends!' Watching paint dry is fun with friends as well, that doesn't make it good.   The gunplay is typical modern FPS with a mixture of hitscan and projectile weaponry that rely on the use of iron sights to be effective, however the gunplay itself is only mediocre. It is not what makes Borderlands 2 the irredeemable turd that it is.  The visuals are awful, they use a cheap, ugly cel shading trick in an attempt to hide the hideous textures and low poly environments. Speaking of which, all the environments are just empty areas with no thought or care put into their design and traversing them is a boring chore.  The 'gorillion' guns in Borderlands 2 are just a few assets for each manufacturer randomly generated together with marginal stat differences. There is no respect for how guns actually work and are wholly impractical and ridiculous in design.    The menus take the form over function approach and are annoying to navigate and difficult to read at times because they're stylised way too much.   The RPG elements of the game are terrible as well. There is horrendous HP bloat especially at higher levels where the damage and health levels keep rising to ridiculous levels which has the knock on effect of making that gun that you really love worthless after a while and you have to throw it away and get something else not as good just to do damage to enemies. There are different classes in the game in an attempt to diversify gameplay which boils down to every few minutes getting to use their special ability for a few seconds and then it's back to the same old repetive monotony that is this game. Of course it also has the obligatory skill tree which allows you to upgrade arbitrary abilities unique to each character that have minimal effect on the gameplay.  Then there's the writing. Oh, God the writing. Everything is wrong here. Most of the lines and dialogue stem from the 'LOL SO RANDUMB XDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDDD LE REDDIT MEMES BADASS SO BADASS XDDDDDDDDD' school of thought with a bit of the trademark Anthony '>tfw no Wii U' Burch forced social justice agenda in there as well. The dialogue and voice acting is always loud, obnoxious and in your face but it isn't funny, it's just annoying and comes off as trying way too hard. Also, the word 'Badass' is so overused it makes 5 year old ♥♥♥♥♥ memes seem fresh in comparison.  Borderlands 2 is worthless garbage and you should never play it. I didn't pay for this and I still regret it.

As you may have guessed from the title, there’s not much new to uncover in the sequel to Borderlands: it has lots of guns, some goofy characters that have returned from the previous game, and a lot of respawning. If you thought all of that was great the first time around, you’ll love this one. If you were lukewarm to all of it, as I was, you won’t necessarily be impressed by what’s fundamentally a retread of the major elements of the first game with a few minor enhancements.  Borderlands 2 picks up several years after the end of the first title: the Vault is open, the Hyperion Corporation wants its treasure and the intrepid heroes from the first game have been waging war against the engineers and robots of Hyperion to ensure that the CEO, Handsome Jack, does not get his hands on it. Borderlands spoiler alert: the end of Borderlands, where you open the Vault everyone’s been after and find essentially nothing, was a terrible conclusion, like Randy Pitchford personally giving you the finger as a reward for finishing his game. As a result, Borderlands 2 spares no opportunity to remind the player that the end of the first game was indeed a substantial letdown. It’s one of those instances of self-referential humor that doesn’t work very well in the game.  Graphically, nothing has really changed about the game, but the original was a very distinctive and handsome game relying on a hybrid cel-shaded 3-D artwork style. The mechanics are very similar to the original: this is basically an FPS with some customization elements. Borderlands 2 has four new characters to choose from, two of which are essentially copied from the first game with some revisions, and two others, the Gunzerker and the Assassin, are unique. There are also some DLC characters available, the Mechromancer (a bit like the Soldier in the first game, but with a pet robot instead of a turret)and the Psycho (a bit like the Berzerker in the first game, a melee-focussed character). Each character has a skill tree that you can plug points into as you level up and, unlike in the first game, there are no real penalties for a specific character to favor one type of weapon over another.  As in the first game, you will need to complete at least some of the available side missions in order not to be too underlevelled for the story content, which does not level with you. On the other hand (so I’ve been advised), if you complete a majority of the available side missions as some Pandoraholics do, you will find your character rapidly overlevels the story content. The new game comes with all of the same flaws (or quirks, if you prefer) that the old one did: a bizarre checkpoint save system that doesn’t even save at a specific checkpoint per se but saves your progress and links it to a specific location on a map; a bizarre fast-travel system that lets you revisit any place you’ve been before but only if you’re actually at a “fast-travel” station; spawnable vehicles that steer using the mouse; and lots of gratuitous deaths. Most of these mechanics feel like they were taken from every console game ever, which makes Gearbox’s decision to retain all of them in the new game’s PC version all the more peculiar.  I will give Borderlands 2 this much: it’s slightly more entertaining than it is aggravating most of the time. Given that, I was able to finish the story in about 30 hours, although there were several hair-tearing boss battles that made me want to quit. However, I will reiterate that this isn’t a very good single-player game. It’s designed for multiplayer and it shows. The entire game appears to be poorly-balanced for a single player who is very close to or on level, although I will concede that it’s possible that I’m just extremely bad at this type of game. After all, I completed my playthrough with the Mechromancer DLC character, who I have been told is an “easy mode” PC.  I played through the Tiny Tina’s Assault on Dragon Keep DLC in about eight hours. There are also some frustrating parts to this story, including some unwelcome platforming elements and annoying boss battles. The narrative is Gearbox’s homage to (or perhaps mockery of) a variety of RPG (both computer and tabletop) conventions and tropes wrapped around Tiny Tina’s acceptance of an event in the main game. While my feeling is that this isn’t really worth the full asking price, I would recommend it if you like Borderlands and role-playing games at all. The pop-culture and RPG references are pretty funny, although the inclusion of tedious switch-flipping and platform-jumping puzzles, even if they are mostly skippable, as references to other games’ overreliance on these mechanics is another case of Gearbox trying to be funny that falls flat. Fortunately the story justifies the more groan-inducing aspects of the gameplay in the case of this DLC, with a genuinely-moving ending that, in typical Borderlands fashion, turns on a dime back to “Let’s go blow some s*@! up!”

Let me tell you up front; this game is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mess.  Let's start with the worst of it all, the writing. The plot revolves around taking down the CEO of the Hyperion Corporation, Handsome Jack, because you're vault hunters and he doesn't want you to find the vault. Now, keep in mind, the story doesn't actually involve YOU. In fact, the player characters are rarely, if ever even mentioned or directly referred to. The player is sometimes addressed in ECHO calls and cutscenes, but seldom will you feel that your efforts actually matter.   No, the real heroes of this game are... well, the heroes of the last game. I could dedicate an entire review to talking about how horribly written, unfaithfully portrayed, and hamfisted the previous Vault Hunters are, but that would take too much time. Basically, they're all annoying pieces of trash that only exist to take any and all enjoyment out of your experience with the game. Roland is your generic leader figure who can disarm a robot with his bare hands but can't remember to wear a ♥♥♥♥ing shield on a planet where shields are common items and are established as things that everyone has. Lilith is your generic 'badass chick' who in one scene can't even teleport the player characters twenty feet but then mere hours later has no trouble teleporting an entire city halfway across the continent, and is also an incompetent ♥♥♥♥♥ who acts as a plot device against all warnings. Mordecai is your generic alcoholic whose character is based entirely on jokes and failed delivery. Brick is the worst of the bunch, the generic energetic bruiser type who can brutally mutilate fifty guys with his bare hands in less than an hour but falls to his knees and cries at the mention of a hurt puppy, and the game will not stop bashing you over the head with his presence once he's introduced to the plot. On top of that, it tries to treat their adventure from the last game as if it were some epic immortalized in the history of Pandora, and not just a matter of a bunch of thieves running around in a desert for forty hours before fighting a giant tentacle monster.  The plot is just a load of garbage. I mean this from the bottom of my heart, it is complete and utter nonsense. Literally, an 8th grader trying his hand at fanfiction can do better than this tripe. It's riddled with plot holes, melodrama, and padding. It starts out as this light-hearted, campy shooter, and then attempts to have emotional impact and get the player involved, as if it were this deep, enthralling story. It then trips over itself trying to force more jokes into the mix while simultaneously being unable to remember that the player has absolutely no attachment to any of these characters, has no reason to form an attachment, and is probably fuming from the fact that they have to trudge through yet another sidequest padded, unnecessarily large area. The plot has poor timing, doesn't compensate for the fact that the game doesn't have a set pacing, and tries to treat its main story like it's in any way engaging and not only being completed so that there are more areas to farm for loot. The plotline with Handsome Jack is somewhat redeeming... for the first ten minutes, and then it faceplants into a ditch, contradicting itself literally around every corner. If anything, it's obvious that the game is hinging itself entirely on the humor. There are some genuinely funny parts of the game, both in scenery and in spoken dialogue -- it's just that you'll have to dig between the piles of year-old internet memes and ancient slapstick to find them.   Now let's talk about the somewhat bearable part of the game. The shooting mechanics are generally what you'd expect if you've played any first person shooter made within the past six years. The controls are responsive and movement is very fluid, although you'll quickly find that you move just as slow in this game as you do in practically every other modern shooter. They attempt to subvert this by letting you jump very high, but your actual walking motion will start to feel very, VERY slow, especially in areas where, for some reason, vehicles aren't included. There are four different character classes (six with DLC) that all function somewhat differently. They each have their own action skill, and Gearbox at the very least did a decent job of balancing their capabilities (as far as I could tell, anyway.) Beyond that, your skills all revolve around passive damage bonuses, enhanced combat abilities (such as throwing grenades in fight for your life or being able to run faster after a kill) and upgrades to your action skill.  I'd like to dedicate a paragraph to talking about how utterly broken the 'Fight For Your Life' system is with regards to how often you'll be stuck in it because of the enemies' perfect accuracy and nonsensical damage scaling, but this might have more to do with the fact that I played in a stack of four players, and that I'm probably not that great at the game. Be wary of higher levels, however, where enemies will take dozens of shots to kill while being capable of destroying your entire shield and half your health with a single bullet. Something in me feels that the game is balanced toward you, the player, dying in every single enemy encounter, considering the sheer number of skills each class has dedicated to enhancing your fight-for-your-life capabilities.  As far as loot goes, there's not much to say. Gear has varying rarities that may or may not accurately reflect how good the gear actually is. There are dozens and dozens of randomly generated components, both on the visual aspect of the guns, as well as their mechanics. There are some guarantees, such as each brand's special quirks (Dahl weapons burst fire when zoomed, Tediores can be thrown like grenades, Hyperion gets more accurate as you fire, etc.), and then there are some random components, such as weapon accuracy, reload speed, fire rate, magazine size, and damage. I wouldn't say that no two guns are alike, but there's enough variety in terms of randomization to ensure that it'll be a rare occurence if you ever do find the exact same weapon twice. My only complaint with this system is that in order to find the really rare guns (read: the only ones that are worth a damn past level 40), you pretty much have to farm bosses. This process is rather painless, but extremely tedious and monotonous just the same.  Enemy AI doesn't have much worthy of mention. There are three enemy types: bandits, robots, and bugs, and you will be utterly sick and tired of every single one of them before you're eight hours into the game. All enemies act the same; if they're melee or suicide units, they haplessly run at you with no regards to the damage they're taking. If they're ranged units, they will zig-zag around or hide behind cover. There are also flying units, but I think I'll let you explore that special ring of hell just for yourself -- let's just hope you never have to shoot for a second wind if they're all you're fighting. I also hope you never intend to find truly decent loot from enemies that aren't area bosses.  The visual department is pretty much the only space where I can give solid compliments, but still no perfect scores. The cel-shaded style really works in the game's advantage, and the environments are a huge step up to the non-stop deserts and industrial areas featured in the first entry (now you get snow and some trees!) Enemy designs are decent, albeit they could use some more differentiation, especially with the robots. However, you might notice a few big errors. For one: THERE ARE NO FACIAL EXPRESSIONS IN THIS GAME; EVERYONE WEARS THE EXACT SAME NEUTRAL EXPRESSION NO MATTER WHAT THEY'RE DOING OR SAYING. YES, THIS IS A HUMONGOUS PROBLEM IN A GAME FROM A MILLION-DOLLAR CORPORATION, THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO EXCUSE FOR THIS ♥♥♥♥.  I'd mention sound, but I ran out of space to write about it. Game's enjoyable for a while but riddled with flaws. 5/10.

Some good points, but a moronic savegame system spoils it.  The top line says it all, really. This is a nice-looking game, and the gameplay is generally good. However, the save game system is an absolute deal-breaker for me and, if I'd been warned about it, I'd never have wasted my money on the game. Simply put, there is no facility to 'save right here, right now', although the quit menu gives the impression that that's what you're doing. You're not; the game gives you the option to save, and you might think that that would mean when you come back to the game and choose 'continue', that's where you start. Wrong; the game remembers what you've done: what xp you've accumulated, what items you've picked up, what ammo you've expended; however, it drops you right back at the start of that section, with all new enemies in your way again. This is, frankly, shoddy, and reminds me of old console games with their limited save points. Apparently it's something to do with multiplayer games, but I have no particular desire to play this as anything other than a single player shooter. Why is there no option to start a game as single-player only, and save wherever you want? There should at least be an option to restart your game at one of the many checkpoints you've reached since the start of the level.  End of the day, this game looks good, but unless you've got the time to run through entire sections from start to finish, the savegame system means you'll see the same terrain, and the same mobs over and over again. They, of course, will be at full health and fully armed, while you've already fired off a load of ammo getting through it initially. Glad I bought it when it was on sale, wasting my money on full-price would have been even worse.

Deleting the INF files did nothing, validating the game did nothing, reinstalling the game did nothing, reinstalling Steam did nothing. 2K's support was less than helpful and none of the 'fixes' I could find online worked. For a game that has been out this long it is dissapointing that so little has been done to fix this KNOWN issue. This ultimately made the game unplayable so I would NOT recommend the Steam version of this game to anyone. System specs: Windows 8.1 (64bit), AMD FX-9370, 16GB RAM, AMD Radeon R9 200 Series graphics card.

I like the guns in this. They all look cool and there are enough different kinds that you can play using any strategy you want. The shotguns and assault rifles kind of suck though. The stats are likewise very customizable. You can try out a little of everything the game has to offer and not feel underpowered from not having a focus. Combat rarely feels like drudgery; every kill is just different enough to be satisfying in its own way. The busy comic-booky graphical style looks cool but the characters are pretty lifeless, though nicely designed. The open world is nothing special. There's no reason to get excited at the prospect of getting from point A to point B. The vehicle controls are bad and dumb. Sigh.  The story is blehhhh. The bad guy is going to destroy the planet you are on by letting some kind of monster out from underground. I have played this game for 20 hours and have only encountered this guy through voice communiques where he brags about how evil he is and says ~WaCkY~ things. The approach to humor here is dumb and overblown. It reminds me of Patton Oswalt's bit about 'punching up' animated films. It just has goofy voice clips bolted onto a game that is colorful but not actually particularly funny. This feels desperate and pathetic at times, like a happy dog that jumps up on you. There's a lot of jokes about killing midgets, and I don't get why that's funny. It's just off-putting. Little people exist, and they have had a hard time of things throughout history because of jokes like these that make them the target of ridicule. I'm not just acting offended on their behalf; it made me feel dirty, because the game, in requiring you to kill lots and lots of midgets and then congratulating you on it, makes you an accomplice to its cruel and insensitive attitudes.  The reincarnation mechanic might be the dumbest aspect from a gameplay standpoint. If you die, you just respawn at a checkpoint minus a few hundred bucks (this is the only thing cash is good for, as you regularly loot better stuff than can be bought from vendors) and then wander through empty areas back to where you were and wipe out the rest of the enemies. So if it comes down to it, you can mindlessly brute-force your way through any given mission. Shouldn't you actually have to be good at a level to pass it? Maybe it's less stupid in multiplayer? Diegetic devices that allow player characters to die over and over again (Bioshock and PoP:SoT also come to mind here) always seem too clever by half, are rarely internally consistent, and can even (as seen here) be detrimental to gameplay. The best instance of it was probably the otherwise-mediocre Scrapland, which not only had NPCs use it too but built the entire story around the mechanic without making it a hokey meta framing thing like Assassin's Creed.  If you like games that are fun, but irritating and mean-spirited, well then Borderlands 2 should be right up your alley.

Borderlands 2 is a great FPS ruined by an obnoxiously ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and grindy leveling system which requires a non trivial investment of time for which the player is rewarded with tiny amounts of experience points, a large assortment of fairly useless loot drops, and currency rewards that might as well be pocket change scrounged from under the cushions and out of crannies of your couch. And as if that isn't enough, the penalty for dieing is pretty steep whereby the player is financially punished with a significantly large chunk of change taken from the player's in-game earnings each time the player respawns. Another fun-killing aspect is the miniscule ammo clip sizes, where the player spends more time reloading than shooting(what? did the anti-gun lobby get involved in the dev process somehow?).  Pros: You can kill stuff and blow ♥♥♥♥ up. No monthly subscription fee Trading Cards  Cons: Grindy Time Sink Too many weapons, armors, and class mods ♥♥♥♥♥♥ reward system: very low ROI Too many quests which detract from the story line Too much DLC  I would only recommend picking up BL2 if you can get it on sale for a significant discount: $5.00USD or less. As it is, it's an overpriced killjoy of a game.

UPDATE 10/15/2014: Oh boy have I hit the jackpot here, if you insist on playing this series because you find it fun, I encourage you to pirate it, not buy it, heck, sell pirated copies of it too, do everything you can to divert money from Gearbox. Why? Well the creators were caught in a bit of hot water lately which personally has me disgusted and puts them worse than EA. See, Gearbox was the one making and showing off all those trailers for Aliens:CM. You know the bait & switch ones that were all lies and completely different games? Well the UK doesn't take kindly to false advertising and is charging them with $2,000,000 in fees. (When EA was given a similar situation with Dungeon Keeper iOS they paid their fine...) Gearbox (however) wanted to play dumb and say that it wasn't their fault at all, instead it was all SEGAs. So SEGA took them to court and proved that it was in fact Gearbox. Despite this tretchery SEGA still offered to pay $1,200,000 of the bill, as they should have kept a closer eye and tighter leash on Gearbox. That's over half the fine they're offering to pay there, for something they didn't do. But no, Gearbox's CEO said, and I quote 'I'm Randy Pitchford, I'll do whatever the f*ck I want.' and refuses to pay a penny for all the false advertising he did to get his game sold.  So do you *really* want to support a company that sees you as nothing more than cash to be gathered? Do you *REALLY* want to keep giving money to people who will happily lie to your faces just to make a quick buck? If you answer 'yes' then congrats, you're an indoctrinated fanboy/girl who not only doesn't belong in the gaming community, but is contributing to what is making it die. So long as people support these kinds of practices, they will continue to be used. Enjoy your always online DRM, unfinished games that use memes as their selling point, and companies that openly screw you over and don't care. But I, as a true gamer, will not stand for it and watch my favorite hobby be destoryed by greedy non-persons like Gearbox and EA. And the blind sheep that follow them.   [11/30/2013] 'Why do we have to spend all this time upgrading things we can already do? It's called progression in gaming, a must have these days...' - Deadpool  With the exception of Tiny Tena's Assault DLC this is pretty... Meh... I mean I totally understand that people don't like challenge anymore because if they get their butt kicked by a bunch of 0s and 1s it makes the a bit angry. But... Ehhhhhh...  I will never understand the attraction of the MMO-styled game. You could have just had a liner plot for us to follow that involves stopping Handsome Jack and busting open the vault and it would have been great. But instead... Not even 10 minute in... 'Please go kill X amount of monster Y'. Oh goodie it's going to be one of these games... Where the creators want it to only FEEL like a longer experience by reusing the exact same four quests with different names and enemies each time. What should have been a 16-20 hour game with a 8-10 hour story suddenly becomes an 40+ hour grindfest. Doesn't matter how skilled you are, the game will not let you go to the next story mission until you've done at least 3 hours of side missions to level up to the point where it won't kill you in one hit, at which point there's not even a challenge in the game, it's just pointing and clicking.  But to be fair, the people buying this game aren't exactly the most 'gaming talented'. It takes a truely... special... type of gamer to die in a game with no learning curve. There is something seriously wrong when you can play a game like this and die, as a level 28, while I, a level 22 can't even manage to get shot. But hey I guess everyone needs something they can feel good at, and honestly, this is only a *single* step up from farmville. But it's pretty, enjoy your 80+ hour total firework show!  Graphics: 7/10 Sound: 7/10 Story: 4/10 Gameplay: 5/10 Difficulty: 0/10 (if you can't win, grind more, no skill needed) Value: 2/10

Community: Fanboys that refuse to accept the dullness and hypocrisy of a game that mocks the dullness and repetitevness of other games. Even though this is an opinion for a game that came out 3 years ago, which is not only completely irrelevant, but will just be drowned out by blind fanboys. I'm just really, REALLY hateful.

I would only recommend Borderlands 2 to anyone who loves multiplayer or co-op games. If the person was someone who prefered single player games instead, I would not dare recommend this. Borderland 2 is a game that requires co-op assistance to actually be enjoyed. If you're not playing with someone, the game gets quickly boring.  Even from the start I found this game quite disappointing, but when I started playing with others online I got to like it a little more as I played. One other thing you definitely notice in the game is that it can be extremely difficult at times, and not the kind of difficult that would make you determined to try again. When I was soloing the game I died VERY often, and too quickly on a mission. When I was in a group of 2, it was impossible to get through the stage because of how overpowered the enemies were. While I don't mind the missions taking an hour or so to complete, what makes it a true pain is if you don't complete it you have to start from the beginning again if you decide to quit the game.   If I had to make a suggestion, a difficulty adjuster would help not make the game very frustrating for newcomers along with computer co-op partners for those who prefer not to play with others/online. It would surely make the game much more bearable.  What I mostly liked about the game was the great story and characters that made the game lively and interesting. I surely would have loved to see the game until the end if I didn't like it as I do.  I believe Borderlands 2 goes in the category of 'overrated'. While this is a game that would be loved by co-op/multiplayer player fans, players such as me who prefer to solo or single player games will find this game disappointing.  Rating: 5/10

To keep this simple, I'm going to only put in Pro and Con.   Pro:  ~ Fun for Multi playing ~ Somewhat funny NPC conversations  ~ Things explodes  ~ The art direction is quite nice  Con:  ~ The environment is extremely static. Nothing reacts to explosions or any other combat activities (Except barrels or animal crap)  ~ If one inch of a floor pops out, it will stop you dead regardless on if you're running or walking. Seen NPC enemies spaz out from seeming nothing.  ~ Unfriendly exploration for the maps. In another word, very restrictive limited map exploration options.  ~ Mobs fights dirty and often unfairly in a predictable way.  ~ Mobs would roll around and none of your shots will hit it until it stops rolling ~ Extremely low replay value. Same old story line, same old side quests, same old choices, same old rewards ~ The guns you find will not be enough and/or good enough for the job at hand. You will be forced to use the golden keys just to get to the next stages in game and prevent you from pulling your hair out from frustration.  ~ Very low Legendary drop rate (Only found 1 Legendary drop rate in 165 hours of game playing)  ~ Character outfits is extremely generic with mostly just color change options (unless you buy the DLC just to get a few more variations)  ~ Spend $200,000+ on the slot machine, never got anything better than Blue weapons ~ Invisble boundry walls everywhere making it feel very trapped for a map ~ Limit options for cars to drive ~ If you die, all mobs including boss mobs will reset their health instantly  ~ Mobs respawns too quickly (about 10 min)  ~ Getting reincarnated by the machine after death takes so long to wait, unnecessary reincarnation cut scene.  ~ Worth repeating: The environment is extremely static, doesn't encourage any interactions with the environment other than opening chests or blowing up barrels.   Would I recommend this game to anyone?  If you like blowing the crap out of thing in a mindless braindead fashion with a witty but rather linear story line, Yes, recommended.   Otherwise, No. Better games out there to play with and a better use of your time not to play this game.

I am probably in the minority here, but I did not like Borderlands 2. The gameplay is EXTREMELY reptitive(all you do is shoot, loot and drive), the environments almost all look the same, the characters are always obnoxiously overenthusiastic, and the endlessly respawning enemies create for a dull and dragging 20+ hour experience. Thats not to say I didnt enjoy some parts of the game. The shooting is fantastic and claptrap was a hilarious character but the cons far outweigh the pros. 5/10

This game is fun for about an hour. then you realize you are fighting the same NPCs over and over again. In other words, it gets repetative quickly. Co op can be fun, but you run into the same issue with too much repetition. The characters are for the most part, akin to sandpaper accross ones genitals. Every mission is to go into a similarly themed instance area and fight your way thru identical mobs you faced in your last ten missions. The only thing different is the prefix to the names of the creatures and npcs you come up against. The story is pretty unoriginal 'hey I just came to and realized I am being hunted by a super powerful corporation/ bad guy because I'm super powerful and special...' The only reason I would buy this game again, would be if I was desperate for co-op gameplay in an industry slowly trying to kill off co op gamplay. If you dont care to play with anyone else, but just want to kill stuff in a post apocalyptic world, do yourself a favor and buy RAGE or a fallout title. Hell, even Red Faction: Guerilla held my attention longer. Better graphics, more interesting characters and quests IMO..
